The Simpsons includes a large array of supporting characters: co-workers, teachers, family friends, extended relatives, townspeople, local celebrities, fictional characters within the show and even animals. The writers originally intended many of these characters as one-time jokes or for fulfilling needed functions in the town. A number of them have gained expanded roles and have subsequently starred in their own episodes. According to the creator of The Simpsons, Matt Groening, the show adopted the concept of a large supporting cast from the Canadian sketch comedy show Second City Television. [ http://www.avclub.com/content/node/47771/1 Matt Groening: Interview 2006-10-22 Rabin Nathan 2006-04-26 The A.V. Club ] [ Agnes Skinner ] Agnes Skinner, voiced by Tress MacNeille is the mother of school principal Seymour Skinner and first appeared in the first season episode &quot; The Crepes of Wrath &quot; as an old woman who embarrassingly calls her son &quot; Spanky &quot;. However, as episodes progressed, the character turned bitter. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { The Crepes of Wrath &quot; } She is very harshly controlling of Seymour, and treats him like a mother would a small child, once grounding him because he did not say who was at the door after answering it, when it was &quot; The Sugarman &quot;. She hates Edna Krabappel. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Special Edna &quot; } Agnes has married a total of four times, once with Skinner&apos;s father, Sheldon Skinner, and following Sheldon&apos;s death she then married three more times, each time, to a tow truck driver. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Midnight Towboy &quot; } Several Springfield residents (including the Simpsons) are afraid of her. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { The Principal and the Pauper &quot; } When Agnes&apos; real son, &quot; the real Seymour Skinner &quot; arrives in Springfield, Agnes turns him away, unhappy with her new living situation, largely because the true Seymour Skinner is a man who can stand up to Agnes and make his own decisions. Although she appears to not care for the fake Skinner, it turns out she really loves him, although she denies it in &quot; Large Marge &quot;. Agnes&apos;s first name was revealed in the seventh season episode &quot; Bart the Fink &quot;. { Richmond, p. 196 } Before that, the character was known as &quot; Mrs. Skinner &quot;. In the beginning of the series, the writers made several references to Agnes and Seymour&apos;s relationship being similar to that of Norman Bates and his mother&apos;s in the film Psycho. { Jean, Al (2003). Easter egg commentary for &quot; } { Separate Vocations &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Third Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } In &quot; Boy Meets Curl, &quot; it is revealed that some of Agnes&apos; resentment to Seymour may have derived from even before Seymour was born  — during the 1952 Summer Olympics in Helsinki, Agnes competed in the pole vaulting event while 9-months pregnant. When Seymour makes his first kick, he hits the bar, thus, making Agnes lose and subsequently crushing her dreams. { &quot; } { Boy Meets Curl, &quot; first aired February 14, 2010 } However, this would contradict the earlier episode when it is revealed that Seymour isn&apos;t her birth son. [ Akira ] Akira, works as a waiter at The Happy Sumo, a Japanese restaurant in Springfield. He first appeared in the second season in &quot; One Fish, Two Fish, Blowfish, Blue Fish &quot;. Actor George Takei originally voiced Akira in &quot; One Fish, Two Fish, Blowfish, Blue Fish &quot;. Since Akira&apos;s speaking role in &quot; When Flanders Failed &quot;, Hank Azaria has voiced the character, doing an impression of Takei for the voice. { Jean, Al (2003). Commentary for &quot; } { When Flanders Failed &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Third Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } [ Anastasia ] Anastasia is a tiger that performs in casinos with Gunter and Ernst. She debuts in &quot; $pringfield &quot;, where it is explained she was captured from the wild by Ernst and Gunter. She reappears in &quot; Viva Ned Flanders &quot;, performing in Las Vegas. In &quot; The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons &quot;, Gunter and Ernst lose it. [ Arnie Pye ] Arnie Pye, voiced by Dan Castellaneta, is a disgruntled, somewhat eccentric helicopter traffic reporter for Springfield&apos;s KBBL-TV (Channel 6). His name and appearance are a parody of the famous, Pulitzer winning 1930s journalist, Ernie Pyle. His segments are titled &quot; Arnie (or &quot; Pye &quot; ) in the Sky &quot;. He has an apparent dislike of anchorman Kent Brockman, with whom he often gets into arguments on the air, and Brockman once snarled that Arnie was a &quot; jackass &quot;. In earlier episodes he had the name &apos;Bill Pye&apos;. [ Arthur Crandall and Gabbo ] Arthur Crandall and Gabbo (both voiced by Hank Azaria ) are a puppet and ventriloquist who start their own TV show that is in competition with Krusty the Clown &apos;s. The show is a huge hit that ruins Krusty&apos;s career, but Bart then ruins Gabbo&apos;s future by capturing him making a rude comment on TV. The pair are later reduced to low-paying work such as a show at an Indian casino. The pair mainly appeared in season four&apos;s &quot; Krusty Gets Kancelled &quot; but they also appeared in &quot; Bart to the Future &quot;, &quot; Homerazzi &quot;, &quot; All About Lisa &quot;, and The Simpsons Movie. [ Artie Ziff ] Artie Ziff is a former classmate of Marge who becomes an Internet millionaire. He is voiced by Jon Lovitz in all appearances, except for season four&apos;s &quot; The Front &quot;, where he was voiced by Dan Castellaneta. [ Jean, Al The Simpsons: The Complete Third Season DVD Video ] In &quot; The Ziff Who Came to Dinner &quot;, where after he loses his bankrupt company to Homer, Homer is taken away by the United States Securities and Exchange Commission for bankrupting the company, although Artie confesses in the end and goes to jail instead. Strongly disliked by Marge since their experience at the senior prom when he attempts to grope her, he eventually comes to terms with the fact that his personality, not his religion ( Judaism ), is the reason he is disliked. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Half-Decent Proposal &quot; } Animator David Silverman based Ziff&apos;s appearance and body language of a man he went to high school with. [ http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1565538/20070725/story.jhtml &apos;Simpsons&apos; Trivia, From Swearing Lisa To &apos;Burns-Sexual&apos; Smithers 2007-07-29 2007-07-26 Larry Carroll MTV ] [ Baby Gerald ] Gerald Samson, better known as Baby Gerald, also known as &quot; the one-eyebrowed baby &quot;, is Maggie Simpson &apos;s archenemy, known for his large unibrow. He makes his first appearance in &quot; Sweet Seymour Skinner&apos;s Baadasssss Song &quot;, where Lisa refers to Baby Gerald as Maggie&apos;s rival. On a few occasions, Gerald has been shown being pushed in a stroller by his mother outside the Simpson house as in &quot; Lady Bouvier&apos;s Lover &quot;, as the two babies glare at one another. The character&apos;s name was revealed in the episode &quot; The Canine Mutiny &quot;. { Richmond, p. 223 } [ Benjamin, Doug and Gary ] Benjamin, Doug, and Gary (voiced by Harry Shearer, Hank Azaria, and Dan Castellaneta, respectively) are geek s that were once Homer&apos;s dormitory roommates at Springfield University. Gary carries a calculator on his belt and uses ear medicine, Doug is overweight and wears a pocket protector, and Benjamin is black and wears horn-rimmed glasses. { Richmond, p122. } The writer of &quot; Homer Goes to College &quot; Conan O&apos;Brien partially based them on three guys he went to college with, who, he said, were &quot; incredible nerds &quot;. { O&apos;Brien, Conan (2004). Commentary for &quot; } { Homer Goes to College &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Fifth Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } Because time was short, director Jim Reardon used a caricature of animator Rich Moore and colored it black for Benjamin. { Reardon, Jim (2004). Commentary for &quot; Homer Goes to College &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Fifth Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } [ Bernice Hibbert ] Bernice Hibbert, voiced by Tress MacNeille. She is Dr. Julius Hibbert &apos;s wife and is loosely based on the Clair Huxtable character from The Cosby Show. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Duffless &quot; } She has two boys and a girl with Julius. Nevertheless, her marriage is on the rocks; { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Dude, Where&apos;s My Ranch? &quot; } Bernice refuses to kiss Julius, even when an entire audience is looking at them. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Marge and Homer Turn a Couple Play &quot; } Her drinking has been joked about on several occasions; she faints when she reads that prohibition had been introduced to Springfield { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Homer vs. the Eighteenth Amendment &quot; } and attends Springfield Alcoholics Anonymous meetings. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Days of Wine and D&apos;oh&apos;ses &quot; } [ Bill and Marty ] Bill and Marty, voiced by Harry Shearer and Dan Castellaneta, are two radio show hosts and DJs on Springfield&apos;s own radio station KBBL. Marty is middle-aged and balding, while Bill is younger and has a full head of hair. They are responsible for giving Bart his elephant, Stampy, although they were surprised when Bart wanted Stampy, because they thought he would choose the other prize, $10,000. When Mr. Burns monopolized the local media in Fraudcast News, he fired the duo, but they have returned to the job in later episodes. [ Billy ] Billy is Troy McClure &apos;s assistant who appeared in &quot; Lisa the Simpson &quot;, and &quot; Bart the Mother &quot;. He was supposed to appear in more episodes but due to McClure&apos;s voice actor Phil Hartman &apos;s death, he was retired along with McClure. He is a child who appears in Troy McClure&apos;s educational films. He appears in the films &quot; Birds: Our Fine Feathered Colleagues &quot;, and &quot; In The Kitchen with DNA &quot;. He was voiced by Tress MacNeille. A similar child named Jimmy (who at one point McClure also calls Billy) appears in &quot; The Meat Council Presents: &apos;Meat and You: Partners in Freedom&apos; &quot; in the episode, &quot; Lisa the Vegetarian &quot;. [ Birch Barlow ] Birchibald &quot; Birch &quot; T. Barlow (voiced by Harry Shearer on &quot; Sideshow Bob Roberts &quot; and Maurice LaMarche on &quot; You Kent Always Say What You Want &quot; ). He is a conservative talk show host on the radio station KBBL, who in voice and appearance is modeled after Rush Limbaugh. As of &quot; You Kent Always Say What You Want &quot;, he also has a show on Fox News, and serves as a parody of Fox News conservative bias. On his radio show, he declares himself to be &quot; the fourth branch of government &quot; and &quot; the fifty-first state &quot;. He is also the author of the book Only Turkey s Have Left Wings. Barlow plays an important part in the episode &quot; Sideshow Bob Roberts &quot;, in which Sideshow Bob, while jailed, calls Barlow on his radio show, giving Bob an outlet to voice how the prison treats him unfairly. Barlow, knowing Bob is a fellow Republican, sympathizes with his complaints, and influences the rest of Springfield to as well. This leads to Bob&apos;s prompt release and ensuing mayor al election-rigging. Barlow also appears in the episode &quot; We&apos;re on the Road to D&apos;ohwhere &quot; as a customer at Marge&apos;s prescription drug-laden &quot; yard sale &quot;, a reference to Limbaugh&apos;s Oxycontin addiction. Most recently Barlow appears with other Springfield Republicans in the episode &quot; E Pluribus Wiggum &quot;, in which he tells Lisa to make Ralph Wiggum decide whether he wants to run for President as a Republican or a Democrat. [ &quot; Bleeding Gums &quot; Murphy ] &quot; Bleeding Gums &quot; Murphy, voiced by Ron Taylor and Daryl L. Coley, { Daryl L. Coley TV.com. URL accessed on December 7, 2006 } was a jazz musician, idol, and mentor of Lisa Simpson. His actual first name has never been revealed, though Murphy claimed his nickname came from the fact he had never once been to a dentist, as &quot; I got enough pain in my life as it is &quot;. His significant roles were in the episodes &quot; Moaning Lisa &quot; and &quot; &apos;Round Springfield &quot;, though he appears in other episodes, such as &quot; Bart the Daredevil &quot; (where he is yellow), &quot; Dancin&apos; Homer &quot;, &quot; Old Money &quot;, &quot; Flaming Moe&apos;s, &quot; Bart Gets an F &quot;, &quot; Radio Bart &quot;, and &quot; Lisa&apos;s Pony &quot;. In &quot; Dancin&apos; Homer &quot;, he was voiced by Daryl L. Coley. In &quot; Round Springfield we learn that at one point he had enjoyed a fairly successful career, releasing an album ( &quot; Sax on the Beach &quot; ) and appearing on Steve Allen &apos;s Tonight Show, { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { &apos;Round Springfield &quot; } and as one of the Cosby children&apos;s four grandfathers on an episode of The Cosby Show, but quickly lost his money feeding his $1500-a-day habit of purchasing and smashing Fabergé egg s. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Moaning Lisa &quot; } He had taught Lisa to display her emotions through music, prompting Lisa to hold him as an important figure in her life. His last appearance was in &quot; &apos;Round Springfield &quot; { &apos;Round Springfield The Simpsons.com. URL accessed on December 14, 2006 } - after Bart ends up in the hospital, Lisa wanders off to find Murphy dying in a nearby ward. He explains about his life, family, and work to her as well as giving her advice for her upcoming school performance, giving her his saxophone. When Lisa returns, she finds out that Bleeding Gums has died from circumstances which are never revealed. No one, except for Lisa, attends Murphy&apos;s funeral. Lisa soon learns that though he may be gone, he still is alive in her. It is strongly hinted that Murphy and Doctor Hibbert are long-lost brothers, most notably by Murphy&apos;s quote: &quot; I don&apos;t really have a family. All I had was a little brother who grew up to become a doctor. He used to laugh at the most inappropriate times. &quot; Hibbert then laughs inappropriately and says, &quot; Hey, I&apos;ve got an older brother that I&apos;ll never see. He&apos;s a jazz musician or some such. Oh well, bye, bye. &quot; Bleeding Gums Murphy is loosely based on Blind Willie Johnson, at whose feet the young Bleeding Gums character learned. { Matt Groening, DVD commentary for the episode &quot; &apos;Round Springfield &quot; } The voice of Bleeding Gums Murphy was provided by Ron Taylor, while his saxophone playing is provided by Dan Higgins. { Dan Higgins Biography Dan Higgins.net. URL accessed on December 15, 2006 } As a sign of respect for the character, Murphy has been a fixture of The Simpsons opening sequence since the second season. Originally, even after his death, Bart would skateboard past him on the street.In &quot; The Great Wife Hope &quot; Bleeding Gums Murphy is mentioned and supposedly according to Carl he is still alive after Homer asks Carl if he knows African-American boxer Drederick Tatum; Carl takes offense, saying that just because he is African American, he doesn&apos;t know all the other African-American citizens in Springfield. Carl then says that he met Drederick Tatum while he was at a party with Dr. Hibbert at Bleeding Gums Murphy&apos;s house. { Opening Sequence SNPP. } [ Blinky ] Blinky is a three-eyed orange fish featured primarily in &quot; Two Cars in Every Garage and Three Eyes on Every Fish &quot;. Likely mutated by toxic waste from the Springfield Nuclear Power Plant pouring into the river, Blinky became a major news story when he was caught by Bart Simpson. Mr. Burns defends the fish, arguing that his extra eye is merely the next step in evolution. Mr. Burns later goes to the Simpsons&apos; house for a meal to boost his race for governor. Marge, a supporter of Burns&apos; opponent Mary Bailey, deliberately serves Blinky for dinner. Mr. Burns spits the fish out and subsequently loses the election. Blinky was briefly seen again in episodes &quot; Homer&apos;s Odyssey &quot; and &quot; Raging Abe Simpson and His Grumbling Grandson in &quot; The Curse of the Flying Hellfish &quot; &quot;. Blinky also made a brief appearance in an underwater section of tube-way Fry travels through in the pilot episode of the animated series Futurama, which was created by Simpsons creator Matt Groening. [ Blue Haired Lawyer ] Mr. Burns&apos; Lawyer, { Reiss, Mike (2002). Commentary for &quot; } { Bart Gets Hit by a Car &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Second Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } also known as &quot; The Blue-Haired Lawyer &quot;, is voiced by Dan Castellaneta. { Gimple, p. 86 } He first appeared in the second season episode &quot; Bart Gets Hit by a Car &quot;. { Richmond, p. 153 } He is Springfield&apos;s most prominent and powerful lawyer, known for his blue hair and nasal New York accent. He also occasionally appears to serve as a prosecutor. Unlike Lionel Hutz or Gil Gunderson, he is a competent though not necessarily ethical lawyer. He has served as Mr. Burns &apos; head lawyer, helping him out with threats of the Power Plant closing down and of Burns losing his money. He is a member of the Springfield Republican Party. His clients often tend to be antagonists of the Simpsons. The Blue Haired Lawyer played a very important role in Bart&apos;s emancipation in &quot; Barting Over &quot; and works at a law firm named &quot; Luvum and Burnam &quot;. The character&apos;s demeanor, as well as Dan Castellaneta&apos;s voice for the character, are based on Roy Cohn, best known as Joe McCarthy &apos;s chief counsel during the Communist witchhunts in the 1950s. Animator Jim Reardon modeled the character&apos;s appearance on actor Charles Lane. { Reardon, Jim (2005). Commentary for &quot; } { Bart the Fink &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Seventh Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } [ Boobarella ] Boobarella is an ample-chested vampire -looking woman, first seen in the episode &quot; I&apos;m Spelling as Fast as I Can &quot;. She is aware of the size of her breasts, and often makes reference to them on the rare occasion she appears on TV. Her character is a takeoff of Elvira, a character portrayed by Cassandra Peterson, herself a takeoff of Vampira. Her name is probably a takeoff from Vampirella and the 1968 cult science fiction/fantasy/horror film Barbarella, which stars Jane Fonda in the title role. Boobarella uses a stereotypical Eastern European &quot; horror &quot; accent and makes school supplies. [ Brandine Spuckler ] Brandine Spuckler is voiced by Tress MacNeille and is the partner of Cletus Spuckler. Brandine and Cletus are depicted as stereotypical yokels. Throughout the series, the two are shown to be brother and sister, { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Alone Again, Natura-Diddily &quot; } boyfriend and girlfriend, { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { There&apos;s Something About Marrying &quot; } mother and son, { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { The Italian Bob &quot; } and father and daughter. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Little Big Girl &quot; } She is apparently the daughter of Cletus and an alien. She has suffered from rabies, { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Goo Goo Gai Pan &quot; } and admitted to being illiterate. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { 22 Short Films About Springfield &quot; } More recently, Brandine is shown fighting in the Iraq War. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Yokel Chords &quot; } She comes back revealing Cletus is the father of only two of the kids, casting doubt over the paternity of her other children. Assuming that all of the children believed to be Cletus&apos; are also hers, Brandine has 45 specifically named children. Brandine and Cletus were married by Homer during his brief stint as a priest. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Simple Simpson &quot; } On April 27, 2008, more is revealed about Cletus and Brandine in an episode entitled &quot; Apocalypse Cow &quot;; Brandine had married Cletus at the age of 13, and had married four times before that. Some of the most distinct features of Brandine are that she speaks in a thick accent, and wears her red hair up in a high ponytail. [ Brunella Pommelhorst ] The school gym teacher, voiced by Tress MacNeille / Maggie Roswell (in Moaning Lisa) First appeared in &quot; Moaning Lisa &quot;, although her name is not mentioned until &quot; The PTA Disbands &quot;. She has blond hair and usually wears a whistle and takes a tough-as-nails approach to teaching. In &quot; Little Girl in the Big Ten &quot;, she decides that because of the oath she took on Xena, she has to fail Lisa but decides to let her make it up by taking private lessons. In a more recent episode, &quot; My Fair Laddy &quot;, she decides to leave for the year and return the next semester as &quot; Mr. Pommelhorst, the new shop teacher. &quot; [ Bumblebee Man ] The Bumblebee Man, voiced by Hank Azaria, is the star of a Spanish-language television sitcom on &quot; Channel Ocho &quot;, in which he dresses in a bumblebee costume and performs slapstick comedy. In the episode &quot; Team Homer &quot;, his bowling shirt bears the name &quot; Pedro &quot;. He works at the same studio as Kent Brockman. His first appearance was in &quot; Itchy &amp; Scratchy: The Movie &quot;. Bumblebee Man is never seen to take off his costume, even when by himself; the sole exception is the episode &quot; 22 Short Films About Springfield &quot;, in which his private life is shown. In this short segment, he is portrayed as innately clumsy rather than simply acting as such. In general, Bumblebee Man only speaks in simple, over-enunciated (and inaccurate) Spanish sentences. His catchphrases of choice are typically &quot; ¡Ay, ay, ay, no me gusta! &quot; ( &quot; I don&apos;t like it! &quot; ), &quot; ¡Ay, ay, ay, no es bueno! &quot; ( &quot; That&apos;s not good! &quot; ) and &quot; ¡Ay, Dios no me ama! &quot; ( &quot; God doesn&apos;t love me! &quot; ). Quite commonly, his phrases will be intentionally sloppy Spanish. For example, in the episode &quot; 22 Short Films About Springfield &quot;, there are several words used that are not real (such as &quot; wudpequero &quot; for &quot; woodpecker &quot;, rather than the correct pájaro carpintero). The crude Spanish is used so that English-speaking viewers would still understand what was being said. { Season 7 DVD Commentary - &quot; } { 22 Short Films About Springfield &quot; } On occasions, he also speaks English, such as briefly in &quot; Mr. Spritz Goes to Washington &quot;. In &quot; Bart Gets Famous &quot;, he anchored the news with an articulate English accent, filling in for the regular, Kent Brockman. Bumblebee Man is a caricature of El Chapulín Colorado, a character created and portrayed by Mexican television comedian Roberto Gómez Bolaños (a.k.a. &quot; Chespirito &quot; ), and his show consists of simple skits, often involving heavy slapstick. The staff have said that whenever they watched Telemundo, this character was &quot; always on &quot;, thus they created Bumblebee Man, who is also always on the air when the Spanish-language channel is depicted. [ Reiss, Mike 2004 The Simpsons season 4 DVD commentary for the episode &quot; Itchy &amp; Scratchy: The Movie &quot; DVD 20th Century Fox ] His costume was based on one used in the Saturday Night Live sketch &quot; Killer Bees &quot;. [ Flash! 24 Simpsons Stars Reveal Themselves 2007-08-15 2000-10-21 TV Guide Joe Rhodes ] Hank Azaria won a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Voice-Over Performance for voicing Bumblebee Man, and various other characters, in 2003. [ http://www.emmys.org/awards/awardsearch.php Primetime Emmy Awards Advanced Search Emmys.org 2008-11-05 ] [ Capital City Goofball ] The Capital City Goofball is the mascot for Capital City. He was voiced by Tom Poston. His appearance seems to have been inspired by the mascot of the Philadelphia Phillies baseball team, the Phillie Phanatic. The costume is a creature with a baseball body, with a blue Capital City T-Shirt, yellow arms and legs, a long flat-ended nose, tufts of fur at the side, a red hat with two springs, two costume eyes that look in either direction, and two more eyes that peek outside the mouth. The Capital City Goofball first appeared in the episode &quot; Dancin&apos; Homer &quot; and shared the stage with Homer. In &quot; Bart vs. Lisa vs. the Third Grade &quot;, the Capital City Goofball represents Capital City in the state legislature; he spent 80 million dollars out of his own pocket to win the seat, and now is leading an effort to change the state&apos;s embarrassing, Confederate-symbol centered state flag. With the death of Tom Poston in 2007, it is likely that this character will be retired, if the precedent regarding Phil Hartman and Doris Grau &apos;s characters (except for Lunchlady Doris, who is still used and is now voiced by Tress MacNeille ) is followed. He has not spoken since &quot; Bart and Lisa vs. the Third Grade &quot; and has been reduced to making minor background appearances and usual honking sounds. [ Captain Lance Murdock ] Captain Lance Murdock is a professional stunt devil who appeared more in the early days of the show rather than the newer episodes. He first appeared in &quot; Bart the Daredevil &quot; which featured him in more scenes than other episodes. He later appeared in &quot; I Married Marge &quot;, &quot; Selma&apos;s Choice &quot;, and &quot; Viva Ned Flanders &quot;. He was most recently featured when Krusty was flicking channels on his TV in &quot; Today I Am a Clown &quot;. He also appears in Lisa &apos;s lecture about Lake Springfield in The Simpsons Movie sitting in the audience. His signature bike is the suicycle and has his own action figure complete with ambulance. [ Charlie ] Charlie, voiced by Dan Castellaneta works at the Springfield Nuclear Power Plant as the &apos;Dangerous Emissions Supervisor&apos;. He was briefly replaced by Mindy Simmons, but she got fired afterwards. His first appearance was in &quot; Life on the Fast Lane &quot;. He was briefly out of work due to a unnamed on-the-job injury, where he collected workers&apos; compensation, however future episodes show him back to work. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { King-Size Homer &quot; } { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Homer Goes to College &quot; } He has a wife and two kids { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Homer the Smithers &quot; } as well as a sister with a wooden leg. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Homer at the Bat &quot; } In &quot; The Trouble with Trillions &quot;, Charlie tells Homer (who is working undercover) that he has plans to overrun the American government due to their stalling on making HDTV available; he is soon arrested by FBI agents for conspiracy. Dan Castellaneta said that he did &quot; an imitation of Lenny &quot; (voiced by Harry Shearer ) for the voice. { Castellaneta, Dan (2003). Commentary for &quot; } { Homer at the Bat &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Third Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } [ Chase/Pyro ] Chase, also known as Pyro, is an American Gladiator. He is a parody of the real-life Gladiator Nitro. He first appears in the episode &quot; A Milhouse Divided &quot;, when he is dating Luann after she divorces Kirk. Their relationship ends when she&apos;s caught cheating on him with his best friend Gyro. He also appears in &quot; Wild Barts Can&apos;t Be Broken &quot;, &quot; Mom and Pop Art &quot;, &quot; Alone Again, Natura-Diddily &quot;, It&apos;s a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad Marge, Day of the Jackanapes, A Star Is Born Again, and &quot; The Bart of War &quot;. He is voiced by Hank Azaria. [ Cookie Kwan ] Cookie Kwan (voiced by Tress MacNeille ), is an Asian American real estate broker who first appears in the Season 9 Simpsons episode &quot; Realty Bites &quot;. She is the stereotypical competitive woman. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Realty Bites &quot; } She touts herself as being &quot; number one on the West Side &quot;, although she also works on the East Side. She is very aggressive toward anyone whom she deems a threat to her business, evidenced by when she threatens Gil Gunderson. She had once attempted to seduce Ned Flanders, { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { A Star Is Born-Again &quot; } had an illegitimate baby with Mayor Quimby, { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { She Used to Be My Girl &quot; } and flirted with Homer. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Large Marge &quot; } She is friends with Lindsey Naegle. She is a Republican. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { You Kent Always Say What You Want &quot; } She is played by MacNeille with a strong and harsh Asian accent. [ Corporal Punishment ] Corporal Punishment is a cast member on the Krusty the Clown show. He first appeared in the episode Itchy &amp; Scratchy &amp; Marge as the enforcer for the show. He is a large man and is always seen in military uniform. [ Crazy Cat Lady ] Eleanor Abernathy { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { See Homer Run &quot; } (voiced by Tress MacNeille ), better known as the Crazy Cat Lady, is a woman with the appearance and behavior of a stereotypical mentally ill person. She first appears in &quot; Girly Edition &quot;. Abernathy is always surrounded by a large number of cats, and in every appearance she screams gibberish and/or throws cats at passersby. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Girly Edition. &quot; } She gives Lisa one of her cats, Snowball V, who looks exactly like her original Snowball II. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { I, (Annoyed Grunt)-Bot &quot; } Abernathy has an unfortunate past. When she was eight, she was a smart and ambitious young girl who wanted to be both a lawyer and a doctor &quot; because a woman can do anything &quot;. She was studying for law school at 16, and by 24 she had earned a law degree from Yale Law School and a medical degree from Harvard Medical School. However, by 32, suffering from burnout, she had turned to alcohol and became obsessed with her pet cat. By the time she turned 40, she had assumed her present state as a drunken, raving lunatic. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Springfield Up &quot; } Abernathy briefly reverts to her sanity and high intelligence thanks to some pills that she shows the Simpsons, but after Marge points out that the pills are actually Reese&apos;s Pieces candy, Abernathy abruptly resumes her deranged behavior. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Homer and Ned&apos;s Hail Mary Pass &quot; } When participating in a mayoral election, she lucidly discusses topics such as health care, economy and public education in between her screams and gibberish. In the episode &quot; Eeny Teeny Maya Moe, &quot; Abernathy reveals that she once owned a cat with Moe Syzlak after he says that there &quot; Is a much creepier guy right next to me. &quot; from a public library computer. She yells &quot; You know I&apos;m a woman! &quot; and also that their cat had kittens; she then proclaims that &quot; These are yours! &quot; and insanely throws three cats at him.In the episode &quot; A Midsummer&apos;s Nice Dream, &quot; Abernathy is shown to be a hoarder. After Marge helps her clean up her house, she begins speaking normally and wearing proper clothing. Later, in an attempt to fix Marge&apos;s new hoarding problem, Abernathy reverts back to her crazy self, reclaiming all of the hoarded junk and calling her cats back to her. { &apos;&apos;The Simpsons episode &quot; } { A Midsummer&apos;s Nice Dream &quot; } [ Crusher and Lowblow ] Crusher (also referred to as Joey) and Lowblow are a pair of stereotypical henchmen often found in the employment of Montgomery Burns as he prefers the hands-on touch you only get with hired goons. Crusher&apos;s first appearance was in the second season episode &quot; Blood Feud &quot; where he is seen escorting Homer off the premises of the Springfield Nuclear Power Plant. The two seem to be on first name terms as Homer calls him Joey. Their first appearance together was in the episode &quot; Last Exit to Springfield &quot; when the two of them kidnap Homer and take him to Burns Manor. They introduce themselves as &apos;Hired Goons&apos;, a term that Homer apparently is not familiar with. The pair rarely had speaking roles and were often used as Mr Burns&apos; goons for a number of early episodes but eventually they became background characters. [ Database ] Database, or Data, (real name unknown to viewers) is a nerd y student who attends Springfield Elementary School. He first appeared in the episode &quot; Bart&apos;s Comet &quot; as a member of &quot; the Super Friends &quot;. He has since had speaking parts in several episodes. He is usually seen with his fellow nerd Martin Prince. Database is a common target for Nelson, Dolph, Jimbo, and Kearney. Database is part of the group of boys who invade Shelbyville in &quot; Lemon of Troy &quot;. He is one of the Pre-Teen Braves in the episode &quot; The Bart of War &quot;. He is a member of the school band, as seen in &quot; The PTA Disbands &quot;. Database is known for his annoying, nerdy voice which is supplied by Nancy Cartwright. Database&apos;s father is shown in &quot; Lemon of Troy &quot;, although he utters no dialogue and is only in the background and has not appeared since that episode. Matt Groening has stated that Database is his least favorite character in the show. { Groening, Matt (2005). (Part Two) &quot; } { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Three Men and a Comic Book &quot; } { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { $pringfield &quot; } [ Declan Desmond ] Declan Desmond (voiced by Eric Idle of Monty Python fame) is an odd and skeptical British documentary filmmaker who has directed several films, including Do You Want Lies with That?, American Boneheads: A Day In The Life Of Springfield Elementary, Growing Up Springfield,Ain’t No Mountain: A Blind Man Climbs Everest and &quot; The Spy Who Learned Me &quot;. Growing Up Springfield is his most notable documentary. It follows the lives of the inhabitants of Springfield, starting when they were in third grade and continuing every eight years. It is a parody of Michael Apted ’s Up Series. Desmond appeared in the episodes &quot; &apos;Scuse Me While I Miss the Sky &quot; and &quot; Fat Man And Little Boy &quot; and his Growing Up Springfield series were featured in the episode &quot; Springfield Up &quot;. The character is based on real British filmmakers David Attenborough and Desmond Morris [ January 2009 ]. [ Dewey Largo ] Dewey Largo, voiced by Harry Shearer, is the music teacher, whom Lisa credited with proving that any piece of music could have the soul sucked out of it. He is very uncreative and is a poor, pathetic music conductor. He is always seen in the opening sequence, teaching his class and throwing Lisa out of his band class when she plays a funky/jazzy tune on her saxophone. His last name Largo is also an Italian word for a slow, broad musical tempo, a possible reference to the fact that he can make any piece of music uninteresting. He has not played a large role in the series, but was originally intended to be an uptight foil for Lisa, and her non-conformist ways. After the first few seasons, Mr. Largo was rarely seen. However he has since resurfaced as a recurring character in the seventeenth season, making appearances in several episodes. In the 17th season in the episode &quot; Homer&apos;s Paternity Coot &quot; it is revealed that Largo was accepted to the Juilliard School, but never got the letter as it was frozen atop Mount Springfield. He ended up at Springfield Elementary instead. A recurring gag since the 17th season episode &quot; See Homer Run &quot;, are allusions that Largo is gay. The 22nd season episode &quot; Flaming Moe &quot; confirmed Largo is gay and in a relationship with an older man. [ Disco Stu ] Disco Stu, real name Stuart Discotheque { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Homer Scissorhands &quot; } (voiced by Hank Azaria ) is a man who is mentally stuck in the disco era. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Two Bad Neighbors &quot; } He is normally featured wearing a rhinestone-encrusted leisure suit. Stu was introduced as the punchline to a joke in &quot; Two Bad Neighbors &quot;. In a garage sale, Homer attempts to sell a jacket on which he had once tried to write &quot; Disco Stud &quot; in rhinestone s, but having made the letters too big he did not have room for the final &quot; d &quot;. After Marge remarks that nobody would ever want to buy a jacket that read &quot; Disco Stu &quot;, another customer recommends it to Stu, but Stu replies, &quot; Disco Stu doesn&apos;t advertise. &quot; Stu&apos;s speech pattern is similar to that of Duffman, also voiced by Hank Azaria; he speaks in the third person, often referring to himself as &quot; Disco Stu &quot; (emphasizing &quot; Stu &quot; and then pausing before saying anything else; whatever follows usually rhymes with &quot; Stu &quot; ). According to &quot; How I Spent My Strummer Vacation &quot;, Stu actually is aware disco is dead, does not like disco music at all, and worries that his personality may make him a &quot; one-note guy &quot;. He is a Roman Catholic, having gotten an annulment from Pope John Paul II after a brief marriage to Selma Bouvier. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { How I Spent My Strummer Vacation &quot; } { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { How I Wet Your Mother &quot; } In the March 11th, 2012 episode &quot; How I Wet Your Mother &quot;, Professor Frink created a device that allowed people to enter the dreams of others. Stu was originally to be voiced by repeat guest star Phil Hartman. [ Goldman, Eric; Iverson, Dan and Brian Zoromski Top 25 SimpsonsPeripheral Characters 2006-10-06 http://tv.ign.com/articles/730/730957p1.html 2008-05-26 IGN ] [ Doctor Colossus ] Doctor Colossus, voiced by Hank Azaria, is a supervillain and a mad scientist, who resides in Springfield. [ Dolph Starbeam ] Dolphin &quot; Dolph &quot; Starbeam, voiced by Tress MacNeille, is a bully and student at Springfield Elementary School. Dolph is recognized by his asymmetrical haircut which covers one eye and wears cutoff shorts and basketball shoes. He is left-handed and does not talk as much as the other bullies. He usually comes across as very intelligent and speaks a variety of languages including Esperanto, Swahili, and Klingon. It turns out Dolph is Jewish and attends Hebrew school. Despite the fact that he appears to be wholly Caucasian, in the episode &quot; Little Big Girl &quot; he shows up to multicultural day with a disked lower lip, suggesting some African or South American descent. He lied to his friends about not having a bar mitzvah, later claiming it had been &quot; just family &quot;. He has also mentioned the fact that he has two fathers. Dolph was named after one of Matt Groening&apos;s classmates from Lincoln High School named Dolph Timmerman. Groening stated that Timmerman was not a bully but just a real cool guy. [ Drederick Tatum ] Drederick Tatum (voiced by Hank Azaria ) has appeared in several episodes. He is a professional boxer and the reigning World Heavyweight Champion. He features prominently in the episode &quot; The Homer They Fall &quot;, in which Homer takes up boxing and is lined up as an opponent for Tatum, soon to be released from prison. The fight proves one-sided, and Homer is rescued by Moe just as he is about to be knocked out by Tatum. Tatum grew up in Springfield, but in &quot; Flaming Moe&apos;s &quot; he calls the city &quot; a dump &quot; and says &quot; if you ever see me back there, you know I really fu*#ed up bad! &quot; A former 1984 Olympic Gold medalist, he first became champion after defeating Watson in the heavily promoted &quot; Bout to Knock the Other Guy Out! &quot;, a fight Homer and his friends watched on his illegal cable hookup. He was so feared inside prison he could stop riots just by telling the rioters to shut up. Tatum also appears in &quot; Bye Bye Nerdie &quot;. Lisa tests her nerd spray on him, which forces Nelson Muntz to involuntarily get up and start punching Tatum, to little effect. A sobbing Nelson tries to apologise but Tatum rolls up his sleeves and declares &quot; you leave me little recourse! &quot; Tatum is a parody of Mike Tyson, with a high-pitched lisping voice, a menacing demeanor, a criminal record, financial problems and a tendency to make pseudo-intellectual comments like &quot; I insist that you desist &quot; and &quot; your behavior is unconscionable &quot;. He also has an unscrupulous manager named Lucius Sweet, who closely resembles Tyson&apos;s promoter/manager Don King. Indeed, in &quot; The Homer They Fall &quot; Homer notes that Sweet &quot; is as rich and famous as Don King, and looks just like him &quot;. King and Tyson were asked to appear in the episode but declined. Paul Winfield, who played King in a 1995 Tyson biopic, took the role instead. [ Duffman ] Duffman, voiced by Hank Azaria, is a recurring character, who according to Turner, &quot; embodies all the self-importance and over-statement of contemporary marketing. &quot; [ Turner 2004 172 ] He is the mascot for the fictional Duff Corporation that sells Duff beer, [ Cochran Jennifer D. &quot; Mmmm... Duffman is a muscular actor, dressed in a superhero costume who spouts slogans while he thrusts his hips. Commentary for &quot; } { Bart vs. Thanksgiving &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Second Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } [ Elizabeth Hoover ] Elizabeth Hoover is a second grade teacher at Springfield Elementary, voiced by Maggie Roswell and Marcia Mitzman Gaven while Roswell was involved in a pay dispute. Miss Hoover has been worn down by her years in the public school system, and in Lisa Gets an &quot; A &quot; implies that she frequently drinks during lunch. In the episode Lisa&apos;s Substitute, she thought she had lyme disease. She is very apathetic and bored with her job, and seems overwhelmed with stress, seeking whatever remedies she can to alleviate it. She is often seen smoking even while teaching, once even under a &quot; No Smoking &quot; sign in the assembly hall. Her desperate attempts to regain her stability include rushing out of class to recite &quot; Calm blue ocean, calm blue ocean &quot; with her eyes closed, getting into her car and driving off on two occasions, and even letting Ralph teach the class when she was granted tenure. When the series began Miss Hoover&apos;s hair was pale blue, but from Season 4 onwards, she has had brown hair, presumably because of stress. [ March 2012 ] [ Fallout Boy ] In the series, Fallout Boy first appears in a 1950s Radioactive Man serial film shown at a comic book convention in the episode &quot; Three Men and a Comic Book. &quot; However, unlike many Simpsons characters, he has only made a handful of appearances since. While Radioactive Man is a broad parody of many superheroes, most obviously containing elements of Batman and Superman (and the comic incorporates an origin story similar to Marvel &apos;s Hulk ), among others, Fallout Boy is mainly a parody of Robin (with his costume, references as being the &apos;young ward&apos; of Radioactive Man, and his younger age and sidekick status) with elements of Spider-Man (his fictional comic book origin, for example). His catchphrase is &quot; Jiminy Jillickers! &quot; Additionally, Fallout Boy also appears in a real-life comic book titled Radioactive Man, published by Bongo Comics (a comic created in part by Matt Groening, the creator of The Simpsons). In these comic books, Fallout Boy&apos;s real name is Rod Runtledge, he has a brother named Dodd Runtledge, and they live in Zenith City. Rod is a high school nerd living with his aunt, Aunt June. Fallout Boy was an average book worm, until one day, he was at a Radioactive demonstration, where he met up with Claude Kane. A tall piece of machinery fell towards them. Claude grabbed Rod and jumped over the rail, Claude holding onto the machine. The machine came to life, and as the ray passed through Claude, who became Radioactive Man, it hit Rod. Rod then got a pint sized version of RM&apos;s powers, and became Fallout Boy. In the episode &quot; Radioactive Man &quot;, Milhouse was chosen over Bart to play Fallout Boy in the Radioactive Man movie to be filmed in Springfield. Rock band Fall Out Boy took the name of this character after, when they asked a concert audience what band name they should have, a fan shouted &quot; Fallout Boy! &quot; [ Frankie the Squealer ] Frankie the Squealer is a member of the Mafia and associate of Fat Tony. However, he does not appear to be very useful to his colleagues in criminal activity due to his uncontrollable habit of squealing (he claims that &quot; it makes [him] feel big &quot; ), even squealing on himself one time. On several occasions, the mob has attempted to kill him for his squealing, though they have repeatedly been unsuccessful. Frankie first appeared in episode &quot; Insane Clown Poppy &quot; where his squealing habits are introduced after he squeals on himself for squealing. [ Gil Gunderson ] Gil Gunderson, a.k.a. [ http://www.wga.org/subpage_newsevents.aspx?id%3D2764 2008 Writers Guild Awards Winners Announced -- 2008-02-09 WGAW ] [ Gloria ] Gloria, voiced by Julia Louis-Dreyfus is Snake &apos;s girlfriend. She is a meter maid. She first appears in &quot; A Hunka Hunka Burns in Love &quot;, dating Mr. Burns. [ God ] God, voiced by Harry Shearer, has had many appearances in the series, including &quot; Homer the Heretic &quot;, &quot; Thank God, It&apos;s Doomsday &quot;, and a scene with Him, Buddha, and Colonel Sanders in &quot; Pray Anything &quot;, as well as appearing in the flick across the town in the opening sequence (in the HD episodes) where he is fighting with the devil. He is portrayed in the traditional depiction of the Abrahamic God : a gray-haired man in a white robe with a booming voice. In most episodes, only his beard is seen as the camera only films him up to the shoulders. His body is usually surrounded by a glowing light, and his robes float around him, though not always. He does not seem to be all-knowing. Another notable characteristic of him is his ability to forgive and tolerate Homer&apos;s mishaps, despite his later often heretical attitude. He is on good and even friendly terms with Homer, but he would not hesitate to severely punish him if Homer become too obnoxious. One of God&apos;s distinctive features is that he and Jesus are the only two Simpsons characters to be drawn with five fingers on each hand and five toes on each foot, though not always. [ Grady and Julio ] Grady, voiced by Scott Thompson and Julio, voiced by Hank Azaria are two gay men who become Homer&apos;s roommates when he leaves Marge in &quot; Three Gays of the Condo &quot;. Julio reappears in &quot; There&apos;s Something About Marrying &quot;, marrying another man, in &quot; I Don&apos;t Wanna Know Why the Caged Bird Sings &quot; as one of the bank robbery hostages, and has speaking cameos in &quot; Eternal Moonshine of the Simpson Mind &quot; and &quot; E Pluribus Wiggum &quot;. He appeared in the episode &quot; Four Great Women and a Manicure &quot;, in which he was seen as &quot; King Julio &quot; in Lisa&apos;s first story, &quot; Elizabeth the First &quot;. He works as a photographer, as seen in &quot; The Devil Wears Nada &quot;. Grady made his second appearance to date in &quot; Homer and Lisa Exchange Cross Words &quot;, in which he persuades Homer to break up his (Grady&apos;s) relationship with Julio, so that he could pursue a relationship with Duffman. Julio made further appearances as Marge&apos;s Hairdresser in &quot; The Blue and the Gray &quot; and &quot; Homer Scissorhands &quot;. [ Gunter and Ernst ] Gunter and Ernst, Las Vegas-style entertainers voiced by Harry Shearer and Hank Azaria, are obvious parodies of Siegfried &amp; Roy : they speak with German accents, their act involves magic and white tiger s, and one has black hair while the other has bleached-blond hair. The duo appear in the episodes &quot; Viva Ned Flanders &quot;, &quot; $pringfield &quot;, &quot; The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons &quot;, and &quot; Jazzy and the Pussycats &quot;. In &quot; Jazzy and the Pussycats &quot;, they are seen at Amber Simpson&apos;s funeral. In &quot; The Simpsons Game &quot; it is revealed they performed at an aquarium. In a case of life imitating art, the 1993 episode &quot; $pringfield &quot; (the first episode featuring Gunter and Ernst) depicts the duo being savagely mauled by their trademark white tiger, Anastasia. Ten years later, the trained white tiger Montecore dragged Roy Horn off-stage by his neck during a performance at The Mirage. According to the DVD commentary on this episode on the Simpsons season five DVD set, the part where Gunter and Ernst get attacked is considered &quot; the greatest prediction &quot; the Simpsons ever made, but it was &quot; bound to happen &quot; considering how the tiger was treated. [ The Happy Little Elves ] The Happy Little Elves are a parody of The Smurfs, who appeared more often in the show&apos;s earlier episodes. They are a favorite of Lisa and Maggie Simpson. Bart, however, hates them; he mainly refers to them as either &quot; those stupid elves &quot; &quot; The Crappy Little Elves &quot;, or &quot; The Little Green Idiots &quot;. Their movies include Return of the Happy Little Elves, an unnamed Christmas movie as seen in &quot; Simpsons Roasting on an Open Fire &quot;, The Happy Little Elves Meet The Curious Bear Cubs, The Happy Little Elves in Tinkly Winkly Town, and The Happy Little Elves meet Fuzzy Snuggleduck (which was listed as an R-rated movie along with Thelma &amp; Louise and The Erotic Awakening of S on Rancho Relaxo&apos;s cable system). They were first mentioned in a short on The Tracey Ullman Show entitled &quot; Scary Movie &quot;. The most recent appearance they had was in &quot; Lisa Simpson, This Isn&apos;t Your Life &quot; in November 2010. In more current episodes, they appear as wall decorations in Maggie&apos;s and Lisa&apos;s rooms. [ Helen Lovejoy ] Helen Lovejoy (née Schwartzbaum), voiced by Maggie Roswell and Marcia Mitzman Gaven, is Rev. Lovejoy ’s judgmental and gossip y wife, and the mother of Jessica Lovejoy. She introduced herself in the episode &quot; Life on the Fast Lane &quot; as &quot; the gossipy wife of the minister. &quot; Her catchphrase is &quot; What about the children?! Won&apos;t somebody &apos;&apos;please&apos;&apos; think of the children !? &quot; which she always says among a crowd when something bad is happening in the city. In &quot; Wedding for Disaster &quot;, the Parson remarks to Reverend Lovejoy that he remembers when Helen Lovejoy was Helen Schwartzbaum and prior to that, Harold Schwartzbaum, before deciding he has said too much, implying that Helen was not always a woman, however this is directly contradicted as in flashbacks she is shown to be a girl as a child, and the fact that she and Reverend Lovejoy have a biological daughter in Jessica. In E Pluribus Wiggum, it was revealed that Helen is a member of the Springfield Republican Caucus while in one of their dungeon meetings. In the Treehouse of Horror XX, she is revealed to be Lisa&apos;s Godmother. [ Herman ] Herman Larson, voiced by Harry Shearer, is the owner of Herman&apos;s Military Antiques. He is a right-arm above-elbow amputee; he tells Bart that the arm was lost when he stuck it out the window of a moving bus as a kid. A brilliant military tactician, Herman was instrumental in Bart’s victory in water balloon combat against Nelson and in the negotiation of the peace treaty between the two combatants in &quot; Bart the General &quot;, which is his most significant and first appearance. He is friends with Abraham Simpson, to whom he sold a fez, claiming it was previously owned by Napoleon; Herman then advertised Abe&apos;s old hat as &quot; the hat McKinley was shot in &quot;. He also tried to sell counterfeit jeans out of the Simpsons&apos; garage, but was foiled by Marge Simpson. He once captured Chief Wiggum and Snake and held them hostage, but was accidentally knocked out by Milhouse with a medieval mace, rescuing them. Harry Shearer does an impression of George H.W. Bush for the voice. { Groening, Matt (2001). Commentary for &quot; } { Bart the General &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete First Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } Herman&apos;s facial appearance is modeled after Simpsons writer John Swartzwelder. The original idea behind Herman, said Groening, was that each time he appeared, he would give a different explanation for how he lost his arm. However, the second joke, involving Herman having stuck his arm in a ball return at a bowling alley, got cut, and the writers never pursued the idea. { Groening, Matt (2006). Commentary for &quot; } { Treehouse of Horror VIII &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Ninth Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } [ Janey Powell ] Janey Powell, voiced by Pamela Hayden, is a classmate and friend of Lisa Simpson. Janey first appeared in &quot; Bart the General &quot; and was once Lisa&apos;s closest friend. She has been at Lisa&apos;s sleepover s, and Lisa is seen watching cartoons at her house on numerous occasions. Her description on The Simpsons POG set described her as &quot; Lisa&apos;s fair-weather friend &quot;. Though she is sometimes seen spending time with Lisa, other times she teases her along with the other children. She is not portrayed as being nearly as intelligent or nerdy as Lisa. Janey may have had a crush on Milhouse Van Houten, who has a crush on Lisa. She enjoys reading babysitting books. [ Jasper Beardly ] Jasper Beardly, voiced by Harry Shearer is one of the elder residents of Springfield, often portrayed as Abraham Simpson &apos;s best friend. His most distinguishing features are his ultra-low, gravelly voice and very long beard. Jasper made his first appearance in &quot; Homer&apos;s Odyssey &quot;. He is a veteran of World War II, but (according to the episode &quot; Marge and Homer Turn a Couple Play &quot; ) he attempted to avoid the draft by disguising himself as a woman. He stayed in Springfield to play in the local women&apos;s baseball league, along with his friend Abe, who was also avoiding the war but was exposed during a game. In a deleted scene, it was shown that Jasper was the town pastor, prior to Reverend Lovejoy. He briefly served as substitute teacher of Lisa&apos;s class during which time he confiscated everything made of tin, got his beard caught in a pencil sharpener and threatened paddling for minor infractions such as looking out the window or talking out of turn. In the subplot of the season nine episode, &quot; Lisa the Simpson &quot;, Jasper put himself in crude &quot; suspended animation &quot; in the Kwik-E-Mart &apos;s freezer, and under advice from Dr. Nick Riviera, Apu kept him frozen. When Jasper&apos;s frozen form became popular with customers, Apu started exploiting the spectacle, and transformed the Kwik-E-Mart into a special interest store dealing with weird items, or perfectly ordinary ones which had been made out to be abnormal, called the Freak-E-Mart. Jasper was accidentally unfrozen, and stepped out into what he thought was a future world, just as Apu was considering selling him to the Rich Texan. In the episode &quot; I Don&apos;t Wanna Know Why the Caged Bird Sings &quot; Jasper mentions he is a diabetic. [ Jebediah Springfield ] Jebediah Obadiah Zachariah Jedediah Springfield (a.k.a. Hans Sprungfeld) is the founder of the town of Springfield. He is voiced by Harry Shearer. According to legend, Jebediah Springfield and his partner Shelbyville Manhattan, led a band that left Maryland in search of &quot; New Sodom &quot; due to a misinterpretation of the Bible, but they parted ways over political differences: though both men are devoted to chastity and abstinence, Manhattan wanted to let people be free to marry their cousins if they wish, to which Springfield strongly opposes. It was then Manhattan went on to found the rival town of Shelbyville, taking half of the settlers with him. Springfield had many famous quotations, such as &quot; A noble spirit embiggens the smallest man &quot;. He also wears a coonskin cap. The Springfield Marathon commemorates an occasion on which he ran across six states in order to avoid his creditors. In &quot; The Telltale Head &quot; Bart beheaded the statue, thinking that this would make him more popular. In reality, the town became depressed and angry, leaving Bart to endure &quot; The Tell-Tale Heart &quot; -style guilt before replacing it. This episode is referenced in multiple Simpsons video games such as The Simpsons: Bart vs. the Space Mutants, where the statue&apos;s head serves as a power-up item, or The Simpsons Road Rage and The Simpsons Hit &amp; Run, where characters can kick or ram Jebediah&apos;s head off the statue. Many Jebediah legends have been debunked during the run of the series. For instance, &quot; The Telltale Head &quot; repeatedly refers to Jebediah killing a bear with his bare hands, but on the news, Kent Brockman reveals that recent historical evidence suggests the bear actually killed Jebediah. On an expedition to Springfield&apos;s historic &quot; Fort Springfield &quot;, Bart uncovers other inconsistencies in the Jebediah legend, such as that he fought at Fort Ticonderoga the same day as the first Whacking Day. Most of Springfield&apos;s biography is revealed in the 1996 episode &quot; Lisa the Iconoclast &quot;, wherein Lisa Simpson discovers Jebediah Springfield&apos;s biggest secret: he was formerly a bloodthirsty pirate named Hans Sprungfeld, who once brawled with George Washington and lost after Washington crushed Sprungfeld&apos;s genitals in one of his sets of iron false teeth. Sprungfeld fled and changed his name in 1795 to hide his identity. He was well known for his &quot; silver tongue &quot; (literally; a metal prosthetic tongue, his original tongue having been bitten off by a Turkish pirate in a grog house fight). Before he died of diphtheria, he wrote his confession on a scrap of canvas that he hid in a fife. The canvas scrap formed the &quot; missing piece &quot; of the famously incomplete 1796 Gilbert Stuart portrait of George Washington; Sprungfeld picked it up during a fight against Washington which occurred while the latter was having his portrait painted. Lisa decides not to reveal this secret to the people of Springfield, seeing that the myth of Jebediah has brought out the good in everyone and that the true story will cause them to lose hope and morale within themselves. The Australian rock-band &quot; Jebediah &quot; was named after Jebediah Springfield. [ Jimbo Jones ] Corky James &quot; Jimbo &quot; Jones, voiced by Pamela Hayden and originally by Tress MacNeille in his first appearance in the first season episode &quot; The Telltale Head &quot; is a lowlife who wears a purple knit cap and a black T-shirt emblazoned with a menacing skull. He can often be seen hanging around Kearney, Dolph, and sometimes Nelson. He is generally acknowledged as the leader of this clique. He enjoys intimidating his schoolmates and shoplifting. It is hinted that he comes from a well-off family, most notably in season six&apos;s &quot; The PTA Disbands &quot; when  — with the school closed for a teacher&apos;s strike - he and his mother watch soap opera s and sip tea together in a very nice living room. In season seven&apos;s Bart the Fink, Bart discovers that Jimbo&apos;s real name is Corky. Jimbo&apos;s other known aliases are Jamesbo, Dr. J and Hector Gutierrez. Jimbo is named for executive producer James L. Brooks. { Jean, Al (2001). Commentary for &quot; } { The Telltale Head &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete First Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } Jimbo runs for mayor in the Season 17 episode &quot; See Homer Run &quot;, with a campaign slogan of &quot; Tough on Nerds. Tougher on Dorks. &quot; [ Johnny Tightlips ] Johnny &quot; John &quot; Tightlips, voiced by Hank Azaria, is a member of the Mafia and associate of Fat Tony. He says very little, which spares him from accusations of being a &quot; squealer &quot;, but his reticence tends to be unhelpful to others and even himself. In &quot; The Twisted World of Marge Simpson &quot; he tries to help Fat Tony in taking away Marge&apos;s earnings from her &apos;Pretzel Wagon&apos; franchise. In &quot; Insane Clown Poppy &quot;, there is a shoot-out in Fat Tony&apos;s mansion and Tightlips is shot by accident. When asked where he&apos;s injured, he says &quot; I ain&apos;t sayin&apos; nuthin&apos;! &quot;, and when asked what to tell the doctor he says, &quot; Tell him to suck a lemon. &quot; [ http://www.snpp.com/episodes/BABF17 Insane Clown Poppy The Simpsons Archive 2008-04-12 ] [ Jub-Jub ] Jub-Jub is Selma Bouvier &apos;s pet iguana and was originally owned by Aunt Gladys. It was first seen in &quot; Selma&apos;s Choice &quot;. Gladys gives Jub-Jub to Jacqueline Bouvier, who is highly unattached to it. As a result, she later passes it on to Selma. Selma once said that Jub-Jub will eat her remains upon her death. The name Jub-Jub was coined by then-writer Conan O&apos;Brien. [ Stern, David 2004 The Simpsons The Complete Fourth Season DVD commentary for the episode &quot; Selma&apos;s Choice &quot; DVD 20th Century Fox ] He often said nonsensical things around the office for no apparent reason, one of which was &quot; Jub-Jub &quot;. (There is, however, a Jubjub bird in The Hunting of the Snark.) Fans of Sportsradio 1310 in Dallas voted that Jub-Jub be the new nickname of morning radio host George Dunham. O&apos;Brien, on October 17, 2007, mentioned his creation of Jub Jub and asked Joe Buck, the play-by-play commentator of the MLB World Series on FOX, to say it during his broadcast. O&apos;Brien promised $1,000.00 to the charity of the announcer&apos;s choice. On October 24, 2007, during Game 1 of the 2007 World Series, Buck called field level reporter, Chris Myers, &quot; our own little Jub-Jub. &quot; Jub-Jub was used as the first Twitter hash tag for O&apos;Brien&apos;s &quot; Legally Prohibited from Being Funny on Television Tour &quot; in 2010. [ Judge Constance Harm ] Judge Constance Harm, voiced by repeat guest star actress Jane Kaczmarek, is a harsh, unforgiving disciplinarian. { The Simpsons &quot; } { The Parent Rap &quot; - November 4, 2001 } She enjoys creating cruel punishments for criminals in her court and frightening them with a miniature guillotine on the bench. She might be a transsexual based on a statement she makes during her first appearance in &quot; The Parent Rap &quot; : &quot; you remind me of me, when I was a little boy &quot;. Her name is a play on &quot; constant harm &quot;. The character is a parody of Judge Judy. In &quot; On a Clear Day I Can&apos;t See My Sister &quot;, she reveals she has a husband. Although Judge Snyder resolves court cases, Judge Harm has mainly been used for handing down negative verdicts, such as sentencing a family member to prison. She also appears in &quot; Brawl in the Family &quot;, &quot; Barting Over &quot;, &quot; The Wandering Juvie &quot;, &quot; Brake My Wife, Please &quot; and &quot; Chief of Hearts &quot;. { The Simpsons &quot; } { Brake My Wife, Please &quot; - May 11, 2003 } [ Judge Snyder ] Judge Roy Snyder, voiced by Harry Shearer, { Gimple, p. 87 } is a Springfield judge known for his lenient punishments and somewhat unorthodox rulings (as in the episode &quot; Sweets and Sour Marge, &quot; when he bans sugar from Springfield). The character was originally named &quot; Judge Moulton &quot;, but show runners Bill Oakley and Josh Weinstein did not know that, and called him &quot; Snyder &quot;. { Oakley, Bill; Weinstein, Josh (2005). Commentary for &quot; } { The Day the Violence Died &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Seventh Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } His appearance is modeled on Robert Bork. Ned Flanders says he is &quot; right as rain, or, as we say around here, &apos;left as rain&apos; but the man bluntly responds &quot; Just stamp the ticket. &quot; His next appearances is in &quot; Homer Alone &quot;, when the Squeaky Voiced Teen tries to hand him a flyer he brushes him off by saying &quot; Don&apos;t touch me &quot;. [ Dr. J. Loren Pryor ] Dr. J. Loren Pryor, voiced by Harry Shearer, is the school psychologist. He is based on an early design for Seymour Skinner, and first appears in &quot; Bart the Genius &quot; where he decides to send Bart to a school for gifted children after Bart cheats on a test. Bart later approaches him to request returning to Springfield Elementary. In &quot; Bart Gets an F &quot;, he tells Bart that he may have to repeat the fourth grade. He appears again, discussing Bart&apos;s problems at school and Lisa&apos;s special gift in a flashback sequence of &quot; Lisa&apos;s Sax &quot;. In this episode he also inadvertently reveals that Milhouse Van Houten possesses &quot; flamboyantly homosexual &quot; tendencies. Pryor does not appear again for several years until the episode &quot; See Homer Run &quot;, in which he tells Lisa that she is going through a developmental condition. [ Kearney Zzyzwicz ] Kearney Zzyzwicz, voiced by Nancy Cartwright, is one of Springfield Elementary&apos;s many bullies. He has a buzz cut, and wears a torn white T-shirt, blue shorts, and studded wristbands. Although he looks and sounds to be around Jimbo or Dolph &apos;s age, Kearney is actually older. He is the only Springfield Elementary School student who remembers the Watergate Scandal and the 1976 Bicenntenial (according to Principal Skinner), was in Otto the bus driver&apos;s third-grade class (according to Otto), owns a car (even though he rode the school bus on &quot; A Milhouse Divided &quot;, &quot; The Mook, the Chef, the Wife, and Her Homer &quot;, and &quot; How the Test Was Won &quot; ), regularly shaves, has custody of a child from a divorce, is old enough to vote in a general U.S. election, was sent to prison, and pays taxes. In &quot; She of Little Faith &quot;, Kearney dated Jimbo&apos;s mother. In the same episode, it is revealed that he is on the church council of the First Church of Springfield and is &quot; a teenager and the parent of a teenager &quot;. [ She of Little Faith She of Little Faith The Simpsons The Simpsons 2001-12-16 13 6 ] Kearney often relies on (or tricks) Homer into procuring alcohol for himself and his friends (as seen in &quot; The Springfield Connection &quot;, &quot; Simpsoncalifragilisticexpiala(Annoyed Grunt)cious &quot;, and &quot; Last Tap Dance in Springfield &quot; ), and once used a fake ID (as seen in &quot; Much Apu About Nothing &quot; ), though it is heavily implied that Kearney is of the legal age to buy alcohol for himself (as in &quot; El Viaje Misterioso de Nuestro Jomer &quot;, in which he is seen drinking at Moe&apos;s Tavern ). Kearney&apos;s last name (Zzyzwicz) was revealed in a computer file in season 18&apos;s &quot; 24 Minutes &quot;. Prior to that episode, Kearney&apos;s surname was never mentioned. In &quot; Bart Gets a &apos;Z&apos; &quot;, Kearney can be seen sitting in the back row of Bart&apos;s classroom, implying that Kearney is a fourth grader. Kearney&apos;s father was shown on the season eight episode &quot; The Homer They Fall &quot;, but in &quot; O Brother, Where Bart Thou? &quot;, Kearney reveals that both of his parents are incarcerated and they only meet when the prison and insane asylum have their annual mixer. [ Kirk Van Houten ] Kirk Van Houten is voiced by Hank Azaria. He is the father of Milhouse, and the remarried husband of Luann Van Houten. He wears glasses just like his son and wife. He first appeared in &quot; Bart&apos;s Friend Falls in Love &quot;. Kirk has been portrayed as a stereotypical middle-aged male loser and deadbeat dad. Much of his character revolves around his extreme emotional depression after his divorce from his wife Luann. Luann got custody of Milhouse when they divorced, but Kirk has visiting rights and is often seen with Milhouse in later episodes. Kirk suffers from the need to cry all the time after his divorce, even in good times. The Van Houtens remarried in the nineteenth season episode &quot; Little Orphan Millie &quot;. In that episode it was established that Kirk is of Dutch and Danish ancestry. Kirk previously served in the U.S. Army, and attended Gudger College. Apparently Kirk&apos;s mother is of Greek ancestry, based on the nineteenth season episode &quot; Husbands and Knives &quot;. In the episode, Milhouse says, &quot; But that&apos;s the money Yaya Sophia gave me for Greek Orthodox Easter! &quot;. According to Luann, Kirk was not a very good provider, and she had to borrow money from her sister to make ends meet. When Luann demands a divorce, Kirk is all too happy to oblige. Unfortunately, he loses his middle-management job at Southern Cracker, a job given to him by Luann&apos;s father, as a result. Kirk briefly attempts a career as a singer-songwriter, recording a demo tape of an original song titled &quot; Can I Borrow A Feeling &quot;, with mediocre results. Later, he attempts to win Luann back by singing the song to her. Luann does not reciprocate Kirk&apos;s feelings, choosing instead to remain with her boyfriend. Kirk reveals in the episode &quot; I Am Furious Yellow &quot;, where he visits his son&apos;s school on career day, that he was currently employed as an assistant to the guy who puts fliers under people&apos;s windshield wipers. Kirk also had a job standing on the curb holding a sign directing people to a condo development and worked as a scarecrow protecting a soy-bean crop, which resulted in his eye being gouged by a crow. Since being fired from the cracker company, Kirk seems to be unable to maintain a steady job. He once shouted at Luann that she had to keep up the alimony payments she owed him, and he has been seen at the Springfield unemployment office, perhaps suggesting that alimony and unemployment benefits are his only steady sources of income. Kirk was put in jail in the episode &quot; Pranksta Rap &quot; for &quot; kidnapping &quot; Bart which he greatly enjoyed due to him being envied by women and fed three meals a day. In The Simpsons Movie, Kirk is briefly seen attending an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting. [ Laura Powers ] Laura Powers, voiced by Sara Gilbert is the teenage daughter of Ruth Powers. Her first and only appearance is in the episode &quot; New Kid on the Block &quot; when she and Ruth move in next door to the Simpsons. When Marge and Homer ask her to babysit Bart, Lisa and Maggie, Bart immediately develops a crush on her. However he is shocked to find out that she is dating local bully Jimbo Jones whom she later breaks up with after Moe threatens to kill Jimbo over a prank call that Bart made. Ruth mentions Laura in &quot; Marge On The Lam &quot; when Ruth tells Marge that she has to head home before her daughter watches &quot; that naked talk show. &quot; [ Legs and Louie ] Legs, voiced by Karl Wiedergott (formerly voiced by Hank Azaria ), and Louie, voiced by Dan Castellaneta, are the two Springfield Mafia hitmen who accompany Fat Tony at all times. The two lack any real definitive characteristic and are almost always seen together. Legs has a dark blonde short haircut and raspy voice. Louie has a slight black afro and a more high-pitched, even squeaky tone. Castellaneta based the voice on actor Joe Pesci, one of the several references to Goodfellas used in the episode &quot; Bart the Murderer &quot;. { Castellaneta, Dan (2009). Commentary for &quot; } { Insane Clown Poppy &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Twelfth Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } Louie says that tear gas is &quot; [his] one weakness, &quot; though this is likely an embellishment. Dan Castellaneta was nominated for Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Voice-Over Performance in 2011 for the voice of Louie, Homer Simpson, Barney Gumble, and Krusty the Clown thanks to the episode Donnie Fatso. [ http://www.emmys.com/nominations/2011/Outstanding%20Voice-Over%20Performance Primetime Emmy Awards nominations for 2011 - Outstanding Voice-Over Performance Emmys.com 2011-10-23 ] [ Leopold ] Leopold, voiced by Dan Castellaneta, is Superintendent Chalmers&apos; assistant. He is a large, surly, snarling man who frequently speaks through clenched teeth, and is one of the few characters on The Simpsons to have eyebrow s. When Principal Skinner has to be temporarily replaced, Leopold stomps in, issues several threats, and terrifies the children by making them think he is the replacement, and then suddenly politely introduces the actual substitute, Ned Flanders. The children then collectively sigh with relief. The gag was repeated when Marge Simpson becomes a substitute teacher in the episode &quot; The PTA Disbands &quot;. Leopold often refers to the children of Springfield Elementary as &quot; little freaks. &quot; [ http://www.snpp.com/episodes/1F18.html [1F18] Sweet Seymour Skinner&apos;s Baadasssss Song 2008-03-01 Cherry James A. 1996-07-21 Episode transcript The Simpsons Archive (snpp.com) ] [ http://www.snpp.com/episodes/2F19.html [2F19] The PTA Disbands 2008-03-01 Cherry James A. 1997-02-22 Episode transcript The Simpsons Archive (snpp.com) ] [ Lewis ] Lewis Jackson is an African American character, and student at Springfield Elementary School in Bart&apos;s class. He can be seen playing the bassoon in the opening sequence of the show. Although one of the most minor characters in the show, Lewis appears frequently in scenes involving the Springfield children, and occasionally speaks. He is usually seen with Richard. While Lewis has never had significant dialogue, he has been voiced by Nancy Cartwright, Jo Ann Harris, Pamela Hayden, Tress MacNeille, and Russi Taylor throughout the series. Lewis&apos;s seeming insignificance to the show is underscored in the episode &quot; Das Bus &quot;, in which Bart mistakenly calls him &quot; Wendell &quot;. [ Lindsey Naegle ] Lindsey Naegle is voiced by Tress MacNeille and first appeared in the eighth season episode &quot; The Itchy &amp; Scratchy &amp; Poochie Show &quot;. { McCann, p. 88 } In that episode, she had no name and was known only as &quot; The Generic Female TV Executive &quot;. She appeared again in &quot; Girly Edition &quot;, also as a generic female TV executive (only her hair and facial features differed from her first appearance). { Gimple, p. 37 } In &quot; They Saved Lisa&apos;s Brain &quot;, she was introduced as &quot; Lindsey Naegle &quot;, a member of the Springfield Chapter of Mensa, and has since become a recurring character. The writers modeled Naegle on a number of network executives that they have encountered while working on the show. { Weinstein, Josh (2006). Commentary for &quot; } { The Itchy &amp; Scratchy &amp; Poochie Show &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Eighth Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } The character gets her last name from Hollywood talent agent Sue Naegle, president of HBO Entertainment and wife of Simpsons writer Dana Gould. { Selman, Matt (2007). Commentary for &quot; } { They Saved Lisa&apos;s Brain &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Tenth Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } [ http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news.aspx?id%3D20080409hbo01 Breaking News  — Sue Naegle Joins HBO as President, HBO Entertainment, Overseeing All Series Programming and Specials Thefutoncritic.com 2009-01-02 ] Writer Matt Selman chose the first name &quot; Lindsey &quot; because he thought it sounded like the name of an annoyingly talkative woman. Naegle prototypes have appeared throughout the series, such as the OmniTouch Rep from &quot; Make Room for Lisa &quot; and Laramie executive Mindy from &quot; E-I-E-I-(Annoyed Grunt) &quot;. { Turner, p. 167 } In &quot; Blame It on Lisa &quot;, it is revealed that she frequently changes jobs because she is a sexual predator. Chris Turner, author of the book Planet Simpson, called Naegle &quot; an excellent allegory for the modern corporate age: you don&apos;t see through her because there&apos;s nothing else to see. &quot; { Turner, p. 168 } Her political allegiances are not concrete: In &quot; You Kent Always Say What You Want, &quot; she is shown at the Republican Party headquarters; in &quot; E Pluribus Wiggum, &quot; Naegle is conversely depicted as a Democrat. [ Lois Pennycandy ] Lois Pennycandy is the beautiful executive assistant to Krusty the Clown. { &quot; } { Like Father, Like Clown &quot; } She swayed Krusty into visiting Bart after he saved Krusty from jail time, { &quot; } { Krusty Gets Busted &quot; } and later reunited him with his estranged father the Rabbi Hyman Krustofski. She was at Krusty&apos;s side during the auditions in which Robert Terwilliger became Krusty&apos;s new sidekick, { &quot; } { Brother from Another Series &quot; } and was at Krusty&apos;s &quot; funeral &quot; when he was presumed dead after crashing his private plane into a cliff. { &quot; } { Bart the Fink &quot; } In a phone conversation, Marge once asked her, &quot; How can [Krusty] hurt someone who loves him so? &quot; While looking at a framed photo of Krusty, Pennycandy replied, &quot; Oh, Mrs. Simpson, I&apos;ve wasted my womanhood asking that same question. &quot; Her only speaking roles are in &quot; Like Father, Like Clown &quot; and &quot; Krusty Gets Kancelled &quot;, in which she was voiced by Pamela Hayden. [ Luann Van Houten ] Luann Van Houten is voiced by Maggie Roswell. When Roswell left the show in 1998, she became a primarily nonspeaking character. However, Roswell returned in 2002. Since the season 8 episode, &quot; A Milhouse Divided &quot;, Luann was depicted as a promiscuous, single mother, who stuck her successful love life in the face of her ex-husband, Kirk. She first appeared in &quot; Homer Defined &quot;. She wears glasses, a trait that she shares with her husband and son. Luann Van Houten&apos;s mother is Italian. She was born in Shelbyville, and moved to Springfield in early life. It is stated in &quot; A Milhouse Divided &quot; that she has a sister. Luann was married to Kirk for several years, giving birth to a son, Milhouse, yet the marriage was an unhappy one. After an argument over a game of Pictionary, she leaves Kirk after he remarks he can&apos;t draw &quot; dignity &quot;, since he gave it up when he married her. Although Kirk found the new liberty of a single life tough, Luann uses her newfound freedom to live life on the fast lane. Luann began dating American Gladiator Pyro shortly after her divorce with Kirk for several seasons, but was caught cheating on him with his best friend, Gyro. In Apu Nahasapeemapetilon &apos;s bachelor years, she had been one of his bachelorettes. In &quot; Milhouse of Sand and Fog &quot;, it is revealed that Luann had also gone out with Disco Stu as well and had begun a relationship with Sea Captain. In &quot; Milhouse of Sand and Fog &quot; the Van Houtens reunited. Since then, they are often seen together (although in the episode &quot; Ice Cream of Margie (with the Light Blue Hair) &quot;, Kirk was seen with Milhouse at a single father&apos;s outing, showing he and Luann were still not married). As of &quot; Little Orphan Millie &quot;, they are remarried.She And Kirk Had A Little Appearance In &quot; Moe Goes From Rags To Riches &quot; [ Luigi Risotto ] Luigi Risotto, voiced by Hank Azaria, { Gimple, p. 86 } is the proprietor of Luigi&apos;s, a Springfield Italian restaurant.
