[ http://www.insse.ro/cms/files%5Cstatistici%5CStatistica%20teritoriala%202008%5Ceng%5C8.htm POPULATION BY ETHNIC GROUPS AT POPULATION AND HOUSING CENSUS, ON MARCH 18, 2002 Insse.ro 2002-03-18 2011-08-29 ] { Sibiu, showing the city&apos;s name in } { Romanian and } { German } In localities where a given ethnic minority makes up more than 20% of the population, that minority&apos;s language can be used in the public administration and justice system, while native-language education and signage is also provided. Hungarians make up some 19% of the population of Transylvania; there are many towns and communes in parts of Transylvania that have Hungarian as a second official language. Language rights are sensitive in these areas, where Hungarian speakers are campaigning for greater official status, and possible autonomy for the predominantly-Hungarian counties of eastern Transylvania (&apos; Székely Land &apos;). English and French are the main foreign languages taught in schools. English is spoken by 5  million Romanians, French is spoken by 4–5  million, and German, Italian and Spanish are each spoken by 1–2  million people. [ April 2012 ] Historically, French was the predominant foreign language spoken in Romania, but English has since superseded it. Consequently, Romanian English-speakers tend to be younger than Romanian French-speakers. Romania is, however, a full member of La Francophonie, and hosted the Francophonie Summit in 2006. [ http://www.francophonie.org/doc/doc-historique/chronologie-oif.pdf pfd French Chronology of the International Organization La Francophonie 2008-08-31 http://web.archive.org/web/20080624195138/http%3A//www.francophonie.org/doc/doc-historique/chronologie-oif.pdf 24 June 2008 ] German has been taught predominantly in Transylvania, due to traditions tracing back to the Austro-Hungarian rule in this province. The Romanian language remains, according to the Constitution of Romania, the only official language of Romania, but local councils ensure linguistic rights to all minorities, who form over 11% of the total population. Foreign citizens and stateless persons that live in Romania have access to justice and education in their own language. [ http://www.cdep.ro/pls/dic/site.page?den%3Dact2_1%26amp%3Bpar1%3D1 Constitutia României Cdep.ro 2011-08-29 ] [ Religion ] [ Orthodox purple 86.7 ] [ Protestant purple 5.2 ] [ Roman Catholic purple 4.7 ] [ Greek-Catholic purple 0.9 ] [ Muslim purple 0.3 ] [ Religion in Romania Romanian Orthodox Church Romanian Church United with Rome, Greek-Catholic Pentecostal Union of Romania ] Romania is a secular state and has no state religion. However, an overwhelming majority of the country&apos;s citizens identify themselves as Christian s. 86.7% of the country&apos;s population identified as Orthodox Christian according to the 2002 census, the vast majority of which belongs to the Romanian Orthodox Church. Other major Christian denomination s include Protestantism (5.2%), Roman Catholicism (4.7%) and the Romanian Greek-Catholic Church (0.9%). The latter two religious organizations suffered most severely under the Communist regime. The Greek-Catholic Church was outlawed by the Communist government in 1948; { Harper-Collins Encyclopedia of Catholicism, 1132; Niessen, &quot; The Greek Catholic Church and the Romanian Nation, &quot; 59–60 } later, under the Ceaușescu regime, several churches in Transylvania were demolished. Protestants and Roman Catholics are also concentrated in Transylvania. The foundation of the oldest-known Romanian Orthodox church is still visible at Drobeta-Turnu Severin today, and dates from the 14th century; however, much earlier crypts with unearthed relics of Christian martyrs executed at the orders of the Roman emperor Diocletian were found in local church records dating as far back as the 3rd century AD. Thus, the relics of Saint Sava the Goth who was martyred by drowning in the river Buzău in Romania, under Athanaric, on 12 April 372, were reverently received by St. Basil the Great. Earlier still, the first known Daco-Roman Christian priest Montanus and his wife Maxima were drowned because of their Christian faith, as martyrs, on 26 March 304. { Metropolitan Cathedral, Iași, the largest Orthodox church in Romania, founded in 1833 } Romania also has a Muslim minority concentrated in Dobruja, mostly of Turkish and Tatar ethnicity and numbering 67,500 people. [ http://www.recensamant.ro/datepr/tbl6.html Romanian Census Website with population by religion Recensamant.ro 2008-01-01 ] [ August 2011 ] According to the results of the 2002 census, there are 66,846 Romanian citizens of the Unitarian faith (0.3% of the total population). Of the total Hungarian-speaking minority in Romania, Unitarians represent 4.55%, being the third denominational group after members of the Reformed Church in Romania (47.10%) and Roman Catholics (41.20%). Since 1700, the Unitarian Church has had 125 parishes—in 2006, there were 110 Unitarian ministers and 141 places of worship in Romania. [ September 2010 ] According to the 2002 census, there were 6,179 Jews, 23,105 people who are of no religion and/or atheist, and 11,734 who refused to answer. On 27 December 2006, a new Law on Religion was approved under which religious denominations can only receive official registration if they have at least 20,000 members, or about 0.1% of Romania&apos;s total population. [ http://www.bosnewslife.com/europe/romania/2674-romania-president-approves-europes-worst/ Romania President Approves Europe&apos;s &quot; Worst Religion Law &quot; 2008-08-31 ] The Romanian Orthodox Church is an autocephalous Orthodox church. It is in full communion with other Orthodox churches, and is ranked seventh in order of precedence. The Primate of the church has the title of Patriarch. Its jurisdiction covers the territory of Romania, with diocese s for Romanians living in nearby Moldova, Serbia and Hungary, as well as diaspora communities in Central and Western Europe, North America and Oceania. It is the only Orthodox church using a Romance language. The majority of people in Romania (18,817,975, or 86.8% of the population, according to the 2002 census data { 2002 census data on religion } [ August 2011 ] ) belong to it, as well as some 720,000 Moldova ns. { &quot; Biserica Ortodoxă Română, atacată de bisericile &apos;surori&apos; &quot; ( &quot; The Romanian Orthodox Church, Attacked by Its &apos;Sister&apos; Churches &quot;, Ziua, 31 January 2008 } The Romanian Orthodox Church is the second-largest in size after the Russian Orthodox Church. The most significant holidays of the Romanian Orthodox Church are: Baptism of Jesus (6 January); Resurrection of Jesus (has no fixed date), associated with Easter; Ascension of Jesus (has no fixed date, celebrated 40 days after Easter ); Dormition of the Theotokos (15 August), preceded by two weeks of fasting; Nativity of the Theotokos (8 September); Nativity of Jesus (25 December), associated with Christmas. [ Urbanization ] [ List of cities and towns in Romania ] [ Metropolitan Areas in Romania ] In the years following the Revolution has been a massive migration from village to city, but since 1996, the trend was reversed, and after 2005 was even stronger. Between 2005 and 2008, the number of people who have changed residence from rural to urban was 294,000, while the number of people who have changed residence from urban to rural was 418,000, difference being of over 120,000 people. Between 1996 and 2008, the difference was 313,000. [ http://businessday.ro/07/2011/urbanizarea-romaniei-cum-a-crescut-populatia-urbana-de-la-37-milioane-locuitori-in-1948-la-12-milioane-in-1989/ Urbanization of Romania: how urban population increased from 3.7 million in 1948 to 12 million in 1989 Businessday.ro 24 April 2012 ] According to statistics compiled in 2004, 11,895,600 citizens (54.88%) lived in the urban environment, and 9,777,728 citizens (45.12%) lived in the rural environment. The most urbanized counties are Hunedoara County (76.87%), Brașov County (74.91%) and Constanța County (71.12%), while the most sparsely urbanized counties are Ilfov County (26.09%), Dâmbovița County (30.06%) and Giurgiu County (30.95%). [ http://www.adevarul.ro/actualitate/doua-urbanizare-Romaniei_0_32998606.html &apos; &amp; #39;Adevărul&apos; &amp; #39; - The second urbanization of Romania Adevarul.ro 29 February 2008 24 April 2012 ] Bucharest is the capital and the largest city in Romania. At the census in 2011, its population was over 1.6  million. The LUZ area of Bucharest has a population of 2,192,372 inhabitants. [ http://www.urbanaudit.org/index.aspx Urban Audit Urban Audit 2011-08-29 ] As of 2011, there are plans to establish a metropolitan area up to 20 times the area of the city proper. [ http://www.zmb.ro/ Proiect – Zona metropolitana Bucuresti Zmb.ro 2011-08-29 ] [ http://www.romanialibera.ro/a94321/zona-metropolitana-bucuresti-va-fi-gata-peste-10-ani.html Metropolitan Zone of Bucharest will be ready in 10 years Romania Libera Romanian 2008-08-31 ] [ Romanian http://www.zmb.ro/main.php Official site of Metropolitan Zone of Bucharest Project 2008-08-31 ] Romania has four other cities that are among the European Union&apos;s 100 most populous : Cluj-Napoca, Timișoara, Iași and Constanța. Other cities with populations over 200,000 are Craiova, Galați and Brașov. Another 11 cities have a population of over 100,000. [ http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-esential-11436960-harta-interactiva-cum-schimbat-ierarhia-marilor-orase-din-tara-mai-ramas-doar-doua-orase-provincie-populatia-peste-300-000-locuitori.htm ​HARTA INTERACTIVA Cum s-a schimbat ierarhia marilor orase din tara. Au mai ramas doar doua orase de provincie cu populatia de peste 300.000 de locuitori 6 February 2012 14 February 2012 Hotnews.ro Romanian ] [ Romanian National Institute of Statistics Romanian Statistical Yearbook 2007 http://www.insse.ro/cms/files/pdf/en/cp2.pdf PDF 2008-01-20 ] At present, several of the largest cities have a metropolitan area : Constanța (446,595 inhab.), Iași (402,786 inhab.), Brașov (402,041 inhab.), Cluj-Napoca (392,562 inhab.), [ http://www.cjcluj.ro/zona-metropolitana-urbana/ Zona Metropolitana Urbana 25 May 2009 CJ Cluj Romanian ] [ http://www.cluj.insse.ro/cmscluj/files%5Cdeclaratii%5CComunicat%20CLUJ%20-%20DATE%20PROVIZORII%20RPL%202011.pdf Comunicat de presă privind rezultatele provizorii ale Recensământului Populaţiei şi Locuinţelor – 2011 Cluj County Regional Statistics Directorate 2012-02-02 2012-02-14 ] Craiova (333,834 inhab.) and Oradea (249,746 inhab.), and several others are planned: Bucharest, Timișoara, Brăila-Galați, Bacău and Ploiești. [ http://www.zmi.ro/de/zmi_context_romania.html Map of Romanian municipalities that can have metropolitan areas in maroon zmi.com 2008-08-31 ] Rural areas represent about 90% of total area of the country [ August 2011 ], and their share – among the highest in Europe – amounts to 47.3% of the total population. In December 2006 Romania had 2,854 commune s, consisting of 12,951 village s. The average population of a Romanian village is about 800 people. { Enciclopediaromaniei.ro } { 2011-05-07 } { 2011-08-29 } [ Education ] [ Romanian educational system ] [ Romanian Baccalaureate List of universities in Romania ] Since the Romanian Revolution of 1989, the Romanian educational system has been in a continuous process of reform that has been both praised and criticized. [ UNESCO http://www.unesco.org/education/wef/countryreports/romania/rapport_1.html The Romanian Educational Policy in Transition 2008-08-31 ] According to the Law on Education adopted in 1995, the educational system is regulated by the Ministry of Education and Research. Each level has its own form of organization and is subject to different legislation. Kindergarten is optional for children between 3 and 6 years old. School ing starts at age 7 (sometimes 6), and is compulsory until the 10th grade (which usually corresponds to the age of 17 or 16). [ UNESCO http://www.unesco.org/education/wef/countryreports/romania/rapport_2.html The Romanian Educational Policy in Transition 2008-08-31 ] Primary and secondary education are divided into 12 grades. Higher education is aligned with the European higher education area. { Politehnica University of Bucharest, one of the most prestigious educational institutions in Romania } Aside from the official schooling system, and the recently [ July 2011 ] added private equivalents, there exists a semi-legal, informal, fully private tutoring system. Tutoring is mostly used during secondary as a preparation for the various examinations, which are notoriously difficult. Tutoring is widespread, and it can be considered a part of the Education System. It has subsisted and even prospered during the Communist regime. [ http://www.genderomania.ro/book_gender_post/part1/Anca_Gheaus.pdf Limited relevants. What feminists can learn from the eastern experience PDF 2008-08-25 genderomania.ro ] In 2004, some 4.4  million of the population were enrolled in school. Out of these, 650,000 in kindergarten, 3.11  million (14% of population) in primary and secondary level, and 650,000 (3% of population) in tertiary level (universities). [ http://www.insse.ro/cms/files/pdf/ro/cap8.pdf PDF Romanian Institute of Statistics Yearbook – Chapter 8 Romanian 2008-08-31 ] In the same year, the adult literacy rate was 97.3% (45th worldwide), while the combined gross enrollment ratio for primary, secondary and tertiary schools was 75% (52nd worldwide). [ http://hdr.undp.org/hdr2006/pdfs/report/HDR06-complete.pdf UN Human Development Report 2006 http://web.archive.org/web/20070202212856/http%3A//hdr.undp.org/hdr2006/pdfs/report/HDR06-complete.pdf PDF 2007-02-02 ] The results of the PISA assessment study in schools for the year 2000 placed Romania on the 34th rank out of 42 participant countries with a general weighted score of 432 representing 85% of the mean OECD score. [ http://www.edu.ro/index.php?module%3Duploads%26amp%3Bfunc%3Ddownload%26amp%3BfileId%3D1958 OECD International Program for Evaluation of Students, National Report București 2002 10–15 Romanian Ministry of Education 2008-08-31 ] According to the Academic Ranking of World Universities, in 2006 no Romanian university was included in the first 500 top universities world wide. [ http://ed.sjtu.edu.cn/rank/2006/ARWU2006FULLLIST-BY%20RANK%20%28PDF%29.pdf PDF Academic Ranking World University 2006: Top 500 World University 2008-08-31 ] Using similar methodology to these rankings, it was reported that the best placed Romanian university, Bucharest University, attained the half score of the last university in the world top 500. [ Asociația Ad Astra a cercetătorilor români Răzvan Florian http://www.ad-astra.ro/journal/8/florian_shanghai_romania.pdf PDF Romanian Universities and the Shanghai rankings Cluj-Napoca, România 7–9 2008-08-31 ] In the most recently ranking Babes-Bolyai University was ranked number 1 University in Romania in 2009 by Capital. [ http://www.capital.ro/articol/exclusiv-topul-universitatilor-din-romania-125346.html EXCLUSIV: Topul universităţilor din România &gt; Capital.ro 2012-04-29 ] BBU is followed by University of Bucharest which is the second and by Transilvania University which is placed 3rd. Notably, Bucharest boasts the largest university in Europe by number of students, Spiru Haret University. { Cum a ajuns “Spiru Haret” cea mai mare universitate din lume Financiarul, 13 July 2009. } [ Culture ] [ Culture of Romania Symbols of Romania ] { Palace of Culture in } { Iași, built on the ruins of the Royal Court of Moldavia, hosts the largest art collection in Romania. } { Mihai Eminescu (1850–1889), Romania&apos;s national } { poet } { Constantin Brâncuși, prominent sculptor } Romania has a unique culture, which is the product of its geography and of its distinct historical evolution. Like Romanians themselves, it is fundamentally defined as the meeting point of three regions: Central Europe, Eastern Europe, and the Balkans, but cannot be truly included in any of them. [ http://www.itcnet.ro/folk_festival/culture.htm Romania – Culture 2008-08-31 http://web.archive.org/web/20071231125142/http%3A//www.itcnet.ro/folk_festival/culture.htm 31 December 2007 ] [ Arts, literature and philosophy ] [ Literature of Romania Arts in Romania Cinema of Romania Romanian philosophy ] A unified Romanian literature began to develop with the revolutions of 1848 and the union of the two Danubian Principalities in 1859. The origin of the Romanians began to be discussed and by the end of the 18th and beginning of the 19th century, Romanian Transylvanian scholars along with Romanian scholars from Moldavia and Wallachia began studying in France, Italy and Germany. [ http://www.ici.ro/romania/en/cultura/cultural_aspects.html Cultural aspects National Institute for Research &amp; Development in Informatics, Romania 2008-08-28 http://web.archive.org/web/20080307182620/http%3A//www.ici.ro/romania/en/cultura/cultural_aspects.html 7 March 2008 ] German philosophy and French culture were integrated into modern Romanian literature, and a new elite of artists led to the appearance of some of the classics of Romanian literature such as Mihai Eminescu, George Coșbuc, Ioan Slavici.Although not particularly renowned outside the country, these writers are widely appreciated within Romania for giving birth to modern Romanian literature. Eminescu is considered the greatest and most influential Romanian poet, particularly for the poem Luceafărul. [ Romanian http://www.ici.ro/romania/en/cultura/l_eminescu.html Mihai Eminescu National Institute for Research &amp; Development in Informatics, Romania 2008-01-20 http://web.archive.org/web/20071231163537/http%3A//www.ici.ro/romania/en/cultura/l_eminescu.html 2007-12-31 ] Among other writers that rose to prominence in the second half of 19th century are Mihail Kogălniceanu (also the first prime minister of Romania), Vasile Alecsandri, Nicolae Bălcescu, Ion Luca Caragiale, and Ion Creangă. The first half of the 20th century is regarded by many scholars as the Golden Age of Romanian culture, as it is the period when it reached its greatest level of international affirmation and enjoyed a strong connection to Western European cultural trends. [ http://www.columbia.edu/cu/romanian/articles/TheRomanianCulturalDebateOfTheSummer.html Romanian Cultural Debate of the Summer: Romanian Intellectuals and Their Status Groups Romanian Club @ Columbia University Mona Momescu 2008-08-28 ] Notably, figures such as Tristan Tzara and Marcel Janco pioneered the anti-war Dada movement beginning with the First World War. { Tom Sandqvist, DADA EAST: The Romanians of Cabaret Voltaire, London MIT Press, 2006. } The most prominent Romanian artist of this time, however, was sculptor Constantin Brâncuși, a central figure of the modern movement and a pioneer of abstraction. His works present a blend of simplicity and sophistication that led the way for modernist sculptors. [ http://www.brancusi.com/bio.html Constantin Brâncuși&apos;s bio Brancusi.com 2008-01-20 ] As a testimony to his skill, one of his pieces, Bird in Space, was sold in an auction for $27.5  million in 2005, a record for any sculpture. [ http://antiquesandthearts.com/AW-2005-05-10-12-15-39p1.htm Brancusi&apos;s &apos;Bird in Space&apos; Sets World Auction Record for Sculpture at $27,456,000 Antiques and the Arts Online 2008-01-20 ] [ http://crib.mae.ro/index.php?lang%3Den%26amp%3Bid%3D31%26amp%3Bs%3D15441%26amp%3Barhiva%3Dtrue Romanian Information Center in Brussels November  9, The price record for a Brancusi masterpiece was set up in 2005 when &quot; Bird in Space &quot; was sold for USD 27.5 M 2008-01-20 ] In the interwar years, Romanian literature was greatly expanded through the works of, among others, Tudor Arghezi, Mircea Eliade, Lucian Blaga, George Bacovia, Eugen Barbu and Liviu Rebreanu. After the World Wars, Communism brought &apos;absolute&apos; censorship and used the cultural world as well as a means to tightly control the population in addition to the much feared &quot; Securitate &quot; paramilitary organization, numerous formers and their informers. Freedom of expression was constantly restricted in various ways, but the likes of Gellu Naum, Nichita Stănescu, Marin Sorescu or Marin Preda managed to escape censorship, broke with &quot; socialist realism &quot; and were the leaders of a small &quot; Renaissance &quot; in Romanian literature. [ Ștefănescu Alex. Nichita Stănescu, The Angel With A Book In His Hands Romanian Mașina de scris 1999 8 978-973-99297-4-5 ] While not many of them managed to obtain international acclaim due to censorship, some, like Constantin Noica, Paul Goma and Mircea Cărtărescu, had their works published abroad even though they were jailed for various political reasons. Some artists chose to leave the country for good and continued to make contributions in exile. Among them Eugen Ionescu, Mircea Eliade and Emil Cioran became renowned internationally for their works. Other literary figures who enjoy acclaim outside of the country include the poet Paul Celan and Nobel laureate Elie Wiesel, both survivors of the Holocaust. The novelist, poet and essayist Herta Müller also received the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2009. Romanian contemporary cinema has achieved worldwide acclaim with the appearance of such films as The Death of Mr. Lăzărescu, directed by Cristi Puiu, ( Cannes 2005 Prix un certain regard winner) and 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days, directed by Cristian Mungiu ( Cannes 2007 Palme d&apos;Or winner). [ http://www.altfg.com/blog/film-festivals/cannes-2007-winners/ Cannes 2007 Winners Alternative Film Guide 2008-08-31 ] The latter, according to Variety, is &quot; further proof of Romania&apos;s new prominence in the film world. &quot; Also, the cinematographic drama If I Want to Whistle, I Whistle directed by Florin Șerban was nominated for the Golden Bear at the 60th Berlin International Film Festival and won the Jury Grand Prix (the Silver Bear ). [ http://www.variety.com/index.asp?layout%3Dcannes2007%26amp%3Bjump%3Dreview%26amp%3Breviewid%3DVE1117933650 4 Months, 3 Weeks &amp; 2 Days 2008-08-31 Jay Weissberg 2007-05-17 Variety ] [ April 2012 ] [ http://www.berlinale.de/en/das_festival/preise_und_juries/preise_internationale_jury/index.html Prizes of the International Jury 2010-02-21 ] [ Music ] [ Music of Romania ] { George Enescu is widely regarded as the most prominent Romanian composer. } The first half of the 20th century saw the rise of George Enescu, Romania&apos;s greatest composer. [ http://www.enescusociety.org/georgeenescu.php George Enescu, the composer International Enescu Society 2008-01-20 ] [ April 2012 ] A child prodigy, Enescu created his first musical composition at the age of five and became an accomplished composer, violin ist, pianist, conductor and teacher. [ http://www.ici.ro/romania/en/cultura/m_enescu.html George Enescu (1881–1955) National Institute for Research &amp; Development in Informatics, Romania 2008-01-20 http://web.archive.org/web/20080115090725/http%3A//www.ici.ro/romania/en/cultura/m_enescu.html 15 January 2008 ] The annual George Enescu Festival is held in Bucharest in his honor. Also active in this period was Dinu Lipatti, a pianist notable for his interpretations of Chopin, Mozart and Bach. Some famous postwar Romanian musicians are folk artists Maria Tănase, Tudor Gheorghe, and virtuoso of the pan flute Gheorghe Zamfir, the latter having sold over 120  million albums worldwide. [ http://www.cbc.ca/insite/SOUNDS_LIKE_CANADA/2006/1/17.html 2006-01-17 CBC Radio Sounds Like Canada feat. Gheorghe Zamfir 2008-08-31 http://web.archive.org/web/20080428050304/http%3A//www.cbc.ca/insite/SOUNDS_LIKE_CANADA/2006/1/17.html 28 April 2008 ] [ http://www.gheorghe-zamfir.com/English/diskographie-e.htm Gheorghe Zamfir, Official Homepage Gheorghe Zamfir, master of the pan pipe 2008-01-20 ] Artists from Romania have recently begun to inch their way onto the international pop music scene, scoring millions of views on YouTube and selling hundreds of thousands of singles. Among the best known are Inna, Edward Maya, Akcent and Alexandra Stan. Maya&apos;s &quot; Stereo Love &quot; became the first number one song in Billboard &apos;s year-end Dance Airplay chart to have reached number one three times in its chart run, while competing in a line-up that included Lady Gaga. Since the 2009 release of &quot; Stereo Love &quot;, the Bucharest -born composer has won gold and platinum albums from Canada to Spain and toured clubs as far away as India and Pakistan. [ http://www.ziare.com/muzica/cantareti/care-e-artistul-roman-cu-cea-mai-mare-priza-in-afara-tarii-sondaj-ziare-com-1086098 Care e artistul roman cu cea mai mare priza in afara tarii? Sondaj Ziare.com 2011-08-29 ] { Inna, the first } { Europe an female singer to surpass one billion hits on } { YouTube } Inna, however, has been the most successful, having sold nearly two million singles worldwide, notably in the United States and United Kingdom. Inna has had more than 114 million views on YouTube for her hits like &quot; Amazing &quot;, &quot; Sun Is Up &quot;, &quot; Hot &quot;, &quot; 10 Minutes &quot; or &quot; Club Rocker &quot; and more than two million fans on Facebook. Alexandra Stan, also a very popular singer has managed millions of views on YouTube and has won many song contests in countries like Israel, Germany or United States. She has also put together her first album consisting of songs such as &quot; Mr. Saxobeat &quot;. The single &quot; Get Back (ASAP) &quot; was awarded in Italy with Platinum Disc, for sales of over 60,000 copies, also Inna being awarded with Gold Discs in Netherlands and France. [ http://life.hotnews.ro/stiri-muzica-8384048-video-inna-castigat-discul-platina-franta.htm ​VIDEO Inna a castigat discul de platina in Franta – Muzica – HotNews.ro Life.hotnews.ro 2011-08-29 ] Romania joined the Eurovision Song Contest 1994, after an unsuccessful attempt the year before. Their best result is three (first in the 2005 final) while their worst is being number twenty-two. Mihai Trăistariu is the Romanian singer with most international performances. His song, &quot; Tornerò &quot;, was ranked the fourth place at Eurovision Song Contest 2006, with 172 points. He has sold over 1.5 million albums in Romania and abroad. Also, Paula Seling and Ovi Martin were ranked third place at televoting results of Eurovision Song Contest 2010, with 162 points. [ Dan Arsenie http://www.evz.ro/detalii/stiri/eurovision-2010-romania-bronz-germania-locul-intai-896221.html Paula Seling despre rezultatul la Eurovision 2010: &quot; Mai bine de atât nu se putea! &quot; &gt; EVZ.ro 2011-08-29 ] [ Monuments ] [ National Register of Historic Monuments in Romania List of World Heritage Sites in Romania List of museums in Romania List of castles in Romania ] { Romanian Athenaeum in Bucharest was opened in 1888 } The list of World Heritage Site s [ http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/?search%3D%26amp%3BsearchSites%3D%26amp%3Bsearch_by_country%3Dromania%26amp%3Btype%3D%26amp%3Bmedia%3D%26amp%3Bregion%3D%26amp%3Border%3D%26amp%3Bcriteria_restrication%3D%26amp%3Bx%3D0%26amp%3By%3D0 Official list of WHS within Romania UNESCO 2008-01-31 ] includes Romanian sites such as the Saxon villages with fortified churches in Transylvania, the Painted churches of northern Moldavia with their fine exterior and interior frescoes, the Wooden Churches of Maramureș unique examples that combine Gothic style with traditional timber construction, the Monastery of Horezu, the citadel of Sighișoara, and the Dacian Fortresses of the Orăștie Mountains. [ http://www.cimec.ro/Monumente/unesco/UNESCOen/fastvers.htm World Heritage List from Romania UNESCO 2008-01-31 ] Peleș Castle ( Sinaia ), built between 1873–1914, is considered one of the most beautiful castles in Romania and Eastern Europe. [ http://peles.ro/ Muzeul National Peles &amp; #124; Site-ul oficial al castelelor Peles si Pelisor Peles.ro 2011-08-29 ] Unique architecture and gold gilded rooms attract thousands of visitors daily. Voroneț Monastery, built in 1488, is one of the most valuable foundations of Stephen the Great. Also, Unirii Square is the treasure in the heart of Cluj-Napoca, on which rises the St. Michael&apos;s Roman Catholic Church, guarded by two &quot; twin &quot; buildings on the eastern side. Located at [ 29.7 km 0 on ] from Brașov, between Bucegi and Piatra Craiului Mountains, Bran Castle is a major national monument and tourist landmark. Built by Saxons in the 14th century, today it hosts an art and furniture collection by Queen Marie, but is also marketed as the legendary residence of Bram Stoker&apos;s Dracula. [ http://www.viaromania.eu/atractii.cfm/2-castelul_bran.html Castelul Bran Viaromania.eu 2011-08-29 ] Romania&apos;s contribution to the World Heritage List stands out because it consists of some groups of monuments scattered around the country, rather than one or two special landmarks. [ http://www.worldheritagesite.org/countries/romania.html World Heritage Site – Romania 2008-01-31 ] Also, in 2007, the city of Sibiu, famous for its Brukenthal National Museum, was the European Capital of Culture alongside the city of Luxembourg. [ The Selection Panel for the European Capital of Culture (ECOC) 2007 Report on the Nominations from Luxembourg and Romania for the European Capital of Culture 2007 2004-04-05 http://ec.europa.eu/culture/pdf/doc670_en.pdf PDF 2008-08-31 ] [ Sports ] [ Sport in Romania ] { Lucian Bute, the former } { IBF } { Super Middleweight champion in professional } { boxing and chosen number 1 at the } { Super Middleweight in 2011 by } { Boxrec } Oină is a traditional Romanian sporting game continuously practiced at least since the 14th century, pursuant to chronicles and charters, first official documentary attestation dating since 1364, during the reign of Vladislav I of Wallachia. [ http://federatiaromanadeoina.ro/page.php?105 Romanian Federation of Oină – History of the game Federatiaromanadeoina.ro 2011-08-29 ] [ April 2012 ] Oină is a sporting game practiced outdoors, on a rectangular field, preferably covered with grass, between two teams of eleven players. The game requires for complex sports skills and is similar to sports common in other countries, such as German Schlagball, Finnish palsepool, French jeu de paume, respectively Irish cluiche corr. Oină underlying the baseball, being borrowed from the period in which it not evolved enough, compared to contemporary period, in which oină represents an extremely complex game. Association football is the most popular sport in Romania. [ The Europa World Year Book Routledge 2007 2 Romania ] The governing body is the Romanian Football Federation, which belongs to UEFA. At the international level, the Romania national football team has taken part seven times in the FIFA World Cup. It had its most successful period in the 1990s, when during the 1994 FIFA World Cup in the United States, Romania reached the quarter-finals and was ranked sixth by FIFA. The core player of this &quot; Golden Generation &quot; [ http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2002/1677201.stm Hagi leaves Romania post 2001-11-26 BBC Sport Hagi enjoyed legendary status in Romania where he spearheaded the &apos;Golden Generation&apos; of players... 2008-08-31 ] and perhaps the best known Romanian player internationally is Gheorghe Hagi (nicknamed the Maradona of the Carpathians). [ http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/low/football/europe/1264097.stm Hagi snubs Maradona BBC Sport Online 2001-04-06 2008-08-31 ] Famous currently active players are Adrian Mutu and Cristian Chivu. The most famous football club is Steaua București, who in 1986 became the first Eastern European club ever to win the prestigious European Champions Cup title, and who played the final again in 1989. Another successful Romanian team Dinamo București played a semifinal in the European Champions Cup in 1984 and a Cup Winners Cup semifinal in the 1990. Other important Romanian football clubs are Rapid București, CFR 1907 Cluj-Napoca and FC Universitatea Craiova. { Ilie Năstase, first number 1 of the } { ATP } Tennis is the second most popular sport in terms of registered sportsmen. Romania reached the Davis Cup finals three times (1969, 1971, 1972). The tennis player Ilie Năstase won several Grand Slam titles and dozens of other tournaments, and was the first player to be ranked as number 1 by ATP from 1973 to 1974. His doubles and Davis Cup Partner as well as mentor, Ion Țiriac is now the most successful businessman in the country. Virginia Ruzici won the French Open in 1978, while in 1980 she was runner-up. Florența Mihai was another female tennis player from Romania who played the final of the French Open in 1977. The Romanian Open is held every fall in Bucharest since 1993. Irina Spîrlea was number 7 in the world in the WTA and Andrei Pavel top 15 of the ATP, both in the 90s. Famous currently active players are Sorana Cîrstea, Simona Halep, Monica Niculescu, Irina Begu, Alexandra Dulgheru, Victor Hănescu and Horia Tecău. Popular team sport s are rugby union ( national rugby team has so far competed at every Rugby World Cup ), basketball and handball. The Romania national handball team is a four-time world champion team, with Sweden and France (record holder), while Oltchim Râmnicu Vâlcea is a top team in women&apos;s handball. Some popular individual sport s are: athletics, chess, sport dance, and martial arts and other fighting sports. Fighting sports are actually popular in Romania, especially in the TV broadcastings. Famous boxers include Nicolae Linca, Francisc Vaștag, Mihai Leu, Leonard Doroftei, Adrian Diaconu and Lucian Bute, while Daniel Ghiță became the first Romanian kickboxer to qualify for the K-1 World Grand Prix Final. Famous athletes with outstanding results in this sport were: Iolanda Balaș, Lia Manoliu, Doina Melinte, Viorica Viscopoleanu, Mihaela Peneș, Argentina Menis, Ileana Silai, Anișoara Cușmir, Maricica Puică, Paula Ivan, Gabriela Szabo, Lidia Simon and lately Monica Iagăr, Marian Oprea, Mihaela Melinte or Constantina Diță-Tomescu. Romanian gymnastics has had a large number of successes – for which the country became known worldwide. { Romanians were for example stereotyped as gymnasts, as in the } { South Park episode } { Quintuplets 2000 } In the 1976 Summer Olympics, the gymnast Nadia Comăneci became the first gymnast ever to score a perfect ten in an Olympic event. She also won three gold medals, one silver and one bronze, all at the age of fifteen. [ http://www.gymn-forum.net/Articles/NYT-1976_AmCup2.html Gymnast Posts Perfect Mark Robin Herman New York Times 1976-03-28 2008-08-13 ] Her success continued in the 1980 Summer Olympics, where she was awarded two gold medals and two silver medals. In her career she won 30 medals, of which 21 were gold. Romania participated for the first time in the Olympic Games in 1900 and has taken part in 18 of the 24 summer games. Romania has been one of the more successful countries at the Summer Olympic Games ( 15th overall ) with a total of 283 medals won throughout the years, 82 of which are gold medals. [ http://www.infoplease.com/ipsa/A0115108.html All-Time Medal Standings, 1896–2004 infoplease.com 2008-08-31 ] They were noted for participating in the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles, United States, in defiance of a Warsaw Pact boycott, finishing second in gold medals (20) and third in total medal count (53). [ Traditions ] { Painted eggs } In addition to the religious aspects, in Romania Easter also symbolizes the rebirth and the renewal of daily life. It is usual on Easter morning, after the return of villagers from churches, for children to go to neighbors&apos; homes, to bring luck and wealth, in exchange for a red egg. On Christmas Eve, young people carol the village homes, hosts giving in exchange nuts, sponge cakes, apples, pretzels and other delicacies. The Star boys&apos; singing procession is a very important part of the Romanian Christmas festivity. In the week between Christmas and New Year, in all villages, groups of lads prepare for &quot; bid &quot;, a complex system of customs and habits. On the evening, in the eve of respective year which arises promising, are expected to occur &quot; Ursul &quot;, &quot; Capra &quot;, &quot; Bunghierii &quot;, &quot; Căiuții &quot;, &quot; Malanca &quot;, &quot; Jienii &quot;, &quot; Mascații &quot; and others. [ Improve It Grup S.R.L http://www.traditii.ro/ Traditii si obiceiuri romanesti. Artizanat traditional romanesc. Arta populara Traditii.ro 2011-08-29 ] { Sibiu } The Romanian folkloric costumes characterize own attributes of the Romanian people and contribute essentially at the definition of ethnic specificity. Closely related to human existence, the folkloric costume reflected over time, as reflected nowadays, mentality and artistic conception of the people. The folkloric costume has been developed with history, being a genuine expression of coherent tradition s throughout centuries. Distinct clothing ornamentation, traditional methods used for sewing and tailoring the pieces of clothing, and wide variety of costumes from one region to another customize the defining spirit of the Romanian people. For women, one of the most important parts of the celebration costume is a kerchief called maramă. A maramă is made from a special fabric called borangic, which resembles silk, so the texture of the material is really nice and soft. An important aspect is its transparency, given by the weaver in which it&apos;s made. The borangic is obtained from silkworms&apos; cocoons. Every woman grows the silkworms in her own yard, feeding them with mullberry leaves. After approximately 6 weeks, the worms would hide in their cocoons and the person who&apos;s in charge of them should move the cocoons into the sun so the worms die and the silk filament can be extracted. Once all the filaments are extracted, they&apos;re put into a weaver and one woman starts making the maramă. { http://www.unibuc.ro/uploads_ro/48384/1328/CIVILIZATIA_TRADITIONALA.pdf } Also, the folklore of Romania is defined by its mythology, branch of folk literature that integrates a variety of ancestral habits, tale s, fable s and ballad s, whose authors are anonymous. The rural character of the Romanian communities resulted in an exceptionally vital and creative traditional culture. So, in Romanian mythology were conceived fabulous beings, unreal characters endowed with supernatural powers. These include Baba Cloanța, a misshapen and recondite witch, Iele, inconstant virgins endowed with unapproachable ability of seduction and superhuman features, Muma Pădurii, a hag that lives in deep forest, Strigoi, troubled souls of the dead rising from the grave and Făt-Frumos, a knight hero that fights with griffons, dragons and witch es to liberate his heart chosen, Ileana Cosânzeana. { http://andilandi.ro/marul-de-aur/personaje-mitologice-romanesti/ } The words &quot; longing &quot; and &quot; mourning &quot; have correspondent in another language, but the nonfigurative character remains undecipherable and define specificity of the Romanian soul. Doina, characteristic only Romanian literary folklore, represents the lyric creation that Romanian expresses the most varied and complex range of feelings, strongly rooted in his spiritual structure. In the Romanian folkloric tradition, &quot; doina &quot; was played mainly orally or accompanied by a single instrument, being the song of elegy, played for self comforting and not intended for festive events because of its sober nature. [ Cuisine ] [ Romanian cuisine ] { Amandine cakes } Romanian cuisine is a diverse blend of different dishes from several traditions with which it has come into contact, but it also maintains its own character. It has been greatly influenced by Ottoman cuisine but also includes influences from the cuisines of other neighbours, such as the Greeks ( musaca ), Bulgarians ( zacuscă ), Turks ( pilaf ), and Hungarians ( langoși ). Quite different types of dishes are sometimes included under a generic term; for example, the category ciorbă includes a wide range of soups with a characteristic sour taste. These may be meat and vegetable soups, tripe and calf foot soups, or fish soups, all of which are soured by lemon juice, sauerkraut juice, vinegar, or traditionally borș (fermented wheat bran). Popular main courses include mititei, frigărui and the șnițel. One of the most common dishes is mămăliga (similar to the Italian polenta ), and is served on its own or as a side dish. Pork and chicken are the preferred meats, but beef, lamb and fish are also popular. Sarmale are prepared from minced meat (pork, beef, mutton, poultry or fish meat, especially in the Danube Delta), mixed with rice and other aliments (pap, couscous etc.) and wrapped in cabbage (fresh or sour) or vine leaves in the form of rolls. Usually, they are served with polenta and smetana, but can be served with a spoonful of fresh butter. The list of desserts includes names like amandine, clătite, chec, cozonac, gogoși, griș cu lapte, lapte de pasăre etc. In the north-western Romania, are prepared so-called ciureghe, gomboți cu prune, pancove, plăcinte crețe, while in the north-eastern Romania, the traditional desserts are chec cu vișine, tartă cu mere, alivenci moldovenești. [ http://www.bucataras.ro/retete-traditionale/140/ Retete traditionale Moldova: retete peste sau cu carne de porc. Bucataras.ro 2008-12-15 2011-08-29 ] { Palincă de prune &apos;&apos;, a traditional } { fruit brandy } Țuică is a strong plum brandy that is widely regarded as the country&apos;s traditional alcoholic beverage, along with wine. Romania is the world&apos;s second largest plum producer (after the United States ) { Romania second to USA in world plum production, 2007 plum production data on FAOSTAT } and as much as 75% of Romania&apos;s plum production is processed into the famous țuică, a plum brandy obtained through one or more distillation steps reaching (but not limited to) an 70% alcohool concentration depending on the number of steps of distillation. [ http://www.regard-est.com/home/breve_contenu.php?id%3D868 Țuica production consumed 75% of Romanian plums in 2003 Regard-est.com 2011-08-29 ] Alcoholic beverages are also obtained from other fruits (see rachiu, palincă and vișinată ). [ http://www.educations.com/Study_in_Romania__d2929.html Study in Romania Educations.com 2008-02-05 2011-03-14 ] Wine, however, is the preferred drink, and Romanian wines have a tradition of over three millennia. Romania is currently the world&apos;s 9th largest wine producer, and recently [ July 2011 ] the export market has started to grow. Romania produces a wide selection of domestic varieties ( Fetească, Grasă, Tamâioasă, Băbească ), as well as varieties from across the world ( Italian Riesling, Merlot, Sauvignon blanc, Cabernet Sauvignon, Chardonnay, Muscat Ottonel ). Beer is also highly regarded, generally blonde pilsener beer, the traditional methods of preparation being generally influenced by German wheat beers. There are some Romanian breweries with a long tradition, such as Timișoreana, Ursus and Azuga. Since the 19th century, beer has become increasingly popular, and today Romanians are amongst the heaviest beer drinkers in the world. [ Diana Tudor http://www.zf.ro/zf-english/romania-enters-global-top-10-for-beer-consumption-3053140/ Romania enters global top 10 for beer consumption &amp; #124; Ziarul Financiar Zf.ro 2011-03-14 ] Certain recipes are made in direct connection with the season or the holiday s. At Christmas, each family usually sacrifice a pig and prepare a large variety of dishes of its meat and organs ( cârnați, caltaboși, chiftele, tobă, șnițele ). At Easter, is customary to sacrifice a lamb, preparing of its meat drob de miel and roast lamb with thyme, as dessert being served pască cu brânză and cozonac cu nucă. [ http://gastronomie.ele.ro/Bucatarie_romaneasca_--a304.html Bucatarie romaneasca – Cultura si retete – Articole Gastronomie.ele.ro 2011-08-29 ] [ See also ] [ Romania European Union ] [ Romania ] yo:Románíà zh-yue:羅馬尼亞 diq:Romanya bat-smg:Romunėjė zh:羅馬尼亞 The Simpsons includes a large array of supporting characters: co-workers, teachers, family friends, extended relatives, townspeople, local celebrities, fictional characters within the show and even animals. The writers originally intended many of these characters as one-time jokes or for fulfilling needed functions in the town. A number of them have gained expanded roles and have subsequently starred in their own episodes. According to the creator of The Simpsons, Matt Groening, the show adopted the concept of a large supporting cast from the Canadian sketch comedy show Second City Television. [ http://www.avclub.com/content/node/47771/1 Matt Groening: Interview 2006-10-22 Rabin Nathan 2006-04-26 The A.V. Club ] [ Agnes Skinner ] Agnes Skinner, voiced by Tress MacNeille is the mother of school principal Seymour Skinner and first appeared in the first season episode &quot; The Crepes of Wrath &quot; as an old woman who embarrassingly calls her son &quot; Spanky &quot;. However, as episodes progressed, the character turned bitter. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { The Crepes of Wrath &quot; } She is very harshly controlling of Seymour, and treats him like a mother would a small child, once grounding him because he did not say who was at the door after answering it, when it was &quot; The Sugarman &quot;. She hates Edna Krabappel. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Special Edna &quot; } Agnes has married a total of four times, once with Skinner&apos;s father, Sheldon Skinner, and following Sheldon&apos;s death she then married three more times, each time, to a tow truck driver. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Midnight Towboy &quot; } Several Springfield residents (including the Simpsons) are afraid of her. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { The Principal and the Pauper &quot; } When Agnes&apos; real son, &quot; the real Seymour Skinner &quot; arrives in Springfield, Agnes turns him away, unhappy with her new living situation, largely because the true Seymour Skinner is a man who can stand up to Agnes and make his own decisions. Although she appears to not care for the fake Skinner, it turns out she really loves him, although she denies it in &quot; Large Marge &quot;. Agnes&apos;s first name was revealed in the seventh season episode &quot; Bart the Fink &quot;. { Richmond, p. 196 } Before that, the character was known as &quot; Mrs. Skinner &quot;. In the beginning of the series, the writers made several references to Agnes and Seymour&apos;s relationship being similar to that of Norman Bates and his mother&apos;s in the film Psycho. { Jean, Al (2003). Easter egg commentary for &quot; } { Separate Vocations &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Third Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } In &quot; Boy Meets Curl, &quot; it is revealed that some of Agnes&apos; resentment to Seymour may have derived from even before Seymour was born  — during the 1952 Summer Olympics in Helsinki, Agnes competed in the pole vaulting event while 9-months pregnant. When Seymour makes his first kick, he hits the bar, thus, making Agnes lose and subsequently crushing her dreams. { &quot; } { Boy Meets Curl, &quot; first aired February 14, 2010 } However, this would contradict the earlier episode when it is revealed that Seymour isn&apos;t her birth son. [ Akira ] Akira, works as a waiter at The Happy Sumo, a Japanese restaurant in Springfield. He first appeared in the second season in &quot; One Fish, Two Fish, Blowfish, Blue Fish &quot;. Actor George Takei originally voiced Akira in &quot; One Fish, Two Fish, Blowfish, Blue Fish &quot;. Since Akira&apos;s speaking role in &quot; When Flanders Failed &quot;, Hank Azaria has voiced the character, doing an impression of Takei for the voice. { Jean, Al (2003). Commentary for &quot; } { When Flanders Failed &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Third Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } [ Anastasia ] Anastasia is a tiger that performs in casinos with Gunter and Ernst. She debuts in &quot; $pringfield &quot;, where it is explained she was captured from the wild by Ernst and Gunter. She reappears in &quot; Viva Ned Flanders &quot;, performing in Las Vegas. In &quot; The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons &quot;, Gunter and Ernst lose it. [ Arnie Pye ] Arnie Pye, voiced by Dan Castellaneta, is a disgruntled, somewhat eccentric helicopter traffic reporter for Springfield&apos;s KBBL-TV (Channel 6). His name and appearance are a parody of the famous, Pulitzer winning 1930s journalist, Ernie Pyle. His segments are titled &quot; Arnie (or &quot; Pye &quot; ) in the Sky &quot;. He has an apparent dislike of anchorman Kent Brockman, with whom he often gets into arguments on the air, and Brockman once snarled that Arnie was a &quot; jackass &quot;. In earlier episodes he had the name &apos;Bill Pye&apos;. [ Arthur Crandall and Gabbo ] Arthur Crandall and Gabbo (both voiced by Hank Azaria ) are a puppet and ventriloquist who start their own TV show that is in competition with Krusty the Clown &apos;s. The show is a huge hit that ruins Krusty&apos;s career, but Bart then ruins Gabbo&apos;s future by capturing him making a rude comment on TV. The pair are later reduced to low-paying work such as a show at an Indian casino. The pair mainly appeared in season four&apos;s &quot; Krusty Gets Kancelled &quot; but they also appeared in &quot; Bart to the Future &quot;, &quot; Homerazzi &quot;, &quot; All About Lisa &quot;, and The Simpsons Movie. [ Artie Ziff ] Artie Ziff is a former classmate of Marge who becomes an Internet millionaire. He is voiced by Jon Lovitz in all appearances, except for season four&apos;s &quot; The Front &quot;, where he was voiced by Dan Castellaneta. [ Jean, Al The Simpsons: The Complete Third Season DVD Video ] In &quot; The Ziff Who Came to Dinner &quot;, where after he loses his bankrupt company to Homer, Homer is taken away by the United States Securities and Exchange Commission for bankrupting the company, although Artie confesses in the end and goes to jail instead. Strongly disliked by Marge since their experience at the senior prom when he attempts to grope her, he eventually comes to terms with the fact that his personality, not his religion ( Judaism ), is the reason he is disliked. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Half-Decent Proposal &quot; } Animator David Silverman based Ziff&apos;s appearance and body language of a man he went to high school with. [ http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1565538/20070725/story.jhtml &apos;Simpsons&apos; Trivia, From Swearing Lisa To &apos;Burns-Sexual&apos; Smithers 2007-07-29 2007-07-26 Larry Carroll MTV ] [ Baby Gerald ] Gerald Samson, better known as Baby Gerald, also known as &quot; the one-eyebrowed baby &quot;, is Maggie Simpson &apos;s archenemy, known for his large unibrow. He makes his first appearance in &quot; Sweet Seymour Skinner&apos;s Baadasssss Song &quot;, where Lisa refers to Baby Gerald as Maggie&apos;s rival. On a few occasions, Gerald has been shown being pushed in a stroller by his mother outside the Simpson house as in &quot; Lady Bouvier&apos;s Lover &quot;, as the two babies glare at one another. The character&apos;s name was revealed in the episode &quot; The Canine Mutiny &quot;. { Richmond, p. 223 } [ Benjamin, Doug and Gary ] Benjamin, Doug, and Gary (voiced by Harry Shearer, Hank Azaria, and Dan Castellaneta, respectively) are geek s that were once Homer&apos;s dormitory roommates at Springfield University. Gary carries a calculator on his belt and uses ear medicine, Doug is overweight and wears a pocket protector, and Benjamin is black and wears horn-rimmed glasses. { Richmond, p122. } The writer of &quot; Homer Goes to College &quot; Conan O&apos;Brien partially based them on three guys he went to college with, who, he said, were &quot; incredible nerds &quot;. { O&apos;Brien, Conan (2004). Commentary for &quot; } { Homer Goes to College &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Fifth Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } Because time was short, director Jim Reardon used a caricature of animator Rich Moore and colored it black for Benjamin. { Reardon, Jim (2004). Commentary for &quot; Homer Goes to College &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Fifth Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } [ Bernice Hibbert ] Bernice Hibbert, voiced by Tress MacNeille. She is Dr. Julius Hibbert &apos;s wife and is loosely based on the Clair Huxtable character from The Cosby Show. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Duffless &quot; } She has two boys and a girl with Julius. Nevertheless, her marriage is on the rocks; { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Dude, Where&apos;s My Ranch? &quot; } Bernice refuses to kiss Julius, even when an entire audience is looking at them. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Marge and Homer Turn a Couple Play &quot; } Her drinking has been joked about on several occasions; she faints when she reads that prohibition had been introduced to Springfield { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Homer vs. the Eighteenth Amendment &quot; } and attends Springfield Alcoholics Anonymous meetings. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Days of Wine and D&apos;oh&apos;ses &quot; } [ Bill and Marty ] Bill and Marty, voiced by Harry Shearer and Dan Castellaneta, are two radio show hosts and DJs on Springfield&apos;s own radio station KBBL. Marty is middle-aged and balding, while Bill is younger and has a full head of hair. They are responsible for giving Bart his elephant, Stampy, although they were surprised when Bart wanted Stampy, because they thought he would choose the other prize, $10,000. When Mr. Burns monopolized the local media in Fraudcast News, he fired the duo, but they have returned to the job in later episodes. [ Billy ] Billy is Troy McClure &apos;s assistant who appeared in &quot; Lisa the Simpson &quot;, and &quot; Bart the Mother &quot;. He was supposed to appear in more episodes but due to McClure&apos;s voice actor Phil Hartman &apos;s death, he was retired along with McClure. He is a child who appears in Troy McClure&apos;s educational films. He appears in the films &quot; Birds: Our Fine Feathered Colleagues &quot;, and &quot; In The Kitchen with DNA &quot;. He was voiced by Tress MacNeille. A similar child named Jimmy (who at one point McClure also calls Billy) appears in &quot; The Meat Council Presents: &apos;Meat and You: Partners in Freedom&apos; &quot; in the episode, &quot; Lisa the Vegetarian &quot;. [ Birch Barlow ] Birchibald &quot; Birch &quot; T. Barlow (voiced by Harry Shearer on &quot; Sideshow Bob Roberts &quot; and Maurice LaMarche on &quot; You Kent Always Say What You Want &quot; ). He is a conservative talk show host on the radio station KBBL, who in voice and appearance is modeled after Rush Limbaugh. As of &quot; You Kent Always Say What You Want &quot;, he also has a show on Fox News, and serves as a parody of Fox News conservative bias. On his radio show, he declares himself to be &quot; the fourth branch of government &quot; and &quot; the fifty-first state &quot;. He is also the author of the book Only Turkey s Have Left Wings. Barlow plays an important part in the episode &quot; Sideshow Bob Roberts &quot;, in which Sideshow Bob, while jailed, calls Barlow on his radio show, giving Bob an outlet to voice how the prison treats him unfairly. Barlow, knowing Bob is a fellow Republican, sympathizes with his complaints, and influences the rest of Springfield to as well. This leads to Bob&apos;s prompt release and ensuing mayor al election-rigging. Barlow also appears in the episode &quot; We&apos;re on the Road to D&apos;ohwhere &quot; as a customer at Marge&apos;s prescription drug-laden &quot; yard sale &quot;, a reference to Limbaugh&apos;s Oxycontin addiction. Most recently Barlow appears with other Springfield Republicans in the episode &quot; E Pluribus Wiggum &quot;, in which he tells Lisa to make Ralph Wiggum decide whether he wants to run for President as a Republican or a Democrat. [ &quot; Bleeding Gums &quot; Murphy ] &quot; Bleeding Gums &quot; Murphy, voiced by Ron Taylor and Daryl L. Coley, { Daryl L. Coley TV.com. URL accessed on December 7, 2006 } was a jazz musician, idol, and mentor of Lisa Simpson. His actual first name has never been revealed, though Murphy claimed his nickname came from the fact he had never once been to a dentist, as &quot; I got enough pain in my life as it is &quot;. His significant roles were in the episodes &quot; Moaning Lisa &quot; and &quot; &apos;Round Springfield &quot;, though he appears in other episodes, such as &quot; Bart the Daredevil &quot; (where he is yellow), &quot; Dancin&apos; Homer &quot;, &quot; Old Money &quot;, &quot; Flaming Moe&apos;s, &quot; Bart Gets an F &quot;, &quot; Radio Bart &quot;, and &quot; Lisa&apos;s Pony &quot;. In &quot; Dancin&apos; Homer &quot;, he was voiced by Daryl L. Coley. In &quot; Round Springfield we learn that at one point he had enjoyed a fairly successful career, releasing an album ( &quot; Sax on the Beach &quot; ) and appearing on Steve Allen &apos;s Tonight Show, { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { &apos;Round Springfield &quot; } and as one of the Cosby children&apos;s four grandfathers on an episode of The Cosby Show, but quickly lost his money feeding his $1500-a-day habit of purchasing and smashing Fabergé egg s. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Moaning Lisa &quot; } He had taught Lisa to display her emotions through music, prompting Lisa to hold him as an important figure in her life. His last appearance was in &quot; &apos;Round Springfield &quot; { &apos;Round Springfield The Simpsons.com. URL accessed on December 14, 2006 } - after Bart ends up in the hospital, Lisa wanders off to find Murphy dying in a nearby ward. He explains about his life, family, and work to her as well as giving her advice for her upcoming school performance, giving her his saxophone. When Lisa returns, she finds out that Bleeding Gums has died from circumstances which are never revealed. No one, except for Lisa, attends Murphy&apos;s funeral. Lisa soon learns that though he may be gone, he still is alive in her. It is strongly hinted that Murphy and Doctor Hibbert are long-lost brothers, most notably by Murphy&apos;s quote: &quot; I don&apos;t really have a family. All I had was a little brother who grew up to become a doctor. He used to laugh at the most inappropriate times. &quot; Hibbert then laughs inappropriately and says, &quot; Hey, I&apos;ve got an older brother that I&apos;ll never see. He&apos;s a jazz musician or some such. Oh well, bye, bye. &quot; Bleeding Gums Murphy is loosely based on Blind Willie Johnson, at whose feet the young Bleeding Gums character learned. { Matt Groening, DVD commentary for the episode &quot; &apos;Round Springfield &quot; } The voice of Bleeding Gums Murphy was provided by Ron Taylor, while his saxophone playing is provided by Dan Higgins. { Dan Higgins Biography Dan Higgins.net. URL accessed on December 15, 2006 } As a sign of respect for the character, Murphy has been a fixture of The Simpsons opening sequence since the second season. Originally, even after his death, Bart would skateboard past him on the street.In &quot; The Great Wife Hope &quot; Bleeding Gums Murphy is mentioned and supposedly according to Carl he is still alive after Homer asks Carl if he knows African-American boxer Drederick Tatum; Carl takes offense, saying that just because he is African American, he doesn&apos;t know all the other African-American citizens in Springfield. Carl then says that he met Drederick Tatum while he was at a party with Dr. Hibbert at Bleeding Gums Murphy&apos;s house. { Opening Sequence SNPP. } [ Blinky ] Blinky is a three-eyed orange fish featured primarily in &quot; Two Cars in Every Garage and Three Eyes on Every Fish &quot;. Likely mutated by toxic waste from the Springfield Nuclear Power Plant pouring into the river, Blinky became a major news story when he was caught by Bart Simpson. Mr. Burns defends the fish, arguing that his extra eye is merely the next step in evolution. Mr. Burns later goes to the Simpsons&apos; house for a meal to boost his race for governor. Marge, a supporter of Burns&apos; opponent Mary Bailey, deliberately serves Blinky for dinner. Mr. Burns spits the fish out and subsequently loses the election. Blinky was briefly seen again in episodes &quot; Homer&apos;s Odyssey &quot; and &quot; Raging Abe Simpson and His Grumbling Grandson in &quot; The Curse of the Flying Hellfish &quot; &quot;. Blinky also made a brief appearance in an underwater section of tube-way Fry travels through in the pilot episode of the animated series Futurama, which was created by Simpsons creator Matt Groening. [ Blue Haired Lawyer ] Mr. Burns&apos; Lawyer, { Reiss, Mike (2002). Commentary for &quot; } { Bart Gets Hit by a Car &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Second Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } also known as &quot; The Blue-Haired Lawyer &quot;, is voiced by Dan Castellaneta. { Gimple, p. 86 } He first appeared in the second season episode &quot; Bart Gets Hit by a Car &quot;. { Richmond, p. 153 } He is Springfield&apos;s most prominent and powerful lawyer, known for his blue hair and nasal New York accent. He also occasionally appears to serve as a prosecutor. Unlike Lionel Hutz or Gil Gunderson, he is a competent though not necessarily ethical lawyer. He has served as Mr. Burns &apos; head lawyer, helping him out with threats of the Power Plant closing down and of Burns losing his money. He is a member of the Springfield Republican Party. His clients often tend to be antagonists of the Simpsons. The Blue Haired Lawyer played a very important role in Bart&apos;s emancipation in &quot; Barting Over &quot; and works at a law firm named &quot; Luvum and Burnam &quot;. The character&apos;s demeanor, as well as Dan Castellaneta&apos;s voice for the character, are based on Roy Cohn, best known as Joe McCarthy &apos;s chief counsel during the Communist witchhunts in the 1950s. Animator Jim Reardon modeled the character&apos;s appearance on actor Charles Lane. { Reardon, Jim (2005). Commentary for &quot; } { Bart the Fink &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Seventh Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } [ Boobarella ] Boobarella is an ample-chested vampire -looking woman, first seen in the episode &quot; I&apos;m Spelling as Fast as I Can &quot;. She is aware of the size of her breasts, and often makes reference to them on the rare occasion she appears on TV. Her character is a takeoff of Elvira, a character portrayed by Cassandra Peterson, herself a takeoff of Vampira. Her name is probably a takeoff from Vampirella and the 1968 cult science fiction/fantasy/horror film Barbarella, which stars Jane Fonda in the title role. Boobarella uses a stereotypical Eastern European &quot; horror &quot; accent and makes school supplies. [ Brandine Spuckler ] Brandine Spuckler is voiced by Tress MacNeille and is the partner of Cletus Spuckler. Brandine and Cletus are depicted as stereotypical yokels. Throughout the series, the two are shown to be brother and sister, { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Alone Again, Natura-Diddily &quot; } boyfriend and girlfriend, { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { There&apos;s Something About Marrying &quot; } mother and son, { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { The Italian Bob &quot; } and father and daughter. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Little Big Girl &quot; } She is apparently the daughter of Cletus and an alien. She has suffered from rabies, { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Goo Goo Gai Pan &quot; } and admitted to being illiterate. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { 22 Short Films About Springfield &quot; } More recently, Brandine is shown fighting in the Iraq War. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Yokel Chords &quot; } She comes back revealing Cletus is the father of only two of the kids, casting doubt over the paternity of her other children. Assuming that all of the children believed to be Cletus&apos; are also hers, Brandine has 45 specifically named children. Brandine and Cletus were married by Homer during his brief stint as a priest. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Simple Simpson &quot; } On April 27, 2008, more is revealed about Cletus and Brandine in an episode entitled &quot; Apocalypse Cow &quot;; Brandine had married Cletus at the age of 13, and had married four times before that. Some of the most distinct features of Brandine are that she speaks in a thick accent, and wears her red hair up in a high ponytail. [ Brunella Pommelhorst ] The school gym teacher, voiced by Tress MacNeille / Maggie Roswell (in Moaning Lisa) First appeared in &quot; Moaning Lisa &quot;, although her name is not mentioned until &quot; The PTA Disbands &quot;. She has blond hair and usually wears a whistle and takes a tough-as-nails approach to teaching. In &quot; Little Girl in the Big Ten &quot;, she decides that because of the oath she took on Xena, she has to fail Lisa but decides to let her make it up by taking private lessons. In a more recent episode, &quot; My Fair Laddy &quot;, she decides to leave for the year and return the next semester as &quot; Mr. Pommelhorst, the new shop teacher. &quot; [ Bumblebee Man ] The Bumblebee Man, voiced by Hank Azaria, is the star of a Spanish-language television sitcom on &quot; Channel Ocho &quot;, in which he dresses in a bumblebee costume and performs slapstick comedy. In the episode &quot; Team Homer &quot;, his bowling shirt bears the name &quot; Pedro &quot;. He works at the same studio as Kent Brockman. His first appearance was in &quot; Itchy &amp; Scratchy: The Movie &quot;. Bumblebee Man is never seen to take off his costume, even when by himself; the sole exception is the episode &quot; 22 Short Films About Springfield &quot;, in which his private life is shown. In this short segment, he is portrayed as innately clumsy rather than simply acting as such. In general, Bumblebee Man only speaks in simple, over-enunciated (and inaccurate) Spanish sentences. His catchphrases of choice are typically &quot; ¡Ay, ay, ay, no me gusta! &quot; ( &quot; I don&apos;t like it! &quot; ), &quot; ¡Ay, ay, ay, no es bueno! &quot; ( &quot; That&apos;s not good! &quot; ) and &quot; ¡Ay, Dios no me ama! &quot; ( &quot; God doesn&apos;t love me! &quot; ). Quite commonly, his phrases will be intentionally sloppy Spanish. For example, in the episode &quot; 22 Short Films About Springfield &quot;, there are several words used that are not real (such as &quot; wudpequero &quot; for &quot; woodpecker &quot;, rather than the correct pájaro carpintero). The crude Spanish is used so that English-speaking viewers would still understand what was being said. { Season 7 DVD Commentary - &quot; } { 22 Short Films About Springfield &quot; } On occasions, he also speaks English, such as briefly in &quot; Mr. Spritz Goes to Washington &quot;. In &quot; Bart Gets Famous &quot;, he anchored the news with an articulate English accent, filling in for the regular, Kent Brockman. Bumblebee Man is a caricature of El Chapulín Colorado, a character created and portrayed by Mexican television comedian Roberto Gómez Bolaños (a.k.a. &quot; Chespirito &quot; ), and his show consists of simple skits, often involving heavy slapstick. The staff have said that whenever they watched Telemundo, this character was &quot; always on &quot;, thus they created Bumblebee Man, who is also always on the air when the Spanish-language channel is depicted. [ Reiss, Mike 2004 The Simpsons season 4 DVD commentary for the episode &quot; Itchy &amp; Scratchy: The Movie &quot; DVD 20th Century Fox ] His costume was based on one used in the Saturday Night Live sketch &quot; Killer Bees &quot;. [ Flash! 24 Simpsons Stars Reveal Themselves 2007-08-15 2000-10-21 TV Guide Joe Rhodes ] Hank Azaria won a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Voice-Over Performance for voicing Bumblebee Man, and various other characters, in 2003. [ http://www.emmys.org/awards/awardsearch.php Primetime Emmy Awards Advanced Search Emmys.org 2008-11-05 ] [ Capital City Goofball ] The Capital City Goofball is the mascot for Capital City. He was voiced by Tom Poston. His appearance seems to have been inspired by the mascot of the Philadelphia Phillies baseball team, the Phillie Phanatic. The costume is a creature with a baseball body, with a blue Capital City T-Shirt, yellow arms and legs, a long flat-ended nose, tufts of fur at the side, a red hat with two springs, two costume eyes that look in either direction, and two more eyes that peek outside the mouth. The Capital City Goofball first appeared in the episode &quot; Dancin&apos; Homer &quot; and shared the stage with Homer. In &quot; Bart vs. Lisa vs. the Third Grade &quot;, the Capital City Goofball represents Capital City in the state legislature; he spent 80 million dollars out of his own pocket to win the seat, and now is leading an effort to change the state&apos;s embarrassing, Confederate-symbol centered state flag. With the death of Tom Poston in 2007, it is likely that this character will be retired, if the precedent regarding Phil Hartman and Doris Grau &apos;s characters (except for Lunchlady Doris, who is still used and is now voiced by Tress MacNeille ) is followed. He has not spoken since &quot; Bart and Lisa vs. the Third Grade &quot; and has been reduced to making minor background appearances and usual honking sounds. [ Captain Lance Murdock ] Captain Lance Murdock is a professional stunt devil who appeared more in the early days of the show rather than the newer episodes. He first appeared in &quot; Bart the Daredevil &quot; which featured him in more scenes than other episodes. He later appeared in &quot; I Married Marge &quot;, &quot; Selma&apos;s Choice &quot;, and &quot; Viva Ned Flanders &quot;. He was most recently featured when Krusty was flicking channels on his TV in &quot; Today I Am a Clown &quot;. He also appears in Lisa &apos;s lecture about Lake Springfield in The Simpsons Movie sitting in the audience. His signature bike is the suicycle and has his own action figure complete with ambulance. [ Charlie ] Charlie, voiced by Dan Castellaneta works at the Springfield Nuclear Power Plant as the &apos;Dangerous Emissions Supervisor&apos;. He was briefly replaced by Mindy Simmons, but she got fired afterwards. His first appearance was in &quot; Life on the Fast Lane &quot;. He was briefly out of work due to a unnamed on-the-job injury, where he collected workers&apos; compensation, however future episodes show him back to work. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { King-Size Homer &quot; } { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Homer Goes to College &quot; } He has a wife and two kids { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Homer the Smithers &quot; } as well as a sister with a wooden leg. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Homer at the Bat &quot; } In &quot; The Trouble with Trillions &quot;, Charlie tells Homer (who is working undercover) that he has plans to overrun the American government due to their stalling on making HDTV available; he is soon arrested by FBI agents for conspiracy. Dan Castellaneta said that he did &quot; an imitation of Lenny &quot; (voiced by Harry Shearer ) for the voice. { Castellaneta, Dan (2003). Commentary for &quot; } { Homer at the Bat &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Third Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } [ Chase/Pyro ] Chase, also known as Pyro, is an American Gladiator. He is a parody of the real-life Gladiator Nitro. He first appears in the episode &quot; A Milhouse Divided &quot;, when he is dating Luann after she divorces Kirk. Their relationship ends when she&apos;s caught cheating on him with his best friend Gyro. He also appears in &quot; Wild Barts Can&apos;t Be Broken &quot;, &quot; Mom and Pop Art &quot;, &quot; Alone Again, Natura-Diddily &quot;, It&apos;s a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad Marge, Day of the Jackanapes, A Star Is Born Again, and &quot; The Bart of War &quot;. He is voiced by Hank Azaria. [ Cookie Kwan ] Cookie Kwan (voiced by Tress MacNeille ), is an Asian American real estate broker who first appears in the Season 9 Simpsons episode &quot; Realty Bites &quot;. She is the stereotypical competitive woman. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Realty Bites &quot; } She touts herself as being &quot; number one on the West Side &quot;, although she also works on the East Side. She is very aggressive toward anyone whom she deems a threat to her business, evidenced by when she threatens Gil Gunderson. She had once attempted to seduce Ned Flanders, { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { A Star Is Born-Again &quot; } had an illegitimate baby with Mayor Quimby, { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { She Used to Be My Girl &quot; } and flirted with Homer. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Large Marge &quot; } She is friends with Lindsey Naegle. She is a Republican. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { You Kent Always Say What You Want &quot; } She is played by MacNeille with a strong and harsh Asian accent. [ Corporal Punishment ] Corporal Punishment is a cast member on the Krusty the Clown show. He first appeared in the episode Itchy &amp; Scratchy &amp; Marge as the enforcer for the show. He is a large man and is always seen in military uniform. [ Crazy Cat Lady ] Eleanor Abernathy { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { See Homer Run &quot; } (voiced by Tress MacNeille ), better known as the Crazy Cat Lady, is a woman with the appearance and behavior of a stereotypical mentally ill person. She first appears in &quot; Girly Edition &quot;. Abernathy is always surrounded by a large number of cats, and in every appearance she screams gibberish and/or throws cats at passersby. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Girly Edition. &quot; } She gives Lisa one of her cats, Snowball V, who looks exactly like her original Snowball II. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { I, (Annoyed Grunt)-Bot &quot; } Abernathy has an unfortunate past. When she was eight, she was a smart and ambitious young girl who wanted to be both a lawyer and a doctor &quot; because a woman can do anything &quot;. She was studying for law school at 16, and by 24 she had earned a law degree from Yale Law School and a medical degree from Harvard Medical School. However, by 32, suffering from burnout, she had turned to alcohol and became obsessed with her pet cat. By the time she turned 40, she had assumed her present state as a drunken, raving lunatic. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Springfield Up &quot; } Abernathy briefly reverts to her sanity and high intelligence thanks to some pills that she shows the Simpsons, but after Marge points out that the pills are actually Reese&apos;s Pieces candy, Abernathy abruptly resumes her deranged behavior. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Homer and Ned&apos;s Hail Mary Pass &quot; } When participating in a mayoral election, she lucidly discusses topics such as health care, economy and public education in between her screams and gibberish. In the episode &quot; Eeny Teeny Maya Moe, &quot; Abernathy reveals that she once owned a cat with Moe Syzlak after he says that there &quot; Is a much creepier guy right next to me. &quot; from a public library computer. She yells &quot; You know I&apos;m a woman! &quot; and also that their cat had kittens; she then proclaims that &quot; These are yours! &quot; and insanely throws three cats at him.In the episode &quot; A Midsummer&apos;s Nice Dream, &quot; Abernathy is shown to be a hoarder. After Marge helps her clean up her house, she begins speaking normally and wearing proper clothing. Later, in an attempt to fix Marge&apos;s new hoarding problem, Abernathy reverts back to her crazy self, reclaiming all of the hoarded junk and calling her cats back to her. { &apos;&apos;The Simpsons episode &quot; } { A Midsummer&apos;s Nice Dream &quot; } [ Crusher and Lowblow ] Crusher (also referred to as Joey) and Lowblow are a pair of stereotypical henchmen often found in the employment of Montgomery Burns as he prefers the hands-on touch you only get with hired goons. Crusher&apos;s first appearance was in the second season episode &quot; Blood Feud &quot; where he is seen escorting Homer off the premises of the Springfield Nuclear Power Plant. The two seem to be on first name terms as Homer calls him Joey. Their first appearance together was in the episode &quot; Last Exit to Springfield &quot; when the two of them kidnap Homer and take him to Burns Manor. They introduce themselves as &apos;Hired Goons&apos;, a term that Homer apparently is not familiar with. The pair rarely had speaking roles and were often used as Mr Burns&apos; goons for a number of early episodes but eventually they became background characters. [ Database ] Database, or Data, (real name unknown to viewers) is a nerd y student who attends Springfield Elementary School. He first appeared in the episode &quot; Bart&apos;s Comet &quot; as a member of &quot; the Super Friends &quot;. He has since had speaking parts in several episodes. He is usually seen with his fellow nerd Martin Prince. Database is a common target for Nelson, Dolph, Jimbo, and Kearney. Database is part of the group of boys who invade Shelbyville in &quot; Lemon of Troy &quot;. He is one of the Pre-Teen Braves in the episode &quot; The Bart of War &quot;. He is a member of the school band, as seen in &quot; The PTA Disbands &quot;. Database is known for his annoying, nerdy voice which is supplied by Nancy Cartwright. Database&apos;s father is shown in &quot; Lemon of Troy &quot;, although he utters no dialogue and is only in the background and has not appeared since that episode. Matt Groening has stated that Database is his least favorite character in the show. { Groening, Matt (2005).
