(Part Two) &quot; } { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Three Men and a Comic Book &quot; } { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { $pringfield &quot; } [ Declan Desmond ] Declan Desmond (voiced by Eric Idle of Monty Python fame) is an odd and skeptical British documentary filmmaker who has directed several films, including Do You Want Lies with That?, American Boneheads: A Day In The Life Of Springfield Elementary, Growing Up Springfield,Ain’t No Mountain: A Blind Man Climbs Everest and &quot; The Spy Who Learned Me &quot;. Growing Up Springfield is his most notable documentary. It follows the lives of the inhabitants of Springfield, starting when they were in third grade and continuing every eight years. It is a parody of Michael Apted ’s Up Series. Desmond appeared in the episodes &quot; &apos;Scuse Me While I Miss the Sky &quot; and &quot; Fat Man And Little Boy &quot; and his Growing Up Springfield series were featured in the episode &quot; Springfield Up &quot;. The character is based on real British filmmakers David Attenborough and Desmond Morris [ January 2009 ]. [ Dewey Largo ] Dewey Largo, voiced by Harry Shearer, is the music teacher, whom Lisa credited with proving that any piece of music could have the soul sucked out of it. He is very uncreative and is a poor, pathetic music conductor. He is always seen in the opening sequence, teaching his class and throwing Lisa out of his band class when she plays a funky/jazzy tune on her saxophone. His last name Largo is also an Italian word for a slow, broad musical tempo, a possible reference to the fact that he can make any piece of music uninteresting. He has not played a large role in the series, but was originally intended to be an uptight foil for Lisa, and her non-conformist ways. After the first few seasons, Mr. Largo was rarely seen. However he has since resurfaced as a recurring character in the seventeenth season, making appearances in several episodes. In the 17th season in the episode &quot; Homer&apos;s Paternity Coot &quot; it is revealed that Largo was accepted to the Juilliard School, but never got the letter as it was frozen atop Mount Springfield. He ended up at Springfield Elementary instead. A recurring gag since the 17th season episode &quot; See Homer Run &quot;, are allusions that Largo is gay. The 22nd season episode &quot; Flaming Moe &quot; confirmed Largo is gay and in a relationship with an older man. [ Disco Stu ] Disco Stu, real name Stuart Discotheque { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Homer Scissorhands &quot; } (voiced by Hank Azaria ) is a man who is mentally stuck in the disco era. { The Simpsons episode &quot; } { Two Bad Neighbors &quot; } He is normally featured wearing a rhinestone-encrusted leisure suit. Stu was introduced as the punchline to a joke in &quot; Two Bad Neighbors &quot;. In a garage sale, Homer attempts to sell a jacket on which he had once tried to write &quot; Disco Stud &quot; in rhinestone s, but having made the letters too big he did not have room for the final &quot; d &quot;. After Marge remarks that nobody would ever want to buy a jacket that read &quot; Disco Stu &quot;, another customer recommends it to Stu, but Stu replies, &quot; Disco Stu doesn&apos;t advertise. &quot; Stu&apos;s speech pattern is similar to that of Duffman, also voiced by Hank Azaria; he speaks in the third person, often referring to himself as &quot; Disco Stu &quot; (emphasizing &quot; Stu &quot; and then pausing before saying anything else; whatever follows usually rhymes with &quot; Stu &quot; ). According to &quot; How I Spent My Strummer Vacation &quot;, Stu actually is aware disco is dead, does not like disco music at all, and worries that his personality may make him a &quot; one-note guy &quot;. [ Dolph Starbeam ] Dolphin &quot; Dolph &quot; Starbeam, voiced by Tress MacNeille, is a bully and student at Springfield Elementary School. Dolph is recognized by his asymmetrical haircut which covers one eye and wears cutoff shorts and basketball shoes. He is left-handed and does not talk as much as the other bullies. He usually comes across as very intelligent and speaks a variety of languages including Esperanto, Swahili, and Klingon. It turns out Dolph is Jewish and attends Hebrew school. Despite the fact that he appears to be wholly Caucasian, in the episode &quot; Little Big Girl &quot; he shows up to multicultural day with a disked lower lip, suggesting some African or South American descent. He lied to his friends about not having a bar mitzvah, later claiming it had been &quot; just family &quot;. He has also mentioned the fact that he has two fathers. Dolph was named after one of Matt Groening&apos;s classmates from Lincoln High School named Dolph Timmerman. Groening stated that Timmerman was not a bully but just a real cool guy. [ Drederick Tatum ] Drederick Tatum (voiced by Hank Azaria ) has appeared in several episodes. He is a professional boxer and the reigning World Heavyweight Champion. He features prominently in the episode &quot; The Homer They Fall &quot;, in which Homer takes up boxing and is lined up as an opponent for Tatum, soon to be released from prison. The fight proves one-sided, and Homer is rescued by Moe just as he is about to be knocked out by Tatum. Tatum grew up in Springfield, but in &quot; Flaming Moe&apos;s &quot; he calls the city &quot; a dump &quot; and says &quot; if you ever see me back there, you know I really fu*#ed up bad! &quot; A former 1984 Olympic Gold medalist, he first became champion after defeating Watson in the heavily promoted &quot; Bout to Knock the Other Guy Out! &quot;, a fight Homer and his friends watched on his illegal cable hookup. He was so feared inside prison he could stop riots just by telling the rioters to shut up. Tatum also appears in &quot; Bye Bye Nerdie &quot;. Lisa tests her nerd spray on him, which forces Nelson Muntz to involuntarily get up and start punching Tatum, to little effect. A sobbing Nelson tries to apologise but Tatum rolls up his sleeves and declares &quot; you leave me little recourse! &quot; Tatum is a parody of Mike Tyson, with a high-pitched lisping voice, a menacing demeanor, a criminal record, financial problems and a tendency to make pseudo-intellectual comments like &quot; I insist that you desist &quot; and &quot; your behavior is unconscionable &quot;. He also has an unscrupulous manager named Lucius Sweet, who closely resembles Tyson&apos;s promoter/manager Don King. Indeed, in &quot; The Homer They Fall &quot; Homer notes that Sweet &quot; is as rich and famous as Don King, and looks just like him &quot;. King and Tyson were asked to appear in the episode but declined. Paul Winfield, who played King in a 1995 Tyson biopic, took the role instead. Duffman is a muscular actor, dressed in a superhero costume who spouts slogans while he thrusts his hips. Commentary for &quot; } { Bart vs. Thanksgiving &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Second Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } [ Elizabeth Hoover ] Elizabeth Hoover is a second grade teacher at Springfield Elementary, voiced by Maggie Roswell and Marcia Mitzman Gaven while Roswell was involved in a pay dispute. Miss Hoover has been worn down by her years in the public school system, and in Lisa Gets an &quot; A &quot; implies that she frequently drinks during lunch. In the episode Lisa&apos;s Substitute, she thought she had lyme disease. She is very apathetic and bored with her job, and seems overwhelmed with stress, seeking whatever remedies she can to alleviate it. She is often seen smoking even while teaching, once even under a &quot; No Smoking &quot; sign in the assembly hall. Her desperate attempts to regain her stability include rushing out of class to recite &quot; Calm blue ocean, calm blue ocean &quot; with her eyes closed, getting into her car and driving off on two occasions, and even letting Ralph teach the class when she was granted tenure. When the series began Miss Hoover&apos;s hair was pale blue, but from Season 4 onwards, she has had brown hair, presumably because of stress. [ March 2012 ] [ Fallout Boy ] In the series, Fallout Boy first appears in a 1950s Radioactive Man serial film shown at a comic book convention in the episode &quot; Three Men and a Comic Book. &quot; However, unlike many Simpsons characters, he has only made a handful of appearances since. While Radioactive Man is a broad parody of many superheroes, most obviously containing elements of Batman and Superman (and the comic incorporates an origin story similar to Marvel &apos;s Hulk ), among others, Fallout Boy is mainly a parody of Robin (with his costume, references as being the &apos;young ward&apos; of Radioactive Man, and his younger age and sidekick status) with elements of Spider-Man (his fictional comic book origin, for example). His catchphrase is &quot; Jiminy Jillickers! &quot; Additionally, Fallout Boy also appears in a real-life comic book titled Radioactive Man, published by Bongo Comics (a comic created in part by Matt Groening, the creator of The Simpsons). In these comic books, Fallout Boy&apos;s real name is Rod Runtledge, he has a brother named Dodd Runtledge, and they live in Zenith City. Rod is a high school nerd living with his aunt, Aunt June. Fallout Boy was an average book worm, until one day, he was at a Radioactive demonstration, where he met up with Claude Kane. A tall piece of machinery fell towards them. Claude grabbed Rod and jumped over the rail, Claude holding onto the machine. The machine came to life, and as the ray passed through Claude, who became Radioactive Man, it hit Rod. Rod then got a pint sized version of RM&apos;s powers, and became Fallout Boy. In the episode &quot; Radioactive Man &quot;, Milhouse was chosen over Bart to play Fallout Boy in the Radioactive Man movie to be filmed in Springfield. Rock band Fall Out Boy took the name of this character after, when they asked a concert audience what band name they should have, a fan shouted &quot; Fallout Boy! &quot; [ Frankie the Squealer ] Frankie the Squealer is a member of the Mafia and associate of Fat Tony. However, he does not appear to be very useful to his colleagues in criminal activity due to his uncontrollable habit of squealing (he claims that &quot; it makes [him] feel big &quot; ), even squealing on himself one time. On several occasions, the mob has attempted to kill him for his squealing, though they have repeatedly been unsuccessful. Frankie first appeared in episode &quot; Insane Clown Poppy &quot; where his squealing habits are introduced after he squeals on himself for squealing. [ Gil Gunderson ] Gil Gunderson, a.k.a. [ http://www.wga.org/subpage_newsevents.aspx?id%3D2764 2008 Writers Guild Awards Winners Announced -- 2008-02-09 WGAW ] [ Gloria ] Gloria, voiced by Julia Louis-Dreyfus is Snake &apos;s girlfriend. [ God ] God, voiced by Harry Shearer, has had many appearances in the series, including &quot; Homer the Heretic &quot;, &quot; Thank God, It&apos;s Doomsday &quot;, and a scene with Him, Buddha, and Colonel Sanders in &quot; Pray Anything &quot;, as well as appearing in the flick across the town in the opening sequence (in the HD episodes) where he is fighting with the devil. He is portrayed in the traditional depiction of the Abrahamic God : a gray-haired man in a white robe with a booming voice. In most episodes, only his beard is seen as the camera only films him up to the shoulders. His body is usually surrounded by a glowing light, and his robes float around him, though not always. He does not seem to be all-knowing. Another notable characteristic of him is his ability to forgive and tolerate Homer&apos;s mishaps, despite his later often heretical attitude. He is on good and even friendly terms with Homer, but he would not hesitate to severely punish him if Homer become too obnoxious. One of God&apos;s distinctive features is that he and Jesus are the only two Simpsons characters to be drawn with five fingers on each hand and five toes on each foot, though not always. [ Grady and Julio ] Grady, voiced by Scott Thompson and Julio, voiced by Hank Azaria are two gay men who become Homer&apos;s roommates when he leaves Marge in &quot; Three Gays of the Condo &quot;. Julio reappears in &quot; There&apos;s Something About Marrying &quot;, marrying another man, in &quot; I Don&apos;t Wanna Know Why the Caged Bird Sings &quot; as one of the bank robbery hostages, and has speaking cameos in &quot; Eternal Moonshine of the Simpson Mind &quot; and &quot; E Pluribus Wiggum &quot;. He appeared in the episode &quot; Four Great Women and a Manicure &quot;, in which he was seen as &quot; King Julio &quot; in Lisa&apos;s first story, &quot; Elizabeth the First &quot;. He works as a photographer, as seen in &quot; The Devil Wears Nada &quot;. Grady made his second appearance to date in &quot; Homer and Lisa Exchange Cross Words &quot;, in which he persuades Homer to break up his (Grady&apos;s) relationship with Julio, so that he could pursue a relationship with Duffman. Julio made further appearances as Marge&apos;s Hairdresser in &quot; The Blue and the Gray &quot; and &quot; Homer Scissorhands &quot;. [ Gunter and Ernst ] Gunter and Ernst, Las Vegas-style entertainers voiced by Harry Shearer and Hank Azaria, are obvious parodies of Siegfried &amp; Roy : they speak with German accents, their act involves magic and white tiger s, and one has black hair while the other has bleached-blond hair. The duo appear in the episodes &quot; Viva Ned Flanders &quot;, &quot; $pringfield &quot;, &quot; The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons &quot;, and &quot; Jazzy and the Pussycats &quot;. In &quot; Jazzy and the Pussycats &quot;, they are seen at Amber Simpson&apos;s funeral. In &quot; The Simpsons Game &quot; it is revealed they performed at an aquarium. In a case of life imitating art, the 1993 episode &quot; $pringfield &quot; (the first episode featuring Gunter and Ernst) depicts the duo being savagely mauled by their trademark white tiger, Anastasia. Ten years later, the trained white tiger Montecore dragged Roy Horn off-stage by his neck during a performance at The Mirage. According to the DVD commentary on this episode on the Simpsons season five DVD set, the part where Gunter and Ernst get attacked is considered &quot; the greatest prediction &quot; the Simpsons ever made, but it was &quot; bound to happen &quot; considering how the tiger was treated. [ The Happy Little Elves ] The Happy Little Elves are a parody of The Smurfs, who appeared more often in the show&apos;s earlier episodes. They are a favorite of Lisa and Maggie Simpson. Bart, however, hates them; he mainly refers to them as either &quot; those stupid elves &quot; &quot; The Crappy Little Elves &quot;, or &quot; The Little Green Idiots &quot;. Their movies include Return of the Happy Little Elves, an unnamed Christmas movie as seen in &quot; Simpsons Roasting on an Open Fire &quot;, The Happy Little Elves Meet The Curious Bear Cubs, The Happy Little Elves in Tinkly Winkly Town, and The Happy Little Elves meet Fuzzy Snuggleduck (which was listed as an R-rated movie along with Thelma &amp; Louise and The Erotic Awakening of S on Rancho Relaxo&apos;s cable system). They were first mentioned in a short on The Tracey Ullman Show entitled &quot; Scary Movie &quot;. The most recent appearance they had was in &quot; Lisa Simpson, This Isn&apos;t Your Life &quot; in November 2010. In more current episodes, they appear as wall decorations in Maggie&apos;s and Lisa&apos;s rooms. [ Helen Lovejoy ] Helen Lovejoy (née Schwartzbaum), voiced by Maggie Roswell and Marcia Mitzman Gaven, is Rev. Lovejoy ’s judgmental and gossip y wife, and the mother of Jessica Lovejoy. She introduced herself in the episode &quot; Life on the Fast Lane &quot; as &quot; the gossipy wife of the minister. &quot; Her catchphrase is &quot; What about the children?! Won&apos;t somebody &apos;&apos;please&apos;&apos; think of the children !? &quot; which she always says among a crowd when something bad is happening in the city. In &quot; Wedding for Disaster &quot;, the Parson remarks to Reverend Lovejoy that he remembers when Helen Lovejoy was Helen Schwartzbaum and prior to that, Harold Schwartzbaum, before deciding he has said too much, implying that Helen was not always a woman, however this is directly contradicted as in flashbacks she is shown to be a girl as a child, and the fact that she and Reverend Lovejoy have a biological daughter in Jessica. In E Pluribus Wiggum, it was revealed that Helen is a member of the Springfield Republican Caucus while in one of their dungeon meetings. In the Treehouse of Horror XX, she is revealed to be Lisa&apos;s Godmother. [ Herman ] Herman Larson, voiced by Harry Shearer, is the owner of Herman&apos;s Military Antiques. He is a right-arm above-elbow amputee; he tells Bart that the arm was lost when he stuck it out the window of a moving bus as a kid. A brilliant military tactician, Herman was instrumental in Bart’s victory in water balloon combat against Nelson and in the negotiation of the peace treaty between the two combatants in &quot; Bart the General &quot;, which is his most significant and first appearance. He is friends with Abraham Simpson, to whom he sold a fez, claiming it was previously owned by Napoleon; Herman then advertised Abe&apos;s old hat as &quot; the hat McKinley was shot in &quot;. He also tried to sell counterfeit jeans out of the Simpsons&apos; garage, but was foiled by Marge Simpson. He once captured Chief Wiggum and Snake and held them hostage, but was accidentally knocked out by Milhouse with a medieval mace, rescuing them. Harry Shearer does an impression of George H.W. Bush for the voice. { Groening, Matt (2001). Commentary for &quot; } { Bart the General &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete First Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } Herman&apos;s facial appearance is modeled after Simpsons writer John Swartzwelder. The original idea behind Herman, said Groening, was that each time he appeared, he would give a different explanation for how he lost his arm. However, the second joke, involving Herman having stuck his arm in a ball return at a bowling alley, got cut, and the writers never pursued the idea. { Groening, Matt (2006). Commentary for &quot; } { Treehouse of Horror VIII &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Ninth Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } [ Janey Powell ] Janey Powell, voiced by Pamela Hayden, is a classmate and friend of Lisa Simpson. Janey first appeared in &quot; Bart the General &quot; and was once Lisa&apos;s closest friend. She has been at Lisa&apos;s sleepover s, and Lisa is seen watching cartoons at her house on numerous occasions. Her description on The Simpsons POG set described her as &quot; Lisa&apos;s fair-weather friend &quot;. Though she is sometimes seen spending time with Lisa, other times she teases her along with the other children. She is not portrayed as being nearly as intelligent or nerdy as Lisa. Janey may have had a crush on Milhouse Van Houten, who has a crush on Lisa. She enjoys reading babysitting books. [ Jasper Beardly ] Jasper Beardly, voiced by Harry Shearer is one of the elder residents of Springfield, often portrayed as Abraham Simpson &apos;s best friend. His most distinguishing features are his ultra-low, gravelly voice and very long beard. Jasper made his first appearance in &quot; Homer&apos;s Odyssey &quot;. He is a veteran of World War II, but (according to the episode &quot; Marge and Homer Turn a Couple Play &quot; ) he attempted to avoid the draft by disguising himself as a woman. He stayed in Springfield to play in the local women&apos;s baseball league, along with his friend Abe, who was also avoiding the war but was exposed during a game. In a deleted scene, it was shown that Jasper was the town pastor, prior to Reverend Lovejoy. He briefly served as substitute teacher of Lisa&apos;s class during which time he confiscated everything made of tin, got his beard caught in a pencil sharpener and threatened paddling for minor infractions such as looking out the window or talking out of turn. In the subplot of the season nine episode, &quot; Lisa the Simpson &quot;, Jasper put himself in crude &quot; suspended animation &quot; in the Kwik-E-Mart &apos;s freezer, and under advice from Dr. Nick Riviera, Apu kept him frozen. When Jasper&apos;s frozen form became popular with customers, Apu started exploiting the spectacle, and transformed the Kwik-E-Mart into a special interest store dealing with weird items, or perfectly ordinary ones which had been made out to be abnormal, called the Freak-E-Mart. Jasper was accidentally unfrozen, and stepped out into what he thought was a future world, just as Apu was considering selling him to the Rich Texan. In the episode &quot; I Don&apos;t Wanna Know Why the Caged Bird Sings &quot; Jasper mentions he is a diabetic. [ Jebediah Springfield ] Jebediah Obadiah Zachariah Jedediah Springfield (a.k.a. Hans Sprungfeld) is the founder of the town of Springfield. He is voiced by Harry Shearer. According to legend, Jebediah Springfield and his partner Shelbyville Manhattan, led a band that left Maryland in search of &quot; New Sodom &quot; due to a misinterpretation of the Bible, but they parted ways over political differences: though both men are devoted to chastity and abstinence, Manhattan wanted to let people be free to marry their cousins if they wish, to which Springfield strongly opposes. It was then Manhattan went on to found the rival town of Shelbyville, taking half of the settlers with him. Springfield had many famous quotations, such as &quot; A noble spirit embiggens the smallest man &quot;. He also wears a coonskin cap. The Springfield Marathon commemorates an occasion on which he ran across six states in order to avoid his creditors. In &quot; The Telltale Head &quot; Bart beheaded the statue, thinking that this would make him more popular. In reality, the town became depressed and angry, leaving Bart to endure &quot; The Tell-Tale Heart &quot; -style guilt before replacing it. This episode is referenced in multiple Simpsons video games such as The Simpsons: Bart vs. the Space Mutants, where the statue&apos;s head serves as a power-up item, or The Simpsons Road Rage and The Simpsons Hit &amp; Run, where characters can kick or ram Jebediah&apos;s head off the statue. Many Jebediah legends have been debunked during the run of the series. For instance, &quot; The Telltale Head &quot; repeatedly refers to Jebediah killing a bear with his bare hands, but on the news, Kent Brockman reveals that recent historical evidence suggests the bear actually killed Jebediah. On an expedition to Springfield&apos;s historic &quot; Fort Springfield &quot;, Bart uncovers other inconsistencies in the Jebediah legend, such as that he fought at Fort Ticonderoga the same day as the first Whacking Day. Most of Springfield&apos;s biography is revealed in the 1996 episode &quot; Lisa the Iconoclast &quot;, wherein Lisa Simpson discovers Jebediah Springfield&apos;s biggest secret: he was formerly a bloodthirsty pirate named Hans Sprungfeld, who once brawled with George Washington and lost after Washington crushed Sprungfeld&apos;s genitals in one of his sets of iron false teeth. Sprungfeld fled and changed his name in 1795 to hide his identity. He was well known for his &quot; silver tongue &quot; (literally; a metal prosthetic tongue, his original tongue having been bitten off by a Turkish pirate in a grog house fight). Before he died of diphtheria, he wrote his confession on a scrap of canvas that he hid in a fife. The canvas scrap formed the &quot; missing piece &quot; of the famously incomplete 1796 Gilbert Stuart portrait of George Washington; Sprungfeld picked it up during a fight against Washington which occurred while the latter was having his portrait painted. Lisa decides not to reveal this secret to the people of Springfield, seeing that the myth of Jebediah has brought out the good in everyone and that the true story will cause them to lose hope and morale within themselves. The Australian rock-band &quot; Jebediah &quot; was named after Jebediah Springfield. [ Jimbo Jones ] Corky James &quot; Jimbo &quot; Jones, voiced by Pamela Hayden and originally by Tress MacNeille in his first appearance in the first season episode &quot; The Telltale Head &quot; is a lowlife who wears a purple knit cap and a black T-shirt emblazoned with a menacing skull. He can often be seen hanging around Kearney, Dolph, and sometimes Nelson. He is generally acknowledged as the leader of this clique. He enjoys intimidating his schoolmates and shoplifting. It is hinted that he comes from a well-off family, most notably in season six&apos;s &quot; The PTA Disbands &quot; when  — with the school closed for a teacher&apos;s strike - he and his mother watch soap opera s and sip tea together in a very nice living room. In season seven&apos;s Bart the Fink, Bart discovers that Jimbo&apos;s real name is Corky. Jimbo&apos;s other known aliases are Jamesbo, Dr. J and Hector Gutierrez. Jimbo is named for executive producer James L. Brooks. { Jean, Al (2001). Commentary for &quot; } { The Telltale Head &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete First Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } Jimbo runs for mayor in the Season 17 episode &quot; See Homer Run &quot;, with a campaign slogan of &quot; Tough on Nerds. Tougher on Dorks. &quot; [ Johnny Tightlips ] Johnny &quot; John &quot; Tightlips, voiced by Hank Azaria, is a member of the Mafia and associate of Fat Tony. He says very little, which spares him from accusations of being a &quot; squealer &quot;, but his reticence tends to be unhelpful to others and even himself. In &quot; The Twisted World of Marge Simpson &quot; he tries to help Fat Tony in taking away Marge&apos;s earnings from her &apos;Pretzel Wagon&apos; franchise. In &quot; Insane Clown Poppy &quot;, there is a shoot-out in Fat Tony&apos;s mansion and Tightlips is shot by accident. When asked where he&apos;s injured, he says &quot; I ain&apos;t sayin&apos; nuthin&apos;! &quot;, and when asked what to tell the doctor he says, &quot; Tell him to suck a lemon. &quot; [ http://www.snpp.com/episodes/BABF17 Insane Clown Poppy The Simpsons Archive 2008-04-12 ] [ Jub-Jub ] Jub-Jub is Selma Bouvier &apos;s pet iguana and was originally owned by Aunt Gladys. It was first seen in &quot; Selma&apos;s Choice &quot;. Gladys gives Jub-Jub to Jacqueline Bouvier, who is highly unattached to it. As a result, she later passes it on to Selma. Selma once said that Jub-Jub will eat her remains upon her death. The name Jub-Jub was coined by then-writer Conan O&apos;Brien. [ Stern, David 2004 The Simpsons The Complete Fourth Season DVD commentary for the episode &quot; Selma&apos;s Choice &quot; DVD 20th Century Fox ] He often said nonsensical things around the office for no apparent reason, one of which was &quot; Jub-Jub &quot;. (There is, however, a Jubjub bird in The Hunting of the Snark.) Fans of Sportsradio 1310 in Dallas voted that Jub-Jub be the new nickname of morning radio host George Dunham. O&apos;Brien, on October 17, 2007, mentioned his creation of Jub Jub and asked Joe Buck, the play-by-play commentator of the MLB World Series on FOX, to say it during his broadcast. O&apos;Brien promised $1,000.00 to the charity of the announcer&apos;s choice. On October 24, 2007, during Game 1 of the 2007 World Series, Buck called field level reporter, Chris Myers, &quot; our own little Jub-Jub. &quot; Jub-Jub was used as the first Twitter hash tag for O&apos;Brien&apos;s &quot; Legally Prohibited from Being Funny on Television Tour &quot; in 2010. [ Judge Constance Harm ] Judge Constance Harm, voiced by repeat guest star actress Jane Kaczmarek, is a harsh, unforgiving disciplinarian. { The Simpsons &quot; } { The Parent Rap &quot; - November 4, 2001 } She enjoys creating cruel punishments for criminals in her court and frightening them with a miniature guillotine on the bench. She might be a transsexual based on a statement she makes during her first appearance in &quot; The Parent Rap &quot; : &quot; you remind me of me, when I was a little boy &quot;. Her name is a play on &quot; constant harm &quot;. The character is a parody of Judge Judy. In &quot; On a Clear Day I Can&apos;t See My Sister &quot;, she reveals she has a husband. Although Judge Snyder resolves court cases, Judge Harm has mainly been used for handing down negative verdicts, such as sentencing a family member to prison. She also appears in &quot; Brawl in the Family &quot;, &quot; Barting Over &quot;, &quot; The Wandering Juvie &quot;, &quot; Brake My Wife, Please &quot; and &quot; Chief of Hearts &quot;. { The Simpsons &quot; } { Brake My Wife, Please &quot; - May 11, 2003 } [ Judge Snyder ] Judge Roy Snyder, voiced by Harry Shearer, { Gimple, p. 87 } is a Springfield judge known for his lenient punishments and somewhat unorthodox rulings (as in the episode &quot; Sweets and Sour Marge, &quot; when he bans sugar from Springfield). The character was originally named &quot; Judge Moulton &quot;, but show runners Bill Oakley and Josh Weinstein did not know that, and called him &quot; Snyder &quot;. { Oakley, Bill; Weinstein, Josh (2005). [ Dr. J. Loren Pryor ] Dr. J. Loren Pryor, voiced by Harry Shearer, is the school psychologist. He is based on an early design for Seymour Skinner, and first appears in &quot; Bart the Genius &quot; where he decides to send Bart to a school for gifted children after Bart cheats on a test. Bart later approaches him to request returning to Springfield Elementary. In &quot; Bart Gets an F &quot;, he tells Bart that he may have to repeat the fourth grade. He appears again, discussing Bart&apos;s problems at school and Lisa&apos;s special gift in a flashback sequence of &quot; Lisa&apos;s Sax &quot;. In this episode he also inadvertently reveals that Milhouse Van Houten possesses &quot; flamboyantly homosexual &quot; tendencies. Pryor does not appear again for several years until the episode &quot; See Homer Run &quot;, in which he tells Lisa that she is going through a developmental condition. [ Kearney Zzyzwicz ] Kearney Zzyzwicz, voiced by Nancy Cartwright, is one of Springfield Elementary&apos;s many bullies. He has a buzz cut, and wears a torn white T-shirt, blue shorts, and studded wristbands. Although he looks and sounds to be around Jimbo or Dolph &apos;s age, Kearney is actually older. He is the only Springfield Elementary School student who remembers the Watergate Scandal and the 1976 Bicenntenial (according to Principal Skinner), was in Otto the bus driver&apos;s third-grade class (according to Otto), owns a car (even though he rode the school bus on &quot; A Milhouse Divided &quot;, &quot; The Mook, the Chef, the Wife, and Her Homer &quot;, and &quot; How the Test Was Won &quot; ), regularly shaves, has custody of a child from a divorce, is old enough to vote in a general U.S. election, was sent to prison, and pays taxes. In &quot; She of Little Faith &quot;, Kearney dated Jimbo&apos;s mother. In the same episode, it is revealed that he is on the church council of the First Church of Springfield and is &quot; a teenager and the parent of a teenager &quot;. [ She of Little Faith She of Little Faith The Simpsons The Simpsons 2001-12-16 13 6 ] Kearney often relies on (or tricks) Homer into procuring alcohol for himself and his friends (as seen in &quot; The Springfield Connection &quot;, &quot; Simpsoncalifragilisticexpiala(Annoyed Grunt)cious &quot;, and &quot; Last Tap Dance in Springfield &quot; ), and once used a fake ID (as seen in &quot; Much Apu About Nothing &quot; ), though it is heavily implied that Kearney is of the legal age to buy alcohol for himself (as in &quot; El Viaje Misterioso de Nuestro Jomer &quot;, in which he is seen drinking at Moe&apos;s Tavern ). Kearney&apos;s last name (Zzyzwicz) was revealed in a computer file in season 18&apos;s &quot; 24 Minutes &quot;. Prior to that episode, Kearney&apos;s surname was never mentioned. In &quot; Bart Gets a &apos;Z&apos; &quot;, Kearney can be seen sitting in the back row of Bart&apos;s classroom, implying that Kearney is a fourth grader. Kearney&apos;s father was shown on the season eight episode &quot; The Homer They Fall &quot;, but in &quot; O Brother, Where Bart Thou? &quot;, Kearney reveals that both of his parents are incarcerated and they only meet when the prison and insane asylum have their annual mixer. [ Kirk Van Houten ] Kirk Van Houten is voiced by Hank Azaria. He is the father of Milhouse, and the remarried husband of Luann Van Houten. He wears glasses just like his son and wife. He first appeared in &quot; Bart&apos;s Friend Falls in Love &quot;. Kirk has been portrayed as a stereotypical middle-aged male loser and deadbeat dad. Much of his character revolves around his extreme emotional depression after his divorce from his wife Luann. Luann got custody of Milhouse when they divorced, but Kirk has visiting rights and is often seen with Milhouse in later episodes. Kirk suffers from the need to cry all the time after his divorce, even in good times. The Van Houtens remarried in the nineteenth season episode &quot; Little Orphan Millie &quot;. In that episode it was established that Kirk is of Dutch and Danish ancestry. Kirk previously served in the U.S. Army, and attended Gudger College. Apparently Kirk&apos;s mother is of Greek ancestry, based on the nineteenth season episode &quot; Husbands and Knives &quot;. In the episode, Milhouse says, &quot; But that&apos;s the money Yaya Sophia gave me for Greek Orthodox Easter! &quot;. According to Luann, Kirk was not a very good provider, and she had to borrow money from her sister to make ends meet. When Luann demands a divorce, Kirk is all too happy to oblige. Unfortunately, he loses his middle-management job at Southern Cracker, a job given to him by Luann&apos;s father, as a result. Kirk briefly attempts a career as a singer-songwriter, recording a demo tape of an original song titled &quot; Can I Borrow A Feeling &quot;, with mediocre results. Later, he attempts to win Luann back by singing the song to her. Luann does not reciprocate Kirk&apos;s feelings, choosing instead to remain with her boyfriend. Kirk reveals in the episode &quot; I Am Furious Yellow &quot;, where he visits his son&apos;s school on career day, that he was currently employed as an assistant to the guy who puts fliers under people&apos;s windshield wipers. Kirk also had a job standing on the curb holding a sign directing people to a condo development and worked as a scarecrow protecting a soy-bean crop, which resulted in his eye being gouged by a crow. Since being fired from the cracker company, Kirk seems to be unable to maintain a steady job. He once shouted at Luann that she had to keep up the alimony payments she owed him, and he has been seen at the Springfield unemployment office, perhaps suggesting that alimony and unemployment benefits are his only steady sources of income. Kirk was put in jail in the episode &quot; Pranksta Rap &quot; for &quot; kidnapping &quot; Bart which he greatly enjoyed due to him being envied by women and fed three meals a day. In The Simpsons Movie, Kirk is briefly seen attending an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting. [ Laura Powers ] Laura Powers, voiced by Sara Gilbert is the teenage daughter of Ruth Powers. Her first and only appearance is in the episode &quot; New Kid on the Block &quot; when she and Ruth move in next door to the Simpsons. When Marge and Homer ask her to babysit Bart, Lisa and Maggie, Bart immediately develops a crush on her. However he is shocked to find out that she is dating local bully Jimbo Jones whom she later breaks up with after Moe threatens to kill Jimbo over a prank call that Bart made. Ruth mentions Laura in &quot; Marge On The Lam &quot; when Ruth tells Marge that she has to head home before her daughter watches &quot; that naked talk show. &quot; [ Legs and Louie ] Legs, voiced by Karl Wiedergott (formerly voiced by Hank Azaria ), and Louie, voiced by Dan Castellaneta, are the two Springfield Mafia hitmen who accompany Fat Tony at all times. The two lack any real definitive characteristic and are almost always seen together. Legs has a dark blonde short haircut and raspy voice. Louie has a slight black afro and a more high-pitched, even squeaky tone. Castellaneta based the voice on actor Joe Pesci, one of the several references to Goodfellas used in the episode &quot; Bart the Murderer &quot;. { Castellaneta, Dan (2009). Commentary for &quot; } { Insane Clown Poppy &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Twelfth Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } Louie says that tear gas is &quot; [his] one weakness, &quot; though this is likely an embellishment. Dan Castellaneta was nominated for Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Voice-Over Performance in 2011 for the voice of Louie, Homer Simpson, Barney Gumble, and Krusty the Clown thanks to the episode Donnie Fatso. [ http://www.emmys.com/nominations/2011/Outstanding%20Voice-Over%20Performance Primetime Emmy Awards nominations for 2011 - Outstanding Voice-Over Performance Emmys.com 2011-10-23 ] [ Leopold ] Leopold, voiced by Dan Castellaneta, is Superintendent Chalmers&apos; assistant. He is a large, surly, snarling man who frequently speaks through clenched teeth, and is one of the few characters on The Simpsons to have eyebrow s. When Principal Skinner has to be temporarily replaced, Leopold stomps in, issues several threats, and terrifies the children by making them think he is the replacement, and then suddenly politely introduces the actual substitute, Ned Flanders. The children then collectively sigh with relief. The gag was repeated when Marge Simpson becomes a substitute teacher in the episode &quot; The PTA Disbands &quot;. Leopold often refers to the children of Springfield Elementary as &quot; little freaks. &quot; [ http://www.snpp.com/episodes/1F18.html [1F18] Sweet Seymour Skinner&apos;s Baadasssss Song 2008-03-01 Cherry James A. 1996-07-21 Episode transcript The Simpsons Archive (snpp.com) ] [ http://www.snpp.com/episodes/2F19.html [2F19] The PTA Disbands 2008-03-01 Cherry James A. 1997-02-22 Episode transcript The Simpsons Archive (snpp.com) ] [ Lewis ] Lewis Jackson is an African American character, and student at Springfield Elementary School in Bart&apos;s class. He can be seen playing the bassoon in the opening sequence of the show. Although one of the most minor characters in the show, Lewis appears frequently in scenes involving the Springfield children, and occasionally speaks. He is usually seen with Richard. While Lewis has never had significant dialogue, he has been voiced by Nancy Cartwright, Jo Ann Harris, Pamela Hayden, Tress MacNeille, and Russi Taylor throughout the series. [ Lindsey Naegle ] Lindsey Naegle is voiced by Tress MacNeille and first appeared in the eighth season episode &quot; The Itchy &amp; Scratchy &amp; Poochie Show &quot;. { McCann, p. 88 } In that episode, she had no name and was known only as &quot; The Generic Female TV Executive &quot;. She appeared again in &quot; Girly Edition &quot;, also as a generic female TV executive (only her hair and facial features differed from her first appearance). { Gimple, p. 37 } In &quot; They Saved Lisa&apos;s Brain &quot;, she was introduced as &quot; Lindsey Naegle &quot;, a member of the Springfield Chapter of Mensa, and has since become a recurring character. The writers modeled Naegle on a number of network executives that they have encountered while working on the show. { Weinstein, Josh (2006). Commentary for &quot; } { The Itchy &amp; Scratchy &amp; Poochie Show &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Eighth Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } The character gets her last name from Hollywood talent agent Sue Naegle, president of HBO Entertainment and wife of Simpsons writer Dana Gould. { Selman, Matt (2007). Commentary for &quot; } { They Saved Lisa&apos;s Brain &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Tenth Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } [ http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news.aspx?id%3D20080409hbo01 Breaking News  — Sue Naegle Joins HBO as President, HBO Entertainment, Overseeing All Series Programming and Specials Thefutoncritic.com 2009-01-02 ] Writer Matt Selman chose the first name &quot; Lindsey &quot; because he thought it sounded like the name of an annoyingly talkative woman. Naegle prototypes have appeared throughout the series, such as the OmniTouch Rep from &quot; Make Room for Lisa &quot; and Laramie executive Mindy from &quot; E-I-E-I-(Annoyed Grunt) &quot;. { Turner, p. 167 } In &quot; Blame It on Lisa &quot;, it is revealed that she frequently changes jobs because she is a sexual predator. Chris Turner, author of the book Planet Simpson, called Naegle &quot; an excellent allegory for the modern corporate age: you don&apos;t see through her because there&apos;s nothing else to see. &quot; { Turner, p. 168 } Her political allegiances are not concrete: In &quot; You Kent Always Say What You Want, &quot; she is shown at the Republican Party headquarters; in &quot; E Pluribus Wiggum, &quot; Naegle is conversely depicted as a Democrat. [ Lois Pennycandy ] Lois Pennycandy is the beautiful executive assistant to Krusty the Clown. { &quot; } { Like Father, Like Clown &quot; } She swayed Krusty into visiting Bart after he saved Krusty from jail time, { &quot; } { Krusty Gets Busted &quot; } and later reunited him with his estranged father the Rabbi Hyman Krustofski. She was at Krusty&apos;s side during the auditions in which Robert Terwilliger became Krusty&apos;s new sidekick, { &quot; } { Brother from Another Series &quot; } and was at Krusty&apos;s &quot; funeral &quot; when he was presumed dead after crashing his private plane into a cliff. { &quot; } { Bart the Fink &quot; } In a phone conversation, Marge once asked her, &quot; How can [Krusty] hurt someone who loves him so? &quot; While looking at a framed photo of Krusty, Pennycandy replied, &quot; Oh, Mrs. Simpson, I&apos;ve wasted my womanhood asking that same question. &quot; Her only speaking roles are in &quot; Like Father, Like Clown &quot; and &quot; Krusty Gets Kancelled &quot;, in which she was voiced by Pamela Hayden. [ Luann Van Houten ] Luann Van Houten is voiced by Maggie Roswell. When Roswell left the show in 1998, she became a primarily nonspeaking character. However, Roswell returned in 2002. Since the season 8 episode, &quot; A Milhouse Divided &quot;, Luann was depicted as a promiscuous, single mother, who stuck her successful love life in the face of her ex-husband, Kirk. She first appeared in &quot; Homer Defined &quot;. She wears glasses, a trait that she shares with her husband and son. Luann Van Houten&apos;s mother is Italian. She was born in Shelbyville, and moved to Springfield in early life. It is stated in &quot; A Milhouse Divided &quot; that she has a sister. Luann was married to Kirk for several years, giving birth to a son, Milhouse, yet the marriage was an unhappy one. After an argument over a game of Pictionary, she leaves Kirk after he remarks he can&apos;t draw &quot; dignity &quot;, since he gave it up when he married her. Although Kirk found the new liberty of a single life tough, Luann uses her newfound freedom to live life on the fast lane. Luann began dating American Gladiator Pyro shortly after her divorce with Kirk for several seasons, but was caught cheating on him with his best friend, Gyro. In Apu Nahasapeemapetilon &apos;s bachelor years, she had been one of his bachelorettes. In &quot; Milhouse of Sand and Fog &quot;, it is revealed that Luann had also gone out with Disco Stu as well and had begun a relationship with Sea Captain. In &quot; Milhouse of Sand and Fog &quot; the Van Houtens reunited. Since then, they are often seen together (although in the episode &quot; Ice Cream of Margie (with the Light Blue Hair) &quot;, Kirk was seen with Milhouse at a single father&apos;s outing, showing he and Luann were still not married). As of &quot; Little Orphan Millie &quot;, they are remarried.She And Kirk Had A Little Appearance In &quot; Moe Goes From Rags To Riches &quot; [ Luigi Risotto ] Luigi Risotto, voiced by Hank Azaria, { Gimple, p. 86 } is the proprietor of Luigi&apos;s, a Springfield Italian restaurant. He is a parody of the &quot; Italian pasta/pizza chef &quot; stereotype (and in fact is on a bowling team called &quot; The Stereotypes &quot; along with Cletus Spuckler, Captain Horatio McCallister, and Groundskeeper Willie ), but seems to be aware of his status as a stock character. He is polite to his customers and treats them with respect when they order and then loudly insults and belittles them to his cook Salvatore, apparently unaware that they can hear him from the kitchen. In the episode &quot; The Last of the Red Hat Mamas, &quot; he reveals that he does not speak Italian. It is hinted that Luigi is an illegal immigrant, even though he tried to run for mayor, telling Springfielders, &quot; I make-a you the good government, just how-a you like it! &quot; The animators copied Luigi&apos;s appearance from a chef that was on the front of a pizza box. { Mirkin, David (2004). Commentary for &quot; } { Sweet Seymour Skinner&apos;s Baadasssss Song &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Fifth Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } [ Lunchlady Doris ] Lunchlady Doris Freedman, voiced by Doris Grau up until her death, and now voiced by Tress MacNeille, is a sardonic chef for Springfield Elementary. She can frequently be seen serving deeply unpleasant meals, such as animal genitalia and ground up gym mats, because of the school budget cutbacks. She has also made a handful of appearances acting as a school nurse, apparently due to budget cutbacks. In the episode Team Homer it is suggested that she is the mother of Jeremy Freedman (a.k.a. the Squeaky-voiced Teen ). After Grau&apos;s death in 1995, Lunchlady Doris was retired out of respect for over 10 years. Due to the delay between recording some episodes and the time they actually air, Grau&apos;s voice was included in episodes airing as late as 1997 such as &quot; Lisa&apos;s Sax &quot;. [ http://snpp.com/guides/doris.html The Simpsons Archive: The Lunchlady Doris File Snpp.com 2005-08-28 2011-10-23 ] Lunchlady Doris is seen as a silent background character until she speaks in the 18th season during &quot; The Mook, the Chef, the Wife and Her Homer &quot;, where she is voiced by Tress MacNeille, season 19&apos;s &quot; The Debarted &quot;, where she is again voiced by Tress MacNeille but with a different voice, and season 20&apos;s &quot; Father Knows Worst &quot;. [ Lurleen Lumpkin ] Lurleen Lumpkin (voiced by Beverly D&apos;Angelo ) is an aspiring country singer who is managed by Homer in &quot; Colonel Homer &quot;. Homer discovers her in a redneck bar in the middle of nowhere and is amazed by her voice. He decides to help her launch a singing career, much to the chagrin of Marge. Grateful for Homer&apos;s help, Lurleen becomes attracted to him and tries to lure him with an erotic song called &quot; Bunk with Me Tonight &quot;. Homer, who had been ignorant of this, suddenly realizes that managing Lurleen could hurt his marriage, so he quits as her manager. A saddened Lurleen sings a song called &quot; Stand By Your Manager &quot;. Lurleen&apos;s next appearance is in &quot; Krusty Gets Kancelled &quot;, in which she is briefly seen in the center square of Springfield Squares. In an earlier episode, &quot; Marge vs. the Monorail &quot;, a much rougher-looking Lurleen, voiced by Doris Grau, makes a brief appearance, in which it is revealed that she had been to the Betty Ford Clinic and &quot; spent last night in a ditch &quot;. In this episode her voice sounds exactly the same as Lunchlady Doris &apos;s, rather than her soft, Southern voice she had when she was first introduced. The nineteenth season episode &quot; Papa Don&apos;t Leech &quot; { IGN TV tv.ign.com. Retrieved July 29, 2007. } follows up on her story with her moving into the Simpsons&apos; home and taking a waitress job at Moe&apos;s in order to pay a $12 million tax bill. It is revealed she has a father named Royce Boss Hogg Lumpkin, who was never much supportive of her and had been missing for years. Marge undertakes efforts to find him and reunite him with Lurleen. As soon as it happens, Lurleen writes a new, upbeat composition called &quot; Daddy&apos;s Back &quot;, but Royce sells the song, taking the writing credits for himself (but altering some lyrics), to the Dixie Chicks. As soon as she learns of this, Lurleen confronts Royce and reveals the truth to the Dixie Chicks, who assault him with their musical instruments and invite Lurleen to join their tour. Lurleen ends up engaged to a man who looks very much like Homer (like her previous husbands did) and tours as an opening act for the Dixie Chicks. [ Dr. Marvin Monroe ] Dr. Marvin Monroe is a psychotherapist who first appeared in the first season episode &quot; There&apos;s No Disgrace Like Home &quot;. Homer pawns the family television in order to afford a session with Monroe for him and his dysfunctional family. The failed attempt at therapy culminates with the Simpsons electroshocking each other endlessly, to the point of causing a blackout. Unable to help the Simpsons, Monroe refunds double what the Simpsons paid, and the Simpsons buy a new TV. Monroe appears in &quot; Some Enchanted Evening &quot; in which 70% of that episode&apos;s original animation had to be redone, although the scenes involving Monroe were mostly untouched, said co-director David Silverman. { Silverman, David (2001). Commentary for &quot; } { Some Enchanted Evening &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete First Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } The script of &quot; Some Enchanted Evening &quot; describes Monroe as &quot; a heavy, chain-smoking, compulsive eater. &quot; { Script for &quot; Some Enchanted Evening &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete First Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } The original idea behind the character, said Matt Groening, was that he was born Marilyn Monroe and was &quot; very caught up over that &quot;, which is why he became a therapist. { Groening, Matt (2001). Commentary for &quot; Some Enchanted Evening &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete First Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } Monroe&apos;s voice is based on psychiatrist David Viscott &apos;s. { Groening, Matt (2001). Commentary for &quot; } { There&apos;s No Disgrace Like Home &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete First Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } Among Monroe&apos;s works is Dr. Marvin Monroe&apos;s Guide to Etiquette, which Bart receives as a birthday gift in &quot; Radio Bart &quot;. Since the seventh season, the character Monroe has been retired. This is because voicing the character strained Harry Shearer &apos;s throat and, eventually, the voice became too annoying for Groening, which, he acknowledges, is the point. { Jean, Al (2001). Commentary for &quot; Some Enchanted Evening &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete First Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } { Groening, Matt (2003). Commentary for &quot; } { Treehouse of Horror II &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Third Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } The character&apos;s retirement was marked by the broadcast of a Dr. Marvin Monroe Memorial Hospital over Lou &apos;s walkie-talkie in &quot; Who Shot Mr. Burns? &quot;, Part Two. { Oakley, Bill (2005). Commentary for &quot; } { Who Shot Mr. Burns? (Part Two) &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Seventh Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } Since then, several references to Monroe being dead have been made: a glimpse of his gravestone in &quot; Alone Again, Natura-diddily &quot;, a Dr. Marvin Monroe Memorial Gymnasium seen in &quot; Bye Bye Nerdie &quot;, and an interstitial in the &quot; 138th Episode Spectacular &quot;. However, Monroe is seen alive in the fifteenth season in &quot; Diatribe of a Mad Housewife &quot; to purchase a copy of Marge&apos;s novel &quot; The Harpooned Heart &quot;, stating simply that he has &quot;...been very sick &quot; when asked about his absence by Marge. [ Manjula Nahasapeemapetilon ] Manjula Nahasapeemapetilon is the wife of Apu Nahasapeemapetilon and the mother of their eight children. She first appeared as a little girl in Apu&apos;s flashback in the seventh season episode &quot; Much Apu About Nothing &quot;, in which Apu tells her that he is sorry that their arranged marriage will not happen, before getting on a plane departing for the U.S. to pursue the American Dream. Her first adult appearance is in the ninth season episode The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons. { Cohen, David (2005). Commentary for &quot; } { Much Apu About Nothing &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Seventh Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } She claims that Fried Green Tomatoes is her favorite book, movie, and food. She has excellent culinary skills, demonstrated by her ability to make a wide variety of dishes using only chickpeas, lentils, and sometimes rice. She is also one of Marge&apos;s best and only friends, and they often walk their babies together. In &quot; The Sweetest Apu &quot;, Apu has an affair with the Squishee lady. After Homer discovers this, he and Marge confront Apu, who caves under the guilt and vows to apologize to Manjula, who sets him a number of grueling tasks in penance. [ Cohen, David The Simpsons: The Complete Seventh Season DVD Video Collector&apos;s Edition commentary for the episode &quot; Much Apu About Nothing &quot; DVD Twentieth Century Fox ] Writer Richard Appel had pitched the idea of Apu marrying years before he wrote &quot; The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons &quot; for season nine. { Appel, Richard (2006). Commentary for &quot; } { The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Ninth Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } For that episode, it took several attempts by the character designers to model Manjula because making women look appealing in Matt Groening &apos;s drawing style is hard for the animators to do. { Moore, Steven Dean (2006). Commentary for &quot; } { The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Ninth Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } { Kirkland, Mark (2003). Commentary for &quot; } { Colonel Homer &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Third Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. } Writer David Cohen named Manjula after a friend of much of the staff. Manjula was voiced by former Saturday Night Live cast member Jan Hooks from seasons 9 to 14, { Gimple, p. 64 } by Tress MacNeille in season 15 (only one appearance) and Maggie Roswell thereafter. [ Martha Prince ] Martha Prince, voiced by Russi Taylor, is the wife of Martin Prince Sr. and mother of Martin Prince. Martha is probably best known for attempting to sell Martin&apos;s extremely valuable Star Wars merchandise to Comic Book Guy for an extremely cheap price. She was warned by Bart and Milhouse before she sold them and decided to not to sell them. It was also hinted by Martin that she shoplifts a lot, &quot; stuff she doesn&apos;t even need &quot;. She also was responsible for all of the guests getting sick at Martin&apos;s birthday party, by serving diseased oysters instead of cake, with the exception of Bart, Lisa, Principal Skinner and Mrs. Krabappel. [ Martha Quimby ] Martha Quimby is the wife of the Mayor of Springfield Joseph Quimby. She wears a pink outfit and a pillbox hat similar to the outfit worn by Jackie Kennedy on the day of the Kennedy assassination. According to Mayor Quimby, the couple met while Martha was working at the &quot; Maison Derrière &quot;, a local burlesque house. She first appeared in &quot; Bart Gets Famous &quot;, { Richmond, p. 215 } when she walks in on Mayor Quimby in bed with another woman, an event she laughs off when he defends himself with &quot; I didn&apos;t do it. &quot; She is humiliated when Marge accidentally uncovers her husband&apos;s lothario ways in &quot; The Last of the Red Hat Mamas &quot; and kicks Marge and her friends out before they can have tea. Martha Quimby is voiced by Maggie Roswell. [ Martin Prince ] Martin Prince, Jr. { The Simpsons, &quot; } { Bart the Genius &quot; - January 14, 1990 } is a recurring character in the Fox animated series, The Simpsons, and is voiced by Russi Taylor. Martin is Bart Simpson &apos;s classmate, and is Lisa Simpson &apos;s rival in intelligence, as well as Nelson Muntz &apos;s favorite target for bullying. He is an academically brilliant, teacher&apos;s pet, and is portrayed as a stereotypical nerd, and is a 4th grade student at Springfield Elementary School. Martin is the son of Martin, Sr. and Martha. He is an academically brilliant student, portrayed when he first appears in the second episode of the series. He is also a teacher&apos;s pet with the stereotypical nerd enthusiasms for science fiction, role-playing game s and not-so-great fashion sense. He has an IQ of 216. As the class nerd, he unwittingly becomes the perfect target for ruthless bullying at Springfield Elementary School. He is a member of the Springfield band, and is often seen with a French Horn. Martin&apos;s most famous catchphrases are &quot; Behold! &quot; and &quot; Excelsior! &quot;. [ Martin Prince, Sr. ] Martin Prince, Sr. is the father of Martin Prince, and husband of Martha Prince. He is a stock broker in Springfield and was shown bringing his son to work on &quot; Go To Work With Your Parents Day &quot;, where Martin made over $1 million trading soy futures (and subsequently lost all but $600). He appears to be a nerd much like his son, seeing as he has somewhat of a lisp. Martin Sr. was also one of the fathers that went in Ned Flanders&apos;s RV, to find their sons in Shelbyville. He is voiced by Dan Castellaneta. [ Mary Bailey ] Mary Bailey is the governor of Springfield&apos;s state. She is voiced by Maggie Roswell. She ran against Mr. Burns in &quot; Two Cars in Every Garage and Three Eyes on Every Fish &quot;, winning in a landslide after Mr. Burns spit out a piece of baked Three eyed Fish during a photo-op at the Simpsons&apos; home. Mary Bailey would later appear briefly in the episode &quot; Bart vs. Lisa vs. the Third Grade &quot; when Bart and Lisa&apos;s class visit Capital City. They show Bailey their class projects (designing a new state flag). Mary Bailey wails in disgust after unfurling Lisa&apos;s flag. Bart had redesigned it to look like a butt with &quot; Learn to Fart &quot; underneath. She also appears in &quot; The Seven-Beer Snitch &quot; where a prison is built out of a defunct concert hall. She decides to release all the abused prisoners to a garbage barge where they would &quot; bare-knuckle box until one of you emerges as king of your floating hell. &quot; She looks nearly identical to Bea Simmons, Abe Simpson&apos;s former girlfriend in the episode Old Money. [ Maude Flanders ] Maude Flanders, voiced by Maggie Roswell and temporarily by Marcia Mitzman Gaven between 1999 and 2000 when Roswell did not work for the show, was the wife of Ned Flanders, and the mother of Rod and Todd. While she was not employed outside the home, Maude was a busy homemaker and a tireless advocate for the children, whose innocence is so often sullied by the &quot; evils &quot; of cartoon violence, liberal education, and the insidious influences of popular culture. Even though she spent much of her free time in prayer and reading the Bible and helping out her husband at the Leftorium, Maude was known to let her hair down for the occasional dinner party at the home of her neighbors, the Simpsons. Homer often made statements insinuating his attraction to Maude, thereby literally coveting his neighbor&apos;s wife. Also, in the second season episode &quot; The War of the Simpsons &quot;, Homer ogled Maude&apos;s cleavage at a dinner party, which resulted in him and Marge going to marriage camp. In the season eleven episode &quot; Alone Again, Natura-Diddily &quot;, Maude was killed by a t-shirt cannon at the Springfield Speedway when Homer ducked at the last second to pick up a bobby pin on the ground. [ Seifert Andy Indiana Man says no to the White Sox T-shirt cannons http://www.avclub.com/chicago/articles/indiana-man-says-no-to-the-white-sox-tshirt-cannon%2C26920/ The A.V. Club 2009-04-26 2010-08-08 ] She was knocked off the grandstand and her rescue was prevented as Homer had parked in the ambulance zone, impeding their rescue attempt. Her death crushed Ned who, though used to some measure of hardship, assumed that they would always be together. This kill-off was the result of Roswell leaving The Simpsons in spring 1999 after a pay dispute with the Fox Broadcasting Company, which airs the show. [ Voice Of &apos;Maude&apos; Disputes Report The Columbian 2000-02-05 E6 ] [ My Life as a 10-Year-Old Boy Cartwright Nancy Nancy Cartwright Lady, that ain&apos;t no gutterball! 96 2000 Hyperion New York City 0-7868-8600-5 ] Voice actress Marcia Mitzman Gaven was hired to fill in for Roswell&apos;s characters, including Maude in &quot; Alone Again, Natura-Diddily &quot; and the earlier episodes of the eleventh season, [ Will corporate greed kill Maude of &apos;Simpsons&apos;? Pittsburgh Post-Gazette 2000-02-07 D8 ] although the producers decided to kill the character off to open up new storylines for the show. [ Maude Flanders will likely leave Simpsons 2000-02-05 F04 ] Roswell returned to The Simpsons in 2002 [ Basile Nancy There&apos;s a New Maude in Town http://animatedtv.about.com/od/maggieroswell/a/roswellreturn.htm About.com 2010-08-06 ] after reaching a deal with Fox to record her lines from her home in Denver. [ Husted Bill Maggie&apos;s back The Denver Post 2003-06-01 F-02 ] Since returning, she has voiced Maude in flashbacks and as a ghost. [ Husted Bill She&apos;s wanted dead or alive by folks on &apos;Simpsons&apos; The Denver Post 2011-04-21 ] Maude&apos;s ghost appears in the opening sequence for &quot; Treehouse of Horror XIII &quot;, and during the credits of &quot; Bart Has Two Mommies &quot; she is seen in heaven with Bob Hope and God, wondering how her boys are doing. Maude appeared through flashbacks in &quot; Dangerous Curves &quot;, &quot; Take My Life, Please &quot;, and &quot; Postcards from the Wedge &quot;. Maude also appears in &quot; Treehouse of Horror XXII &quot; as the devil&apos;s wife. [ Ms. Albright ] Ms. Albright is voiced by Tress MacNeille. { Richmond, p. 179 } She is the First Church of Springfield Sunday school teacher. She first appeared in &quot; The Telltale Head &quot;. She speaks with a soft Southern accent. She appears to be good friends with Helen Lovejoy. She is occasionally seen in the background of various episodes as well as in church scenes (such as in &quot; The Father, the Son, and the Holy Guest Star &quot; ). [ Miss Springfield ] Miss Springfield (voiced by Pamela Hayden ) is a beauty pageant winner, who first appears in &quot; Whacking Day &quot;. She is the lover of Mayor Quimby, and is seen several times in bed with him. She only appears with the sash and the crown of Miss Springfield. In &quot; Mayored to the Mob &quot;, she is one of two women escorting Mayor Quimby to a convention. Since then, she is often seen escorting him to Springfield events such as conventions, recitals, and plays. In one episode, it is revealed she is illiterate. Quimby scolds her for lying about her graduating from &quot; typing school &quot;. She then admits she has trouble with the space bar. In &quot; Smoke on the Daughter &quot;, she appears (and claims to be) pregnant, and Quimby believes he may be the father. [ Mr. Costington ] Mr. Costington, voiced by Hank Azaria, is the president of Costington&apos;s Department Store. He first appeared as &quot; Chairman &quot; { Gimple, p. 38 } in the season nine episode &quot; Trash of the Titans &quot;, in which he invented &quot; Love Day &quot;, and later in &quot; Homer vs. Dignity &quot;. He is one of very few characters on the show who has eyebrows. Costington&apos;s catchphrase is &quot; You&apos;re fiiired! &quot;, delivered while shaking his jowls. In &quot; The Boys of Bummer &quot;, he hires Homer with a jowl-shaking &quot; You&apos;re hiiired! &quot; Homer has worked for him on three occasions: as a Thanksgiving Day Parade Santa Claus, mattress salesman, and model for top-brand jeans. He also employs the Yes Guy, who is seen working at the store in most of his appearances. [ Mr. Teeny ] Louis “Mr. Teeny” Toot, also known as Joseph Teeny and voiced by Dan Castellaneta, is Krusty’s trained chimpanzee who frequently appears on the show. He first appeared in &quot; Itchy &amp; Scratchy &amp; Marge &quot;. Like Krusty, he is a heavy smoker, and often seems depressed off-stage. He is sometimes seen as Krusty’s driver and butler. Teeny’s uncle was former head monkey at the ministry of tourism in Brazil. Three other monkeys have died while working for Krusty known by the same name. Krusty once said he missed the third Mr. Teeny and the current one couldn’t hold a candle to him. In the episode &quot; Day of the Jackanapes &quot; Teeny saves Krusty from a bomb that Sideshow Bob has attached to Bart. His mother’s name is Toot-Toot, and she refers to him as Louis when they are reunited in &quot; Bart Has Two Mommies &quot;. Teeny also was a writer for the “Good Guy Awards” and quit after being insulted on-stage by Krusty. He is an immigrant from Brazil and has been deported but was returned. He wears a pink hat and bow tie but has also been seen in a tuxedo and golden encrusted thong. Krusty has implied that if he can not find a human willing to donate a lung when he gets cancer, he is planning on harvesting one from Mr. Teeny. As of &quot; Wedding For Disaster &quot;, there have been seven Mr. Teenys. [ Mrs. Glick ] Alice { The Simpsons season 23, episode 4: &quot; } { Replaceable You &quot; } Glick is an elderly shut-in for whom Bart did chores in &quot; Three Men and a Comic Book &quot;; he didn&apos;t get paid very well, so he started to hate her. She had a brother named Asa, mentioned in the same episode, who died during World War I; he was killed by his own grenade, which he held for too long. Doctor Hibbert once confessed to leaving his car keys inside her. She is occasionally seen in the background of various episodes, often with a toothless laugh. She is a stereotypical lonely old woman, who spends her days &quot; watching her stories. &quot; She was originally voiced by Cloris Leachman { Richmond, p. 57 } and later by Tress MacNeille. She later dies due to a heart attack caused by an invention Bart and Martin create in the episode &quot; Replaceable You &quot;. Her final scene is dancing with Jesus in Heaven. [ Mrs. Muntz ] Mrs. Muntz, voiced by Tress MacNeille. She is Nelson Muntz &apos;s mother. Nelson receives his trademark laugh from her. Early on in the series, Nelson would often mention his parents, and it was often implied that Nelson&apos;s mother does not care for him. In &quot; A Milhouse Divided &quot;, Nelson tells Milhouse that his mom is addicted to cough drop s, which is why his father left the family.Mrs. Muntz works at Hooters in &quot; Bart Star &quot;, but was fired in a later episode for gaining weight. She owns a dilapidated house and is depicted as a jailbird, a prostitute, a stripper, or something similar. In &quot; &apos;Tis the Fifteenth Season &quot;, she appears, telling Nelson that his father simply did not like him, and he left with her golden tooth. Nelson&apos;s mother was fully introduced in &quot; Sleeping with the Enemy &quot;, after years of being mentioned. A loud, high-pitched contemptuous woman, she neglects Nelson. She implies she misses Nelson&apos;s father. At the end of the episode, the three Muntzes reunite, and she receives a new job as Lady Macbeth, with &quot; the third director she slept with &quot;. Since then, she is often seen around in Springfield. Curiously, in Season 18 &apos;s &quot; The Haw-Hawed Couple &quot;, she appears with brown hair. As revealed in &quot; Dial &apos;N&apos; for Nerder &quot;, Nelson even refers to her as Mrs. Muntz. [ Old Barber ] Jake the Barber { McCann, p. 86 } originated in one of the Tracey Ullman shorts, &quot; Bart&apos;s Haircut &quot;. { Silverman, David (2003). Commentary for &quot; } { Homer Defined &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Third Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox } In the short, he cuts Bart&apos;s hair not to his liking and Bart tries several ways to hide it. Dan Castellaneta, voiced the Old Barber in that short and in subsequent episodes in the series, based the voice on comedian Bob Elliott &apos;s. { Castellaneta, Dan (2003). Commentary for &quot; } { Homer Defined &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Third Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox } The Old Barber made his last appearance in the twelfth season episode &quot; Lisa the Tree Hugger &quot;. He was voiced by Harry Shearer in that episode. { McCann, p. 87 } David Silverman had to create a model sheet of the Old Barber for Jim Reardon, who directed &quot; 22 Short Films about Springfield. &quot; Before then, there was no model sheet for the character. { Reardon, Jim; Silverman, David (2005). Commentary for &quot; } { 22 Short Films About Springfield &quot;, in The Simpsons: The Complete Seventh Season [DVD]. 20th Century Fox } [ Old Jewish Man ] Asa, a.k.a. Old Jewish Man, or Crazy Old Man (according to &quot; Krusty Gets Kancelled &quot; ) is Abraham Simpson and Jasper Beardly &apos;s friend. Mayor Quimby once referred to him as &quot; Old Jewish Man &quot;; also, a list of heart recipients in &quot; Homer&apos;s Paternity Coot &quot; listed him as &quot; Old Jewish Man &quot;. He speaks with a stereotypical Jewish-American accent (voiced by Hank Azaria ), and curses in Yiddish in one episode. He is apparently friendly with Krusty the Clown and Krusty&apos;s father, according to &quot; Simpsons Christmas Stories &quot;. He is often seen yelling at people, and as seen in &quot; Attack of the 50-Foot Eyesores &quot;, owns a store called Zip Boys, a parody of Pep Boys. He once had a brief period of stardom after his act of dancing on a street corner singing &quot; The Old Gray Mare &quot; with his pants down became a hit on television. In &quot; Natural Born Kissers &quot;, it was revealed that he worked as a studio executive during the making of Casablanca and suppressed an alternate ending to the film. He was also responsible for a &quot; Killing Spree Ending &quot; to It&apos;s a Wonderful Life. He observes that the quality of studio management has changed over the years. In &quot; Love Is a Many Strangled Thing &quot; he dies by dancing too hard, although his ghost continues dancing. He reappears in &quot; Replaceable You &quot; alive. [ Opal ] Opal (voiced by Tress MacNeille ) is a talk show host. This celebrity is based on Oprah, as is her show. She first appears in &quot; Ice Cream of Margie (with the Light Blue Hair) &quot; where her segment on successful women depresses Marge, who feels her life of chores and child-raising has left her without any purpose. She later appeared in the back-to-back nineteenth season episodes &quot; Husbands and Knives &quot; and &quot; Funeral for a Fiend &quot;. Marge is a fan of hers, and was interviewed by Opal after achieving success through her chain of Shapes gyms for women. [ Otto Mann ] Otto Mann voiced by Harry Shearer is the school bus driver for Springfield Elementary School. Otto is notable for his maniacal driving style (which, along with never getting a driver&apos;s license, cost him his job on the season three episode &quot; The Otto Show &quot; ), his love of heavy metal music, drugs and his propensity for sounding and acting like a perpetual 1980s teenager. In early seasons he is often used as a friend and confidant to Bart, despite their age difference. Later seasons, however, usually only depict him as a passerby citizen of Springfield. He is a (last-minute) member of Homer&apos;s bowling team, the &quot; Pin Pals &quot;. { &quot; } { Team Homer &quot; } Otto is a skilled guitarist, having done little else but practice during high school. { &quot; } { The Otto Show &quot; } [ Patches and Poor Violet ] Patches and Poor Violet are two of Springfield&apos;s orphans, voiced by Pamela Hayden and Tress MacNeille, respectively. Introduced in “ Miracle on Evergreen Terrace,” Patches gives the dollar they were saving to Bart, which was their vitamin money. They have since had cameos in “ I&apos;m Goin&apos; to Praiseland ” and “ Simple Simpson,” but are seen in many other episodes. Poor Violet often has a cough, while Patches seems to vaguely resemble Tiny Tim from Charles Dickens ’ A Christmas Carol. Their skin color is not the “healthy” yellow of the Simpson family, but rather a more sallow, sickly tone. [ Plopper ] [ Spider-Pig For the variation of Spider-Man who happens to be a pig, see Spider-Ham. For the song of the same name, see The Simpsons Movie: The Music ] Plopper, also known as Spider-Pig and later renamed to Harry Plopper (a play on the popular fictional character Harry Potter ), is a pig who first appears in The Simpsons Movie. Plopper has since become memetic, gaining immense popularity in the real world and on the internet, especially his theme song &quot; Spider-Pig &quot;, which peaked at number 23 in the UK Singles Chart. [ http://www.chartstats.com/songinfo.php?id%3D33298 Hans Zimmer - Spider Pig Chart Stats 2011-10-23 ] The pig is voiced by Tress MacNeille. Plopper has also made appearances in the episodes and comics, and also appears in the reanimated opening sequence, featuring in the pan across Springfield. Plopper&apos;s first appearance is in the movie, where he stars in a TV ad to promote Krusty&apos;s new burger, The Clogger. After the filming is completed, Krusty orders the pig to be killed. Homer becomes upset about this, and immediately adopts him. Homer then spends a lot of time with Plopper and neglects Bart. Later in the movie, Homer is seen making the pig walk on the ceiling whilst singing &quot; Spider Pig &quot;, a parody of the Spider-Man theme song. Homer later calls him Harry Plopper, and the pig is seen with glasses and a lightning bolt-shaped scar, based on the character Harry Potter. At one point in the movie, the Simpsons&apos; house is completely destroyed after being sucked into a sinkhole in their backyard. This may lead to the assumption that the pig is killed in the movie. However, during the 2007 San Diego Comic Convention, an official Simpsons Panel revealed that there was a scene at the end of the movie involving the pig that was cut which later appeared on the DVD. { IGN: SDCC 07: The Simpsons Panel } This removed sequence is a slightly alternate ending of the movie when the townspeople are rebuilding the Simpsons&apos; house and involves Plopper, the Multi-Eyed Creature, and Santa&apos;s Little Helper painting a dog house. During the following TV seasons, Plopper makes a few more appearances. [ Poochie ] When network executives decided that The Itchy and Scratchy Show needed an &quot; update &quot; to keep the interest of its audience, they devised Poochie, a cartoon dog &quot; with an attitude. &quot; After widespread auditions, Homer was chosen to provide Poochie&apos;s voice. The character debuted to an unimpressed audience following a massive publicity campaign; he only served to interfere with the well-oiled machine of hyperviolent slapstick that Itchy and Scratchy had perfected over the years. When dissatisfied viewers flooded the network with letters crying for Poochie&apos;s immediate removal, if not death, the executives quickly decided to get rid of the character. Homer begged for another chance, insisting that Poochie would grow on the audience; this argument held little weight until the actress who performed voices for both Itchy and Scratchy declared her support for Poochie as well. Homer was shocked, however, when the next cartoon aired: it contained a hastily-animated, retroscript ed segment stating that Poochie had decided to return to his &quot; home planet, &quot; and that he died when his spaceship crashed. He has since been seen once in a cameo at a funeral in an Itchy &amp; Scratchy cartoon featured in Little Big Mom. Also in &quot; Treehouse of Horror IX, &quot; he skateboards in the road and gets run over by Scratchy driving a car. However he survives only to have his skateboard falling form the sky and hitting him in the head. He also continues to be released in Itchy &amp; Scratchy related merchandise such as on t-shirts in &quot; Fat Man and Little Boy &quot;. A matrix Poochie also appears in Kill Gil Vols. 1 &amp; 2 during the Krusty on ice show and a Poochie balloon appears in the cartoon in &quot; Funeral for a Fiend &quot;. Poochie reappears in The Simpsons Game as a boss on the Grand Theft Scratchy level. [ Princess Kashmir ] Princess Kashmir is the belly dance r who first appears in &quot; Homer&apos;s Night Out &quot; (and was the first woman who almost ruined Homer&apos;s marriage to Marge as Marge saw Homer dancing with her as a bad example for Bart in how to treat women). She dated Apu in &quot; Lisa&apos;s Pony, &quot; dated Apu&apos;s brother Sanjay on a few occasions, and is seen dancing with Chief Wiggum in the episode &quot; Homer vs. the Eighteenth Amendment &quot; (which also shocked and offended the women in town, much like what happened with Homer). She has also appeared in two couch gag s (the one on &quot; Marge vs. The Monorail, in which the Simpsons sit on the couch, followed by three rows of recurring extras and secondary characters, and the Sgt. Pepper album parody on &quot; Bart After Dark &quot; and the original airing of &quot; The Itchy and Scratchy and Poochy Show &quot; ), and is seen dancing on the stage in the Maison Derrière in the episode &quot; Bart After Dark &quot;. Her nickname is &apos;Queen of the Mysterious East&apos;. Her real name is Shauna Tifton, and also goes by April Flowers when performing in strip clubs. According to the DVD commentary for the season eight episode &quot; Bart After Dark, &quot; Princess Kashmir was originally going to be an actual bachelor party stripper on her premiere episode, but the FOX censors at the time objected (though they had no problem letting Princess Kashmir tell Bart that she works under the name &quot; April Flowers &quot; when she performs at strip clubs). [ Principal Dondelinger ] Harlan Dondelinger, voiced by Harry Shearer was Springfield High School&apos;s principal, first seen in the episode &quot; The Way We Was &quot;, a flashback to Homer and Marge &apos;s senior year in high school. He later appeared in the episode &quot; The Front &quot; at Homer and Marge&apos;s high school reunion and teaches night classes to ease the pain of his wife&apos;s recent death. He appeared in &quot; Half-Decent Proposal &quot; when Artie Ziff, Marge&apos;s high school prom date, recreated their prom. Dondelinger made his most recent appearance in the twentieth season episode &quot; Take My Life, Please &quot;. [ Rabbi Hyman Krustofski ] Hyman Krustofski is the father of Krusty the Clown. He first appeared in the third season episode &quot; Like Father, Like Clown &quot;. { Richmond, p. 103 } In this episode, in season fifteen &apos;s &quot; Today I Am a Clown &quot;, and season twenty-one &apos;s &quot; Once Upon a Time in Springfield &quot; he is voiced by comedian Jackie Mason (because in the three episodes, he was a major character, while in cameo speaking appearances, he is voiced by Dan Castellaneta. However, recent cameo speaking episodes have him again voiced by Jackie Mason). In &quot; Like Father, Like Clown &quot;, Rabbi Krustofski had been estranged from his son for twenty-five years.
