Indeed, lifestyle anarchism today is finding its principal expression in spray-can graffiti, post-modernist nihilism, antirationalism, neo- primitivism, anti-technologism, neo- Situationist &apos;cultural terrorism&apos;, mysticism, and a &apos;practice&apos; of staging Foucauldian &apos;personal insurrections&apos;. &quot; { Social Anarchism or Lifestyle Anarchism: An Unbridgeable Chasm by } { Murray Bookchin } Post-left anarchist Bob Black in his long critique of Bookchin&apos;s philosophy called Anarchy after leftism said about post-left anarchy that &quot; It is, unlike Bookchinism, “individualistic” in the sense that if the freedom and happiness of the individual — i.e., each and every really existing person, every Tom, Dick and Murray — is not the measure of the good society, what is? &quot;. { &apos;&apos;Anarchy after Leftism&apos;&apos; by } { Bob Black } { Hakim Bey, contemporary } { egoist &quot; } { lifestyle anarchist &quot; } A strong relationship does exist between post-left anarchism and the work of individualist anarchist Max Stirner. Jason McQuinn says that &quot; when I (and other anti-ideological anarchists) criticize ideology, it is always from a specifically critical, anarchist perspective rooted in both the skeptical, individualist-anarchist philosophy of Max Stirner. { &quot; What is Ideology? &quot; by } { Jason McQuinn } Also Bob Black and Feral Faun / Wolfi Landstreicher strongly adhere to stirnerist egoist anarchism. Bob Black has humorously suggested the idea of &quot; marxist stirnerism &quot;. { &quot; Theses on Groucho Marxism &quot; by [[Bob Black ]] } Hakim Bey has said &quot; From Stirner&apos;s &quot; Union of Self-Owning Ones &quot; we proceed to Nietzsche &apos;s circle of &quot; Free Spirits &quot; and thence to Charles Fourier &apos;s &quot; Passional Series &quot;, doubling and redoubling ourselves even as the Other multiplies itself in the eros of the group. &quot; { &apos;&apos;Immediatism&apos;&apos; by Hakim Bey } Bey also wrote that &quot; The Mackay Society, of which Mark &amp; I are active members, is devoted to the anarchism of Max Stirner, Benj. Tucker &amp; John Henry Mackay...The Mackay Society, incidentally, represents a little-known current of individualist thought which never cut its ties with revolutionary labor. Dyer Lum, Ezra &amp; Angela Haywood represent this school of thought; Jo Labadie, who wrote for Tucker’s Liberty, made himself a link between the American “plumb-line” anarchists, the “philosophical” individualists, &amp; the syndicalist or communist branch of the movement; his influence reached the Mackay Society through his son, Laurance. Like the Italian Stirnerites (who influenced us through our late friend Enrico Arrigoni ) we support all anti-authoritarian currents, despite their apparent contradictions. &quot; { Hakim Bey. &quot; An esoteric interpretation of the I.W.W. preamble &quot; } As far as posterior individualist anarchists, Jason McQuinn for some time used the pseudonym Lev Chernyi in honor of the Russian individualist anarchist of the same name while Feral Faun has quoted Italian individualist anarchist Renzo Novatore { Anti-politics.net, &quot; Whither now? Some thoughts on creating anarchy &quot; by Feral Faun } and has translated both Novatore. { Towards the creative nothing and other writings by Renzo Novatore } and the young Italian individualist anarchist Bruno Filippi [ http://theanarchistlibrary.org/HTML/Bruno_Filippi__The_rebel_s_dark_laughter__the_writings_of_Bruno_Filippi.html#toc2 The rebel&apos;s dark laughter: the writings of Bruno Filippi ] Kevin Carson is a contemporary mutualist economist and author of Studies in Mutualist Political Economy. { [[Kevin Carson ].Studies in Mutualist Political Economy] } Another important current mutualist is Joe Peacott. Contemporary mutualists are among those involved in the Alliance of the Libertarian Left and in the Voluntary Cooperation Movement. A recent mutualist collective was the Boston Anarchist Drinking Brigade. { http://www.libertarian.co.uk/lapubs/polin/polin184.htm &quot; Contemporary Individualist Anarchism: The Broadsides of the Boston Anarchist Drinking Brigade 1988-2000 &quot; by Joe Peacott, Jim Baker, &amp; Others } Egoism has had a strong influence on insurrectionary anarchism, as can be seen in the work of Wolfi Landstreicher. Feral Faun wrote in 1995 that: In the game of insurgence—a lived guerilla war game—it is strategically necessary to use identities and roles. Unfortunately, the context of social relationships gives these roles and identities the power to define the individual who attempts to use them. So I, Feral Faun, became  ... an anarchist  ... a writer  ... a Stirner-influenced, post- situationist, anti-civilization theorist  ... if not in my own eyes, at least in the eyes of most people who&apos;ve read my writings. { &quot; The Last Word &quot; by Feral Faun } [ European individualist anarchism ] [ European individualist anarchism ] { Émile Armand } { European } individualist anarchism proceeded from the roots laid by William Godwin, { Woodcock, George. 2004. Anarchism: A History Of Libertarian Ideas And Movements. Broadview Press. p. 20. } Pierre Joseph Proudhon and Max Stirner. Proudhon was an early pioneer of anarchism as well as of the important individualist anarchist current of mutualism. [ Encyclopedia Americana George Edward Rines 1918 Encyclopedia Americana Corp. New York 7308909 624 harv ] [ Hamilton Peter Emile Durkheim Routledge New York 1995 0415110475 79 harv ] Stirner became a central figure of individualist anarchism through the publication of his seminal work The Ego and Its Own which is considered to be &quot; a founding text in the tradition of individualist anarchism. &quot; [ max-stirner Max Stirner David Leopold 2006-08-04 ] Another early figure was Anselme Bellegarrigue. { Biography of Anselme Bellegarrigue by Max Nettlau. } IA expanded and diversified through Europe, incorporating influences from North American individualist anarchism. European individualist anarchists include Albert Libertad, Bellegarrigue, Oscar Wilde, Émile Armand, Lev Chernyi, John Henry Mackay, Han Ryner, Adolf Brand, Miguel Gimenez Igualada, Renzo Novatore, and currently Michel Onfray. { Onfray says in an interview &quot; L’individualisme anarchiste part de cette logique. Il célèbre les individualités...Dans cette période de libéralisme comme horizon indépassable, je persiste donc à plaider pour l’individu. &quot; Interview des lecteurs : Michel Onfray Par Marion Rousset| 1er avril 2005 } Important currents within it include free love, { &quot; Voluntary non-submission. Spanish individualist anarchism during dictatorship and the second republic (1923-1938) &quot; by Xavier Diez } anarcho-naturism, and illegalism. { &quot; Parallel to the social, } { collectivist anarchist current there was an individualist one whose partisans emphasized their individual freedom and advised other individuals to do the same. Individualist anarchist activity spanned the full spectrum of alternatives to } { authoritarian society, subverting it by undermining its way of life facet by facet. &quot; Thus } { theft, } { counterfeiting, swindling and } { robbery became a way of life for hundreds of individualists, as it was already for countless thousands of } { proletarian s. The wave of anarchist bombings and assassinations of the 1890s ( } { Auguste Vaillant, Ravachol, } { Emile Henry, } { Sante Caserio ) and the practice of illegalism from the mid-1880s to the start of the First World War ( } { Clément Duval, Pini, } { Marius Jacob, the Bonnot gang) were twin aspects of the same proletarian offensive, but were expressed in an individualist practice, one that complemented the great collective struggles against capital. &quot; } [ France ] [ Individualist anarchism in France ] { Han Ryner } { From } the legacy of Proudhon and Stirner there emerged a strong tradition of French individualist anarchism. An early important individualist anarchist was Anselme Bellegarrigue. He participated in the French Revolution of 1848, was author and editor of &apos;Anarchie, Journal de l&apos;Ordre and Au fait ! Au fait ! Interprétation de l&apos;idée démocratique&apos; and wrote the important early Anarchist Manifesto in 1850. Catalan historian of individualist anarchism Xavier Diez reports that during his travels in the United States &quot; he at least contacted (Henry David) Thoreau and, probably (Josiah) Warren. &quot; { Xavier Diez. El anarquismo individualista en España (1923-1938). Virus editorial. Barcelona. 2007. pg. 60 } Autonomie Individuelle was an individualist anarchist publication that ran from 1887 to 1888. It was edited by Jean-Baptiste Louiche, Charles Schæffer and Georges Deherme. { http://www.la-presse-anarchiste.net/spip.php?rubrique258 Autonomie Individuelle (1887 — 1888) } Later, this tradition continued with such intellectuals as Albert Libertad, André Lorulot, Emile Armand, Victor Serge, Zo d&apos;Axa and Rirette Maitrejean, who developed theory in the main individualist anarchist journal in France, L&apos;Anarchie { &quot; On the fringe of the movement, and particularly in the individualist faction which became relatively strong after 1900 and began to publish its own sectarian paper, -315- L&apos;Anarchie ( 1905-14), there were groups and individuals who lived largely by crime. Among them were some of the most original as well as some of the most tragic figures in anarchist history. &quot; Woodcock, George. Anarchism: A History of Libertarian Ideas and Movements. 1962 } in 1905. Outside this journal, Han Ryner wrote Petit Manuel individualiste (1903). Later appeared the journal L&apos;EnDehors created by Zo d&apos;Axa in 1891. { Zo d&apos;Axa } French individualist anarchists exposed a diversity of positions (per example, about violence and non-violence). For example, Emile Armand rejected violence and embraced mutualism while becoming an important propagandist for free love, while Albert Libertad and Zo d&apos;Axa were influential in violentists circles and championed violent propaganda by the deed while adhering to communitarianism or anarcho-communism { &quot; Libertad était un révolté, qui luttait non en dehors (tel les communautaires/colonies) ni à côté de la société (les éducationnistes), mais en son sein. Il sera énoncé comme une figure de l&apos;anarchisme individualiste, néanmoins, il ne se revendiquera jamais ainsi, même si il ne rejetait pas l&apos;individualisme, et que Libertad se revendiquait du communisme; plus tard, Mauricius, qui était un des éditeurs du journal &quot; l&apos;Anarchie &quot; dira &quot; Nous ne nous faisions pas d&apos;illusions, nous savions bien que cette libération totale de l&apos;individu dans la société capitaliste était impossible et que la réalisation de sa personnalité ne pourrait se faire que dans une société raisonnable, dont le communisme libertaire nous semblait être la meilleure expression. &quot;. Libertad s&apos;associait à la dynamique de révolte individuelle radicale au projet d&apos;émancipation collective. Il insistait sur la nécessité de développer le sentiment de camaraderie, afin de remplacer la concurrence qui était la morale de la société bourgeoise. &quot; &quot; Albert Libertad &quot; } and rejecting work. Han Ryner on the other side conciled anarchism with stoicism. Nevertheless French individualist circles had a strong sense of personal libertarianism and experimentation. Naturism and free love contents started to have a strong influence in individualist anarchist circles and from there it expanded to the rest of anarchism also appearing in Spanish individualist anarchist groups. &quot; Along with feverish activity against the social order, (Albert) Libertad was usually also organizing feasts, dances and country excursions, in consequence of his vision of anarchism as the “ joy of living ” and not as militant sacrifice and death instinct, seeking to reconcile the requirements of the individual (in his need for autonomy) with the need to destroy authoritarian society. &quot; { “Machete” #1. &quot; Bonnot and the Evangelists &quot; } Anarchist naturism was promoted by Henri Zisly, Emile Gravelle and Georges Butaud. Butaud was an individualist &quot; partisan of the milieux libres, publisher of &quot; Flambeau &quot; ( &quot; an enemy of authority &quot; ) in 1901 in Vienna. Most of his energies were devoted to creating anarchist colonies (communautés expérimentales) in which he participated in several. { http://www.eskimo.com/~recall/bleed/0226.htm &quot; 1926 -- France: Georges Butaud (1868-1926) dies, in Ermont. &quot; } &quot; In this sense, the theoretical positions and the vital experiences of french individualism are deeply iconoclastic and scandalous, even within libertarian circles. The call of nudist naturism, the strong defence of bith control methods, the idea of &quot; unions of egoists &quot; with the sole justification of sexual practices, that will try to put in practice, not without difficulties, will establish a way of thought and action, and will result in symphathy within some, and a strong rejection within others. &quot; { &quot; La insumisión voluntaria. El anarquismo individualista español durante la dictadura y la Segunda República &quot; by Xavier Díez } { Albert Libertad } French individualist anarchist s grouped behind Emile Armand, published L&apos;Unique after World War II. L&apos;Unique went from 1945 to 1956 with a total of 110 numbers. { Émile Armand in A las barricadas.com } { http://www.la-presse-anarchiste.net/spip.php?rubrique1 Unique, L&apos; (1945 - 1956) } Within the synthesist anarchist organization, the Fédération Anarchiste, there existed an individualist anarchist tendency alongside anarcho-communist and anarchosyndicalist currents. { &quot; Pensée et action des anarchistes en France : 1950-1970 &quot; by Cédric GUÉRIN } Individualist anarchists participating inside the Fédération Anarchiste included Charles-Auguste Bontemps, Georges Vincey and André Arru. The new base principles of the francophone Anarchist Federation were written by Charles-Auguste Bontemps and the anarcho-communist Maurice Joyeux which established an organization with a plurality of tendencies and autonomy of federated groups organized around synthesist principles. { &quot; Charles-Auguste Bontemps &quot; at Ephemeride Anarchiste } Charles-Auguste Bontemps was a prolific author mainly in the anarchist, freethinking, pacifist and naturist press of the time. His view on anarchism was based around his concept of &quot; Social Individualism &quot; on which he wrote extensively. He defended an anarchist perspective which consisted on &quot; a collectivism of things and an individualism of persons. &quot; { &quot; BONTEMPS Auguste, Charles, Marcel dit « Charles-Auguste »; « CHAB »; « MINXIT » &quot; at &apos;&apos;Dictionnaire International des Militants Anarchistes&apos;&apos; } In 2002, an anarchist, Libertad organized a new version of the L&apos;EnDehors, collaborating with Green Anarchy and including several contributors, such as Lawrence Jarach, Patrick Mignard, Thierry Lodé, Ron Sakolsky, and Thomas Slut. Numerous articles about capitalism, human rights, free love and social fights were published. The EnDehors continues now as a website, EnDehors.org. The prolific contemporary French philosopher Michel Onfray has been writing from an individualist anarchist { &quot; Au-delà, l’éthique et la politique de Michel Onfray font signe vers l’anarchisme individualiste de la Belle Epoque qui est d’ailleurs une de ses références explicites. &quot; &quot; Individualité et rapports à l&apos;engagement militant Individualite et rapports a l engageme &quot;.. par : Pereira Irène } perspective influenced by Nietzsche, French post-structuralists thinkers such as Michel Foucault and Gilles Deleuze; and Greek classical schools of philosophy such as the Cynics and Cyrenaics. Among the books which best expose Onfray&apos;s individualist anarchist perspective include La sculpture de soi : la morale esthétique (The sculpture of oneself: aesthetic morality), La philosophie féroce : exercices anarchistes, La puissance d&apos;exister and Physiologie de Georges Palante, portrait d&apos;un nietzchéen de gauche which focuses on French individualist philosopher Georges Palante. [ Illegalism ] [ Illegalism ] { Bonnot gang } Illegalism is an anarchist philosophy that developed primarily in France, Italy, Belgium, and Switzerland during the early 1900s as an outgrowth of Stirner&apos;s individualist anarchism. { &quot; Parallel to the social, collectivist anarchist current there was an individualist one whose partisans emphasized their individu�al freedom and advised other individuals to do the same. Individualist anarchist activity spanned the full spectrum of alternatives to authoritarian society, subverting it by undermining its way of life facet by facet. &quot; Thus theft, counterfeiting, swindling and robbery became a way of life for hundreds of individual�ists, as it was already for countless thousands of proletarians. The wave of anarchist bombings and assassinations of the 1890s (Auguste Vaillant, Ravachol, Emile Henry, Sante Caserio) and the practice of illegalism from the mid-1880s to the start of the First World War (Clément Duval, Pini, Marius Jacob, the Bonnot gang) were twin aspects of the same proletarian offensive, but were expressed in an individualist practice, one that complemented the great collective struggles against capital. &quot; } Illegalists usually did not seek moral basis for their actions, recognizing only the reality of &quot; might &quot; rather than &quot; right &quot;; for the most part, illegal acts were done simply to satisfy personal desires, not for some greater ideal, although some committed crimes as a form of propaganda of the deed. The illegalists embraced direct action and propaganda of the deed. { http://recollectionbooks.com/siml/library/illegalistsDougImrie.htm } Influenced by theorist Max Stirner&apos;s egoism as well as Proudhon (his view that Property is theft! ), Clément Duval and Marius Jacob proposed the theory of la reprise individuelle (Eng: individual reclamation ) which justified robbery on the rich and personal direct action against exploiters and the system., Illegalism first rose to prominence among a generation of Europeans inspired by the unrest of the 1890s, during which Ravachol, Émile Henry, Auguste Vaillant, and Caserio committed daring crimes in the name of anarchism, { &quot; Pre-WWI France was the setting for the only documented anarchist revolutionary movement to embrace all illegal activity as revolutionary practice. Pick-pocketing, theft from the workplace, robbery, confidence scams, desertion from the armed forces, you name it, illegalist activity was praised as a justifiable and necessary aspect of class struggle. &quot; &quot; Illegalism &quot; by Rob los Ricos } in what is known as propaganda of the deed. France&apos;s Bonnot Gang was the most famous group to embrace illegalism. [ Italy ] { Renzo Novatore } { In } Italy individualist anarchism had a strong tendency towards illegalism and violent propaganda by the deed similar to French individualist anarchism but perhaps more extreme { &quot; anarco-individualismo &quot; in italian anarchopedia } { &quot; At this point, encouraged by the disillusionment that followed the breakdown of the general strike, the terrorist individualists who had always -- despite Malatesta&apos;s influence -- survived as a small minority among Italian anarchists, intervened frightfully and tragically. &quot; } { George Woodcock. Anarchism: A History of Libertarian Ideas and Movements. 1962. } which emphazised criticism of organization be it anarchist or of other type. { &quot; in a dispute with the individualist anarchists of } { Paterson, who insisted that anarchism implied no organization at all, and that every man must act solely on his impulses. At last, in one noisy debate, the individual impulse of a certain Ciancabilla directed him to shoot Malatesta, who was badly wounded but obstinately refused to name his assailant. &quot; } { George Woodcock. Anarchism: A History of Libertarian Ideas and Movements. 1962 } In this respect we can consider notorious magnicides carried out or attempted by individualists Giovanni Passannante, Sante Caserio, Michele Angiolillo, Luigi Luccheni, Gaetano Bresci who murdered king Umberto I. Caserio lived in France and coexisted within French illegalism and later assassinated French president Sadi Carnot. The theoretical seeds of current Insurrectionary anarchism were already laid out at the end of 19th century Italy in a combination of individualist anarchism criticism of permanent groups and organization with a socialist class struggle worldview. { &quot; Essa trova soprattutto in America del Nord un notevole seguito per opera del Galleani che esprime una sintesi fra l&apos;istanza puramente individualista di stampo anglosassone e americano (ben espressa negli scritti di Tucker) e quella profondamente socialista del movimento anarchico di lingua italiana. Questa commistione di elementi individualisti e comunisti - che caratterizza bene la corrente antiorganizzatrice - rappresenta lo sforzo di quanti avvertirono in modo estremamente sensibile l&apos;invadente burocratismo che pervadeva il movimento operaio e socialista. &quot; &quot; anarchismo insurrezionale &quot; in italian anarchopedia } During the rise of fascism this thought also motivated Gino Lucetti, Michele Schirru and Angelo Sbardellotto in attempting the assassination of Benito Mussolini. During the early 20th century, the intellectual work of individualist anarchist Renzo Novatore came to importance; he was influenced by Stirner, Friedrich Nietzsche, Georges Palante, Oscar Wilde, Henrik Ibsen, Arthur Schopenhauer and Charles Baudelaire. He collaborated in numerous anarchist journals and participated in futurism avant-garde currents. In his thought, he adhered to Stirnerist disrespect for private property, only recognizing property of one&apos;s own spirit. &quot; Novatore non era contrario all&apos;abolizione della proprietà privata, poichè riteneva che l&apos;unica proprietà inviolabile fosse solo quella spirituale ed etica. Il suo pensiero è esplicitato in &quot; Verso il nulla creatore &quot; : { Bisogna che tutto ciò che si chiama &quot; proprietà materiale &quot;, &quot; proprietà privata &quot;, &quot; proprietà esteriore &quot; diventi per gli individui ciò che è il sole, la luce, il cielo, il mare, le stelle. E ciò avverrà!Avverrà perchè noi - gli iconoclasti - la violenteremo!Solo la ricchezza etica espirituale è invulnerabile. E&apos; vera proprietà dell&apos;individuo. Il resto no! Il resto è vulnerabile! E tutto ciò che è vulnerabile sarà vulnerato. &quot; &quot; Renzo Novatore &quot; in italian anarchopedia } Novatore collaborated in the individualist anarchist journal Iconoclasta! alongside the young stirner ist illegalist Bruno Filippi { &apos;&apos;The rebel&apos;s dark laughter: the writings of Bruno Filippi&apos;&apos; } The individualist philosopher and poet Renzo Novatore belonged to the leftist section of the avant-garde movement of Futurism { Novatore: una biografia } alongside other individualist anarcho-futurists such as Dante Carnesecchi, Leda Rafanelli, Auro d&apos;Arcola, and Giovanni Governato. Also there was Pietro Bruzzi who published the journal L&apos;Individualista in the 1920s alongside Ugo Fedeli and Francesco Ghezzi but who fell to fascist forces later. { &quot; L’Indivi-dualista &quot; � } { &quot; Pietro Bruzzi &quot; at italian anarchopedia } Pietro Bruzzi also collaborated with the Italian American individualist anarchist publication Eresia of New York City edited by Enrico Arrigoni. In Italy in 1945, during the Founding Congress of the Italian Anarchist Federation, there was a group of individualist anarchists led by Cesare Zaccaria { http://ita.anarchopedia.org/Storia_del_movimento_libertario_in_Italia &quot; Storia del movimento libertario in Italia &quot; in anarchopedia in Italian } who was an important anarchist of the time. { http://www.katesharpleylibrary.net/73n6nh Cesare Zaccaria (19 August 1897-October 1961)Pier Carlo Masini and Paul Sharkey } Later, during the IX Congress of the Italian Anarchist Federation in Carrara in 1965, a group decided to split off from this organization and created the Gruppi di Iniziativa Anarchica. In the seventies, it was mostly composed of &quot; veteran individualist anarchists with an of pacifism orientation, naturism, etc,... &quot;. { &quot; Los anarco-individualistas, G.I.A...Una escisión de la FAI producida en el IX Congreso (Carrara, 1965) se pr odujo cuando un sector de anarquistas de tendencia humanista rechazan la interpretación que ellos juzgan disciplinaria del &apos;&apos;pacto asociativo &quot; clásico, y crean los GIA (Gruppi di Iniziativa Anarchica). Esta pequeña federación de grupos, hoy nutrida sobre todo de veteranos anarco-individualistas de orientación pacifista, naturista, etcétera defiende la autonomía personal y rechaza a rajatabla toda forma de intervención en los procesos del sistema, como sería por ejemplo el sindicalismo. Su portavoz es L&apos;Internazionale con sede en Ancona. La escisión de los GIA prefiguraba, en sentido contrario, el gran debate que pronto había de comenzar en el seno del movimiento &quot; &quot; El movimiento libertario en Italia &quot; by &apos;&apos;Bicicleta. REVISTA DE COMUNICACIONES LIBERTARIAS&apos;&apos; Year 1 No. Noviembre, 1 1977 } In the famous Italian insurrectionary anarchist essay written by an anonymous writer, &quot; At Daggers Drawn with the Existent, its Defenders and its False Critics &quot;, there reads &quot; The workers who, during a wildcat strike, carried a banner saying, &apos;We are not asking for anything&apos; understood that the defeat is in the claim itself (&apos;the claim against the enemy is eternal&apos;). There is no alternative but to take everything. As Stirner said: &apos;No matter how much you give them, they will always ask for more, because what they want is no less than the end of every concession&apos;. &quot; { &quot; At Daggers Drawn with the Existent, its Defenders and its False Critics &quot; by anonymous } The contemporary imprisoned Italian insurrectionary anarchist philosopher Michele Fabiani writes from an explicit individualist anarchist perspective in such essays as &quot; Critica individualista anarchica alla modernità &quot; (Individualist anarchist critique of modernity) { &quot; Critica individualista anarchica alla modernità &quot; by Michele Fabiani } [ Spain ] While Spain was influenced by American individualist anarchism, it was more closely related to the French currents. At the turn of the century, individualism in Spain gathered force through the efforts of people such as Dorado Montero, Ricardo Mella, Federico Urales, Miguel Gimenez Igualada, Mariano Gallardo, and J. Elizalde who translated French and American individualists. Important in this respect were also magazines such as La Idea Libre, La revista blanca, Etica, Iniciales, Al margen, Estudios and Nosotros. The most influential thinkers there were Max Stirner, Emile Armand and Han Ryner. Just as in France, the spread of Esperanto and anationalism had importance just as naturism and free love currents. Later, Armand and Ryner themselves started writing in the Spanish invidualist press. Armand&apos;s concept of amorous camaraderie had an important role in motivating polyamory as realization of the individual. Catalan historian Xavier Diez reports that the Spanish individualist anarchist press was widely read by members of anarcho-communist groups and by members of the anarcho-syndicalist trade union CNT. There were also the cases of prominent individualist anarchists such as Federico Urales and Miguel Gimenez Igualada who were members of the CNT and J. Elizalde who was a founding member and first secretary of the Iberian Anarchist Federation. { Xavier Diez. El anarquismo individualista en España: 1923-1938. ISBN 978-84-96044-87-6 } Spanish individualist anarchist Miguel Giménez Igualada wrote the lengthy theory book called Anarchism espousing his individualist anarchism. { &apos;&apos;Anarquismo&apos;&apos; por [[Miguel Gimenez Igualada ]] } Between October 1937 and February 1938 he was editor of the individualist anarchist magazine Nosotros, { &quot; La insumisión voluntaira: El anarquismo individualista español durante la dictadura y la segunda reppública (1923-1938) por Xavier Diez } in which many works of Han Ryner and Émile Armand appeared. He also participated in the publishing of another individualist anarchist maganize Al Margen: Publicación quincenal individualista. { &quot; Entre los redactores y colaboradores de Al Margen, que trasladará su redacción a Elda, en Alicante, encontraremos a Miguel Giménez Igualada... &quot; La insumisión voluntaira: El anarquismo individualista español durante la dictadura y la segunda reppública(1923-1938) por Xavier Diez } In his youth he engaged in illegalist activities. { Xavier Diez. &apos;&apos;L&apos;ANARQUISME INDIVIDUALISTA A ESPANYA 1923-1938&apos;&apos; } His thought was deeply influenced by Max Stirner, of which he was the main popularizer in Spain through his own writings. He published and wrote the preface to the fourth edition in Spanish of The Ego and Its Own from 1900. He proposed the creation of a Union of Egoists, to be a Federation of Individualist Anarchists in Spain, but did not succeed. { &quot; A partir de la década de los treinta, su pensamiento empieza a derivar hacia el individualismo, y como profundo estirneriano tratará de impulsar una federación de individualistas &quot; &quot; La insumisión voluntaira: El anarquismo individualista español durante la dictadura y la segunda reppública(1923-1938) por Xavier Diez } In 1956 he published an extensive treatise on Stirner, dedicated to fellow individualist anarchist Emile Armand { &quot; Stirner &quot; por Miguel Gimenez Igualada } Afterwards he traveled and lived in Argentina, Uruguay and Mexico. Federico Urales was an important individualist anarchist who edited La Revista Blanca. The individualist anarchism of Urales was influenced by Auguste Comte and Charles Darwin. He saw science and reason as a defense against blind servitude to authority. He was critical of influential individualist thinkers such as Nietzsche and Stirner for promoting an asocial egoist individualism and instead promoted an individualism with solidarity seen as a way to guarantee social equality and harmony. He was highly critical of anarcho-syndicalism, which he viewed as plagued by excessive bureaucracy, and thought that it tended towards reformism. Instead he favored small groups based on ideological alignement. He supported and participated in the establishment of the Iberian Anarchist Federation (FAI) in 1927. In 1956, on exile escaping from Franco´s dictatorship Miguel Giménez Igualada published an extensive treatise on Stirner which he dedicated to fellow individualist anarchist Emile Armand On the subject of individualist anarchist theory, he publisheds Anarchism in 1968, during his exile in Mexico from Franco&apos;s dictatorship in Spain. { &apos;&apos;Anarquismo&apos;&apos; by Miguel Gimenez Igualada } He was present in the First Congress of the Mexican Anarchist Federation in 1945. { Miguel Gimenez Igualada. &apos;&apos;Anarquismo&apos;&apos; } In 2000, in Spain Ateneo Libertario Ricardo Mella, Ateneo libertario Al Margen, Ateneu Enciclopèdic Popular, Ateneo Libertario de Sant Boi, Ateneu Llibertari Poble Sec y Fundació D&apos;Estudis Llibertaris i Anarcosindicalistes republished Emile Armand&apos;s writings on Free Love and individualist anarchism in a compilation titled Individualist anarchism and Amorous camaraderie. { &apos;&apos;Individualismo anarquista y camaradería amorosa&apos;&apos; by [[Emile Armand ]] } Recently Catalan historian Xavier Diez has dedicated extensive research on Spanish individualist anarchism as can be seen in his books El anarquismo individualista en España: 1923-1938 { &apos;&apos;El anarquismo individualista en España.&apos;&apos; by Xavier Diez } and Utopia sexual a la premsa anarquista de Catalunya. La revista Ética-Iniciales(1927–1937) (which deals with free love thought as present in the Spanish individualist anarchist magazine Iniciales ). { Utopía sexual a la premsa anarquista de Catalunya:La revista Ética-Iniciales (1927-1937) por Xavier Díez } [ Germany ] { John Henry Mackay } { In } Germany, the Scottish-German John Henry McKay became the most important propagandist for individualist anarchist ideas. He fused Stirnerist egoism with the positions of Benjamin Tucker and actually translated Tucker into German. Two semi-fictional writings of his own, Die Anarchisten and Der Freiheitsucher, contributed to individualist theory through an updating of egoist themes within a consideration of the anarchist movement. English translations of these works arrived in the United Kingdom and in individualist American circles led by Tucker. { &quot; New England Anarchism in Germany &quot; by Thomas A. Riley } McKay is also known as an important European early activist for Gay rights. Using the pseudonym Sagitta, Mackay wrote a series of works for pederastic emancipation, titled Die Buecher der namenlosen Liebe (Books of the Nameless Love). This series was conceived in 1905 and completed in 1913 and included the Fenny Skaller, a story of a pederast. { thamyris 02 } Under the same pseudonym he also published fiction, such as Holland (1924) and a pederastic novel of the Berlin boy-bars, Der Puppenjunge (The Hustler) (1926). { Der Eigene &apos;&apos; } { stirner ist pioneer Gay activist publication } Adolf Brand (1874–1945) was a German writer, stirner ist anarchist and pioneering campaigner for the acceptance of male bisexuality and homosexuality. Brand published a German homosexual periodical, Der Eigene in 1896. This was the first ongoing homosexual publication in the world. { Karl Heinrich Ulrichs had begun a journal called Prometheus in 1870, but only one issue was published. (Kennedy, Hubert, Karl Heinrich Ulrichs: First Theorist of Homosexuality, In: &apos;Science and Homosexualities&apos;, ed. Vernon Rosario pp. 26–45). New York: Routledge, 1997. } The name was taken from writings of egoist philosopher Max Stirner, who had greatly influenced the young Brand, and refers to Stirner&apos;s concept of &quot; self-ownership &quot; of the individual. Der Eigene concentrated on cultural and scholarly material, and may have had an average of around 1500 subscribers per issue during its lifetime, although the exact numbers are uncertain. Contributors included Erich Mühsam, Kurt Hiller, John Henry Mackay (under the pseudonym Sagitta) and artists Wilhelm von Gloeden, Fidus and Sascha Schneider. Brand contributed many poems and articles himself. Benjamin Tucker followed this journal from the United States. { &quot; Among the egoist papers that Tucker followed were the German } { Der Eigene, edited by } { Adolf Brand... &quot; http://oll.libertyfund.org/index.php?option=com_content &amp; task=view &amp; id=796 &amp; Itemid=259 &quot; Benjamin Tucker and Liberty: A Bibliographical Essay &quot; by Wendy McElroy } Der Einzige was a German individualist anarchist magazine. It appeared in 1919, as a weekly, then sporadically until 1925 and was edited by cousins Anselm Ruest (pseud. for Ernst Samuel) and Mynona (pseud. for Salomo Friedlaender ). Its title was adopted from the book Der Einzige und sein Eigentum (engl. trans. The Ego and Its Own ) by Max Stirner. Another influence was the thought of German philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche. { Constantin Parvulescu. &apos;&apos; &quot; Der Einzige &quot; and the making of the radical Left in the early post-World War I Germany&apos;&apos;. University of Minnesota. 2006] } The publication was connected to the local expressionist artistic current and the transition from it towards dada. { &quot;...the dadaist objections to Hiller´s activism werethemselves present in expressionism as demonstrated by the seminal roles played by the philosophies of } { Otto Gross and Salomo Friedlaender &quot;. The Irish anarchist writer of the Decadent movement Oscar Wilde influenced individualist anarchists such as Renzo Novatore { &quot; We must kill the christian philosophy in the most radical sense of the word. Tucker, in fact, published an American edition. From its early championing of Walt Whitman&apos;s Leaves of Grass to a series of short stories by Francis du Bosque in its last issues, Liberty was a vehicle of controversial, avant-garde literature. &quot; &quot; Benjamin Tucker, Individualism, &amp; Liberty: Not the Daughter but the Mother of Order &quot; by Wendy McElroy } In his important essay The Soul of Man under Socialism from 1891 he defended socialism as the way to guarantee individualism and so he saw that &quot; With the abolition of private property, then, we shall have true, beautiful, healthy Individualism. Nobody will waste his life in accumulating things, and the symbols for things. One will live. To live is the rarest thing in the world. In the late 19th century in the United Kingdom, there existed individualist anarchists such as Wordsworth Donisthorpe, Joseph Hiam Levy, Joseph Greevz Fisher, John Badcock, Jr., Albert Tarn, and Henry Seymour { &quot; The English Individualists As They Appear In Liberty &quot; by Carl Watner } who were close to the United States group around Benjamin Tucker ´s magazine Liberty. In the mid 1880s Seymour published a journal called The Anarchist. and also later took a special interest in free love as he participated in the journal The Adult: A Journal for the Advancement of Freedom in Sexual Relationships. &quot; The Serpent, issued from London...the most prominent English-language egoist journal, was published from 1898 to 1900 with the subtitle &apos;A Journal of Egoistic Philosophy and Sociology&apos; &quot;. { McElroy, Wendy. &quot; Benjamin Tucker and Liberty: A Bibliographical Essay by Wendy McElroy &quot; } Henry Meulen was another British anarchist, he was notable for his support of free banking. Liverpool University Press. 1998. p. 190. } Albert Camus devoted a section of &apos;&apos;The Rebel&apos;&apos; to Stirner. &quot; Although throughout his book Camus is concerned to present &quot; the rebel &quot; as a preferred alternative to &quot; the revolutionary &quot; he nowhere acknowledges that this distinction is taken from the one that Stirner makes between &quot; the revolutionary &quot; and &quot; the insurrectionist &quot;. { &quot; The Egoism of Max Stirner &quot; by Sidney Parker } Sidney Parker is a British egoist individualist anarchist who wrote articles and edited anarchist journals from 1963 to 1993 such as Minus One, Egoist, and Ego. { &quot; Sid Parker &quot; by nonserviam.com } In the hybrid of post-structuralism and anarchism called post-anarchism the British Saul Newman has written a lot on Stirner and his similarities to post-structuralism. He writes: Max Stirner&apos;s impact on contemporary political theory is often neglected. However in Stirner&apos;s political thinking there can be found a surprising convergence with poststructuralist theory, particularly with regard to the function of power. Andrew Koch, for instance, sees Stirner as a thinker who transcends the Hegelian tradition he is usually placed in, arguing that his work is a precursor poststructuralist ideas about the foundations of knowledge and truth. { &quot; War on the State: Stirner and Deleuze&apos;s Anarchism &quot; by [[Saul Newman ]] } Newman has published several essays on Stirner. &quot; War on the State: Stirner and Deleuze&apos;s Anarchism &quot; and &quot; Empiricism, pluralism, and politics in Deleuze and Stirner &quot; { &quot; Empiricism, pluralism, and politics in Deleuze and Stirner &quot; by Saul Newman } discusses what he sees are similarities between Stirner&apos;s thought and that of Gilles Deleuze. In &quot; Spectres of Stirner: a Contemporary Critique of Ideology &quot; he discusses the conception of ideology in Stirner. { &quot; Spectres of Stirner: a Contemporary Critique of Ideology &quot; } In &quot; Stirner and Foucault: Toward a Post-Kantian Freedom &quot; similarities between Stirner and Michel Foucault. { &quot; Stirner and Foucault: Toward a Post-Kantian Freedom } Also he wrote &quot; Politics of the ego: Stirner&apos;s critique of liberalism &quot;. { &quot; Politics of the ego: Stirner&apos;s critique of liberalism &quot; } [ Russia ] { Lev Chernyi } { Individualist } anarchism was one of the three categories of anarchism in Russia, along with the more prominent anarchist communism and anarcho-syndicalism. [ Paul Avrich Avrich Paul The Russian Anarchists AK Press Stirling 2006 1904859488 56 ] The ranks of the Russian individualist anarchists were predominantly drawn from the intelligentsia and the working class. For anarchist historian Paul Avrich &quot; The two leading exponents of individualist anarchism, both based in Moscow, were Aleksei Alekseevich Borovoi and Lev Chernyi (Pavel Dmitrievich Turchaninov). From Nietzsche, they inherited the desire for a complete overturn of all values accepted by bourgeois societypolitical, moral, and cultural. Furthermore, strongly influenced by Max Stirner and Benjamin Tucker, the German and American theorists of individualist anarchism, they demanded the total liberation of the human personality from the fetters of organized society. &quot; Some Russian individualists anarchists &quot; found the ultimate expression of their social alienation in violence and crime, others attached themselves to avant-garde literary and artistic circles, but the majority remained &quot; philosophical &quot; anarchists who conducted animated parlor discussions and elaborated their individualist theories in ponderous journals and books. &quot; Lev Chernyi was an important individualist anarchist involved in resistance against the rise to power of the Bolchevik Party. He adhered mainly to Stirner and the ideas of Benjamin Tucker. In 1907, he published a book entitled Associational Anarchism, in which he advocated the &quot; free association of independent individuals. &quot;. { &quot; Prominent Anarchists and Left-Libertarians &quot; } On his return from Siberia in 1917 he enjoyed great popularity among Moscow workers as a lecturer. Chernyi was also Secretary of the Moscow Federation of Anarchist Groups, which was formed in March 1917. He was an advocate &quot; for the seizure of private homes &quot;, which was an activity seen by the anarchists after the October revolution as direct expropriation on the bourgoise. He died after being accused of participation in an episode in which this group bombed the headquarters of the Moscow Committee of the Communist Party. Although most likely not being really involved in the bombing, he might have died of torture. Chernyi advocated a Nietzschean overthrow of the values of bourgeois Russian society, and rejected the voluntary communes of anarcho-communist Peter Kropotkin as a threat to the freedom of the individual. [ Avrich 2006 180 ] [ Avrich 2006 254 ] [ Chernyi Lev Novoe Napravlenie v Anarkhizme: Asosiatsionnii Anarkhism 1907 Moscow; 2nd 1923 New York ] Scholars including Avrich and Allan Antliff have interpreted this vision of society to have been greatly influenced by the individualist anarchist s Max Stirner, and Benjamin Tucker. [ Antliff Allan 2007 Anarchy, Power, and Poststructuralism SubStance 36 113 56–66 https://muse.jhu.edu/login?uri%3D%2Fjournals%2Fsubstance%2Fv036%2F36.2antliff.pdf 2008-03-10 10.1353/sub.2007.0026 harv ] Subsequent to the book&apos;s publication, Chernyi was imprisoned in Siberia under the Russian Czar ist regime for his revolutionary activities. [ Phillips Terry 1984 Fall The Match! http://recollectionbooks.com/bleed/Encyclopedia/ChernyiLev.htm 79 2008-03-10 Lev Chernyi harv ] On the other hand Aleksei Borovoi (1876?-1936) { http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=labadie;cc=labadie;view=toc;idno=2917084.0001.001 &quot; Anarchism and Law. &quot; on Anarchism Pamphlets in the Labadie Collection }., was a professor of philosophy at Moscow University, &quot; a gifted orator and the author of numerous books, pamphlets, and articles which attempted to reconcile individualist anarchism with the doctrines of syndicallism &quot;. He wrote among other theoretical works, Anarkhizm in 1918 just after the October revolution and Anarchism and Law. For him &quot; the chief importance is given not to Anarchism as the aim but to Anarchy as the continuous quest for the aim &quot;. { Alexei Borovoi (from individualism to the Platform) &quot; by Anatoly Dubovik } He manifests there that &quot; No social ideal, from the point of view of anarchism, could be referred to as absolute in a sense that supposes it’s the crown of human wisdom, the end of social and ethical quest of man. &quot; [ Latin American individualist anarchism ] Argentine anarchist historian Angel Cappelletti reports that in Argentina &quot; Among the workers that came from Europe in the 2 first decades of the century, there was curiously some stirnerian individualists influenced by the philosophy of Nietzsche, that saw syndicalism as a potential enemy of anarchist ideology. They established... affinity groups that in 1912 came to, according to Max Nettlau, to the number of 20. In 1911 there appeared, in Colón, the periodical El Único, that defined itself as ´Publicación individualista´ &quot;. { &apos;&apos;El Anarquismo en América Latina&apos;&apos; por Carlos M. Rama y Ángel J. Cappellett. pg. CLVII } { Biofilo Panclasta, } { Colombian } { stirner ist } Vicente Rojas Lizcano whose pseudonym was Biófilo Panclasta, was a Colombian individualist anarchist writer and activist. In 1904 he begins using the name Biofilo Panclasta. &quot; Biofilo &quot; in Spanish stands for &quot; lover of life &quot; and &quot; Panclasta &quot; for &quot; enemy of all &quot;. { PANCLASTA, Biófilo (1928): Comprimidos psicológicos de los revolucionarios criollos. Periódico Claridad, Bogotá, Nº 52, 53, 54, 55 y 56. } He visited more than fifty countries propagandizing for anarchism which in his case was highly influenced by the thought of Max Stirner and Friedrich Nietszche. Among his written works there are Siete años enterrado vivo en una de las mazmorras de Gomezuela: Horripilante relato de un resucitado(1932) and Mis prisiones, mis destierros y mi vida (1929) which talk about his many adventures while living his life as an adventurer, activist and vagabond, as well as his thought and the many times he was imprisoned in different countries. { Maria Lacerda de Moura individualist } { anarcha-feminist } Maria Lacerda de Moura was a Brazil ian teacher, journalist, anarcha-feminist, and individualist anarchist. Her ideas regarding education were largely influenced by Francisco Ferrer. She later moved to São Paulo and became involved in journalism for the anarchist and labor press. There she also lectured on topics including education, women&apos;s rights, free love, and antimilitarism. Her writings and essays garnered her attention not only in Brazil, but also in Argentina and Uruguay. In February 1923, she launched Renascença, a periodical linked with the anarchist, progressive, and freethinking circles of the period. Her thought was mainly influenced by individualist anarchist s such as Han Ryner and Emile Armand. She maintained contact with Spanish individualist anarchist circles. During the 1990s in Argentina, there appeared a stirner ist publication called El Único: publicacion periódica de pensamiento individualista. { El Único: publicacion periódica de pensamiento individualista } { Argentinian anarchist periodicals in R.A. Forum. } { &apos;&apos;Bitácora de la Utopía: Anarquismo para el Siglo XXI&apos;&apos; by Nelson Méndez and Alfredo Vallota } [ Criticisms ] { distribution of wealth under individualist anarchism. } [ Criticisms of anarchism ] Philosopher Murray Bookchin criticized individualist anarchism for its opposition to democracy and its embrace of &quot; lifestylism &quot; at the expense of class struggle. [ Bookchin Murray Social Anarchism or Lifestyle Anarchism AK Press Stirling 1995 9781873176832 ] Bookchin claimed that individualist anarchism supports only negative liberty and rejects the idea of positive liberty. { Bookchin, Murray. &quot; Communalism: The Democratic Dimensions of Social Anarchism &quot;. Anarchism, Marxism and the Future of the Left: Interviews and Essays, 1993-1998. } { AK Press, 1999, p. 155 } Philosopher Albert Meltzer proposed that individualist anarchism differs radically from revolutionary anarchism, and that it &quot; is sometimes too readily conceded &apos;that this is, after all, anarchism&apos;. &quot; He claimed that Benjamin Tucker &apos;s acceptance of the use of a private police force (including to break up violent strikes to protect the &quot; employer&apos;s &apos;freedom&apos; &quot; ) is contradictory to the definition of anarchism as &quot; no government. &quot; { Meltzer, Albert. Anarchism: Arguments For and Against. AK Press, 2000. pp. 114-115 } Philosopher George Bernard Shaw initially had flirtations with individualist anarchism before coming to the conclusion that it was &quot; the negation of socialism, and is, in fact, unsocialism carried as near to its logical conclusion as any sane man dare carry it. &quot; Shaw&apos;s argument was that even if wealth was initially distributed equally, the degree of laissez-faire advocated by Tucker would result in the distribution of wealth becoming unequal because it would permit private appropriation and accumulation. { Griffith, Gareth. Socialism and Superior Brain: The Political Thought of George Bernard Shaw. Routledge (UK). 1993. p. 310 } According to academic Carlotta Anderson, American individualist anarchists accept that free competition results in unequal wealth distribution, but they &quot; do not see that as an injustice. &quot; { Anderson, Carlotta R. All-American Anarchist: Joseph A. Labadie and the Labor Movement, Wayne State University Press, 1998, p. 250 } Tucker explained, &quot; If I go through life free and rich, I shall not cry because my neighbor, equally free, is richer. Liberty will ultimately make all men rich; it will not make all men equally rich. Authority may (and may not) make all men equally rich in purse; it certainly will make them equally poor in all that makes life best worth living. &quot; { Tucker, Benjamin. Economic Rent. } [ See also ] [ Anarchism ] Individualist anarchism in Europe Individualist anarchism in France Existentialist anarchism [ Bibliography ] Diez, Xavier. &apos;&apos;El anarquismo individualista en España (1923-1939)&apos;&apos;. Some sources, such as An Anarchist FAQ use the classification &quot; social anarchism / individualist anarchism &quot;. Some see individualist anarchism as distinctly non-socialist, and use the classification &quot; socialist anarchism / individualist anarchism &quot; accordingly. { Ostergaard, Geoffrey. &quot; Anarchism &quot;. The Blackwell Dictionary of Modern Social Thought. Blackwell Publishing. p. 14. } Other classifications include &quot; mutualist/communal &quot; anarchism. { Carson, Kevin, &quot; A Mutualist FAQ &quot;. } β [ B β none ] Michael Freeden identifies four broad type s of individualist anarchism. He says the first is the type associated with William Godwin that advocates self-government with a &quot; progressive rationalism that included benevolence to others. &quot; The second type is the amoral self-serving rationality of Egoism, as most associated with Max Stirner. The third type is &quot; found in Herbert Spencer &apos;s early predictions, and in that of some of his disciples such as Donisthorpe, foreseeing the redundancy of the state in the source of social evolution. &quot; The fourth type retains a moderated form of egoism and accounts for social cooperation through the advocacy of market relationships. γ [ C γ none ] See, for example, the Winter 2006 issue of the Journal of Libertarian Studies, dedicated to reviews of Kevin Carson&apos;s Studies in Mutualist Political Economy. Mutualists compose one bloc, along with agorists and geo-libertarians, in the recently formed Alliance of the Libertarian Left. δ [ D δ none ] Though this term is non-standard usage – by &quot; left &quot;, agorists mean &quot; left &quot; in the general sense used by left-libertarians, as defined by Roderick T. Long, as &quot;... an integration, or I&apos;d argue, a reintegration of libertarianism with concerns that are traditionally thought of as being concerns of the left. That includes concerns for worker empowerment, worry about plutocracy, concerns about feminism and various kinds of social equality. &quot; { Long, Roderick. T. local dialing 02 } Jerusalem ( [ icon dʒ ə ˈ r uː s ə l əm ]; [ יְרוּשָׁלַיִם ] [ he Yerushaláyim ] [ He-Jerusalem.ogg no   ]; [ القُدس ] [ ar al-Quds ] [ ArAlquds.ogg no   ] and/or [ ar أورشليم ] &apos;&apos; [ ar Ûrshalîm ] ) [ names i ] is the capital of Israel, though not internationally recognized as such, [ capital ii ] and one of the oldest cities in the world. It is located in the Judean Mountains, between the Mediterranean Sea and the northern edge of the Dead Sea. Today, the status of Jerusalem remains one of the core issues in the Israeli–Palestinian conflict. During the 1948 Arab-Israeli War, West Jerusalem was among the areas captured and later annexed by Israel, while East Jerusalem, including the Old City, was captured by Jordan. Israel captured East Jerusalem during the 1967 Six-Day War and subsequently annexed it. Currently, Israel&apos;s Basic Law refers to Jerusalem as the country&apos;s &quot; undivided capital &quot;. The international community has rejected the annexation as illegal and treats East Jerusalem as Palestinian territory held by Israel under military occupation. [ http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-11709617 Israel plans 1,300 East Jerusalem Jewish settler homes BBC News 9 November 2010 East Jerusalem is regarded as occupied Palestinian territory by the international community, but Israel says it is part of its territory. ] { Israeli authorities back 600 new East Jerusalem homes BBC 26 February 2010 } { Resolution 298 September 25, 1971: &quot; Recalling its resolutions... concerning measures and actions by Israel designed to change the status of the Israeli-occupied section of Jerusalem,... &quot; } The international community does not recognize Jerusalem as Israel&apos;s capital, and the city hosts no foreign embassies. According to the Palestinian Central Bureau of Statistics, 208,000 Palestinians live in East Jerusalem, which is sought by the Palestinian Authority as a future capital of a future Palestinian state. [ http://www.publicpolicy.umd.edu/IPPP/Fall97Report/negotiating_jerusalem.htm Segal Jerome M. The University of Maryland School of Public Policy Negotiating Jerusalem 25 February 2007 Fall 1997 http://web.archive.org/web/20060514191731/http%3A//www.publicpolicy.umd.edu/IPPP/Fall97Report/negotiating_jerusalem.htm 14 May 2006 ] [ Møller, Bjørn A Cooperative Structure for Israeli-Palestinian Relations Working Paper No. 1 Centre for European Policy Studies November 2002 http://shop.ceps.be/downfree.php?item_id%3D171 PDF 16 April 2007 http://web.archive.org/web/20040106192631/http%3A//shop.ceps.be/downfree.php?item_id%3D171 6 January 2004 ] [ Press Associated http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid%3D1202246355071%26amp%3Bpagename%3DJPost%2FJPArticle%2FShowFull Palestinians grow by a million in decade Fr.jpost.com 2008-02-09 2011-10-17 ] All branches of the Israeli government are located in Jerusalem, including the Knesset (Israel&apos;s parliament), the residences of the Prime Minister and President, and the Supreme Court. Jerusalem is home to the Hebrew University and to the Israel Museum with its Shrine of the Book. The Jerusalem Biblical Zoo has ranked consistently as Israel&apos;s top tourist attraction for Israelis. [ Rosenblum Irit http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/843385.html Haareez Biblical Zoo favorite tourist site in 2006 Haaretz Israel 11 September 2010 ] [ Lis Jonathan http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/978314.html Jerusalem Zoo is Israel&apos;s number one tourist attraction Haaretz Israel 2011-09-09 ] [ Etymology ] [ Names of Jerusalem ] A city called Rušalimum or Urušalimum (Foundation of Shalem ) [ Jerusalem, the Holy City Binz Stephen J. 2005 Twenty-Third Publications Connecticut, USA. 2 http://books.google.co.il/books?id%3D7zLuDlzdTFYC%26amp%3Blpg%3DPP1%26amp%3Bdq%3DJerusalem%2C%2Bthe%2BHoly%2BCity%2BBy%2BStephen%2BJ.%2BBinz%26amp%3Bpg%3DPA2%26amp%3B%3Dfalse#v%3Donepage%26amp%3Bq%3DJerusalem%2C%20the%20Holy%20City%20By%20Stephen%20J.%20Binz%26amp%3Bf%3Dfalse 17 December 2011 ] appears in ancient Egyptian records as the first two references to Jerusalem, dating back to the 19th and 18th centuries BCE. { G.Johannes Botterweck, Helmer Ringgren (eds.) Theological Dictionary of the Old Testament, (tr.David E.Green) William B.Eerdmann, Grand Rapids Michigan, Cambridge, UK 1990, Vol. VI, p.348 } [ http://www.tau.ac.il/humanities/semitic/EA263-end.html &apos; &amp; #39;The El Amarna Letters from Canaan&apos; &amp; #39; Tau.ac.il 11 September 2010 ] The name recurs in Akkadian cuneiform as Urušalim, in the Amarna tablets datable to the 1400-1360 BCE. The name “Jerusalem” is variously etymologised to mean “foundation (Sumerian yeru, ‘settlement’/Semitic yry, ‘found’) of the god Shalem ”, ‘dwelling of peace’, ‘founded in safety’, { Marten H.Wouldstra, The Book of Joshua, William B.Eerdmanns Co. Grand Rapids, Michigan (1981) 1995 p.169 n.2 } or to mean ‘Salem gives instruction’ (yrh, ‘show, teach, instruct’). The god Shalem has a special relationship with Jerusalem. { G.Johannes Bottereck, Helmer Ringgren, Heinz-Josef Fabry, (eds.) Theological Dictionary of the Old Testament, tr. David E.Green, vol.XV, pp.48-49 William B.Eeerdmanns Co.Grand Rapids, Michigan/Cambridge UK 2006 pp.45-6 } Others dismiss the Sumerian link, and point to yarah, Semitic/Hebrew for ‘to lay a cornerstone’, yielding the idea of laying a cornerstone to the temple of the god Shalem, who was a member of the West Semitic pantheon (Akkadian Shalim, Assyrian Shulmanu), the god of the setting sun and the nether world, as well as of health and perfection. { Meir Ben-Dov, Historical Atlas of Jerusalem, Continuum International Publishing Group, 2002 p.23. } The form Yerushalayim (Jerusalem) first appears in the Bible, in the book of Joshua. This form has the appearance of a portmanteau (blend) of Yireh (an abiding place of the fear and the service of God) { &apos;&apos;The Legends of the Jews&apos;&apos; Volume 1 by Louis Ginzberg, Release Date: October, 1998 } The meaning of the common root S-L-M is unknown but is thought to refer to either &quot; peace &quot; (Salam or Shalom in modern Arabic and Hebrew) or Shalim, the god of dusk in the Canaanite religion. [ Jerusalem Elon Amos http://www.usna.edu/Users/history/tucker/hh362/telavivandjerusalem.htm 0-00-637531-6 26 April 2007 HarperCollins Publishers Ltd The epithet may have originated in the ancient name of Jerusalem—Salem (after the pagan deity of the city), which is etymologically connected in the Semitic languages with the words for peace (shalom in Hebrew, salam in Arabic). ] { Ringgren, H., Die Religionen des Alten Orients (Göttingen, 1979), 212. } The name gained the popular meanings &quot; The City of Peace &quot; [ A Dictionary of the Bible: Volume II: (Part II: I -- Kinsman), Volume 2 Hastings James James Hastings 2004 Reprinted from 1898 edition by University Press of the Pacific Honolulu, Hawaii 1-4102-1725-6 584 http://books.google.co.il/books?id%3D0wvtFPz03GsC%26amp%3Bpg%3DPA584%26amp%3Bdq%3Djerusalem%2Babode%2Bof%2Bpeace%26amp%3Bredir_esc%3Dy#v%3Donepage%26amp%3Bq%3Djerusalem%20abode%20of%20peace%26amp%3Bf%3Dfalse 17 December 2011 ] and &quot; Abode of Peace &quot;, [ Historic cities of the Islamic world Bosworth Clifford Edmund Clifford Edmund Bosworth 2007 Koninklijke Brill NV The Netherlands 90-04-15388-8 225–226 http://books.google.co.il/books?id%3DUB4uSVt3ulUC%26amp%3Bpg%3DPA226%26amp%3Bdq%3DJerusalem%2BAbode%2Bof%2BPeace%26amp%3Bredir_esc%3Dy#v%3Donepage%26amp%3Bq%3DJerusalem%20Abode%20of%20Peace%26amp%3Bf%3Dfalse 17 December 2011 ] [ http://centre4conflictstudies.org/wanderingthoughts/category/denise-degarmo/ Abode of Peace? Denise DeGarmo 9 September 2011 Wandering Thoughts Center for Conflict Studies 17 December 2011 ] alternately &quot; Vision of Peace &quot; in some Christian theology. [ Millennium: a Latin reader, A Bosworth Francis Edward 1968 Oxford University Press Oxford, United Kingdom B0000CO4LE 183 http://books.google.co.il/books?id%3D5sC2pJYlzbsC%26amp%3Bpg%3DPA183%26amp%3Bdq%3Djerusalem%2Babode%2Bof%2Bpeace%26amp%3Bredir_esc%3Dy#v%3Donepage%26amp%3Bq%3Djerusalem%20abode%20of%20peace%26amp%3Bf%3Dfalse 17 December 2011 ] Typically the ending -im indicates the plural in Hebrew grammar and -ayim the dual, thus leading to the suggestion that the name refers to the fact that the city sits on two hills. [ 0-405-10298-4 Wallace Edwin Sherman Jerusalem the Holy August 1977 16 A similar view was held by those who give the Hebrew dual to the word Arno Press New York ] [ Jerusalem: The Topography, Economics and History from the Earliest Times to A.D. 70 Smith George Adam 1907 Hodder and Stoughton 251 The termination -aim or -ayim used to be taken as the ordinary termination of the dual of nouns, and was explained as signifying the upper and lower cities 0-7905-2935-1 ] { (see here ) } However the pronunciation of the last syllable as -ayim appears to be a late development, which had not yet appeared at the time of the Septuagint. The most ancient settlement of Jerusalem, founded as early as the Bronze Age on the hill above the Gihon Spring, was according to the Bible named Jebus. { The Oxford encyclopedia of ancient Greece and Rome, Volume 1, p. 113 } It was renamed the City of David in the first millennium BCE, and was known by this name in antiquity. [ Bar-Kochva Bezalel 2002 Judas Maccabeus: The Jewish Struggle Against the Seleucids 447 http://books.google.com.au/books?id%3DSIKuW_bl6LAC%26amp%3Bpg%3DPA447 Cambridge, United Kingdom Cambridge University Press 0-521-01683-5 ] [ Mazar Eilat The Complete Guide to the Temple Mount Excavations 2002 Shoham Academic Research and Publication Jerusalem 965-90299-1-8 1 ] Another name, &quot; Zion &quot;, initially referred to a distinct part of the city, but later came to signify the city as a whole and to represent the biblical Land of Israel. In Greek and Latin the city&apos;s name was transliterated Hierosolyma (Greek: Ἱεροσόλυμα; in Greek hieròs, ἱερός, means holy), although the city was renamed Aelia Capitolina for part of the Roman period of its history. In Arabic, Jerusalem is most commonly known as [ ar القُدس ], transliterated as al-Quds and meaning &quot; The Holy &quot; or &quot; The Holy Sanctuary &quot;. Official Israeli government policy mandates that [ ar أُورُشَلِيمَ ], transliterated as Ūršalīm, which is the cognate of the Hebrew and English names, be used as the Arabic language name for the city in conjunction with [ ar القُدس ]. [ ar أُورُشَلِيمَ-القُدس ] &amp; lrm;. [ http://www.jerusalem.muni.il/jer_main/defaultnew.asp?lng%3D3 The Official Website of Jerusalem 19 September 2011 Municipality of Jerusalem ] [ History ] [ Timeline of Jerusalem History of Jerusalem ] Given the city&apos;s central position in both Israeli nationalism ( Zionism ) and Palestinian nationalism, the selectivity required to summarise more than 5,000 years of inhabited history is often [ http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2010/995/focus.htm A brief note on Jerusalem Azmi Bishara 22 September 2010 ] [ http://www.danielpipes.org/blog/2002/05/counterfeit-history-jerusalem Constructing a Counterfeit History of Jerusalem Daniel Pipes 22 2010 ] influenced by ideological bias or background (see Historiography and nationalism ). For example, the Jewish periods of the city&apos;s history are important to Israeli nationalists ( Zionists ), whose discourse suggests that modern Jews descend from the Israelites and Maccabees, { “No city in the world, not even Athens or Rome, ever played as great a role in the life of a nation for so long a time, as Jerusalem has done in the life of the Jewish people.” } { David Ben-Gurion, 1947 } { “For three thousand years, Jerusalem has been the center of Jewish hope and longing. No other city has played such a dominant role in the history, culture, religion and consciousness of a people as has Jerusalem in the life of Jewry and Judaism. Throughout centuries of exile, Jerusalem remained alive in the hearts of Jews everywhere as the focal point of Jewish history, the symbol of ancient glory, spiritual fulfillment and modern renewal. This heart and soul of the Jewish people engenders the thought that if you want one simple word to symbolize all of Jewish history, that word would be ‘Jerusalem.’” } { Teddy Kollek (DC: Washington Institute For Near East Policy, 1990), pp. 19–20. } whilst the Islamic, Christian and other non-Jewish periods of the city&apos;s history are important to Palestinian nationalism, whose discourse suggests that modern Palestinians descend from all the different peoples who have lived in the region. { &quot; Throughout history a great diversity of peoples has moved into the region and made Palestine their homeland: } { Canaanites, } { Jebusites, } { Philistines from } { Crete, Anatolian and } { Lydia n Greeks, } { Hebrews, } { Amorites, } { Edomites, } { Nabateans, } { Arameans, } { Romans, Arabs, and European } { crusaders, to name a few. Each of them appropriated different regions that overlapped in time and competed for sovereignty and land. Others, such as } { Ancient Egyptians, } { Hittites, } { Persians, } { Babylonians, and } { Mongols, were historical &apos;events&apos; whose successive occupations were as ravaging as the effects of major earthquakes  ... Like shooting stars, the various cultures shine for a brief moment before they fade out of official historical and cultural records of Palestine. The people, however, survive. In their customs and manners, fossils of these ancient civilizations survived until modernity—albeit modernity camouflaged under the veneer of Islam and } { Arabic culture. &quot; Ali Qleibo, Palestinian anthropologist } { &quot; (With reference to Palestinians in } { Ottoman times) Although proud of their } { Arab heritage and ancestry, the } { Palestinians considered themselves to be descended not only from Arab conquerors of the seventh century but also from } { indigenous peoples who had lived in the country since time immemorial, including the ancient } { Hebrews and the } { Canaanites before them. Acutely aware of the distinctiveness of Palestinian history, the Palestinians saw themselves as the heirs of its rich associations. &quot; } { Walid Khalidi, 1984, Before Their Diaspora: A Photographic History of the Palestinians, 1876–1948. Institute for Palestine Studies } As a result, both sides claim the history of the city has been politicized by the other in order to strengthen their relative claims to the city, [ http://hnn.us/articles/7257.html How Jews and Arabs Use (and Misuse) the History of Jerusalem to Score Points Eric H. Cline 22 September 2010 ] [ One Nation’s Capital Throughout History Eli E. Hertz 22 September 2010 ] and that this is borne out by the different focuses the different writers place on the various events and eras in the city&apos;s history. [ Overview of Jerusalem&apos;s historical periods ] [ Ancient period ] [ City of David History of ancient Israel and Judah ] { Stepped Stone Structure, City of Jebus } Ceramic evidence indicates occupation of the City of David, within present-day Jerusalem, as far back as the Copper Age (c. 4th millennium BCE), [ Eerdmans Dictionary of the Bible Freedman David Noel Wm B. Eerdmans Publishing 0-8028-2400-5 1 January 2000 694–95 ] with evidence of a permanent settlement during the early Bronze Age (c. 3000–2800 BCE). { Killebrew Ann E. &quot; Biblical Jerusalem: An Archaeologiref name= &quot; mfa-40th &quot; &gt; } [ http://www.cbs.gov.il/population/new_2009/table3.pdf PDF Israel Central Bureau of Statistics TABLE 3. – POPULATION(1) OF LOCALITIES NUMBERING ABOVE 2,000 RESIDENTS AND OTHER RURAL POPULATION ON 31/12/2008 26 October 2009 ] { cal Assessment &quot; in Andrew G. Vaughn and Ann E. Killebrew, eds., &quot; Jerusalem in Bible and Archaeology: The First Temple Period &quot; (SBL Symposium Series 18; Atlanta: Society of Biblical Literature, 2003) } The Execration Texts (c.  19th century BCE), which refer to a city called Roshlamem or Rosh-ramen and the Amarna letters (c.  14th century BCE) may be the earliest mention of the city. [ Jerusalem in Bible and Archaeology: the First Temple Period Vaughn, Andrew G. Ann E. Killebrew 1 August 2003 Jerusalem at the Time of the United Monarchy 1-58983-066-0 32–33 Society of Biblical Literature Atlanta ] [ http://www.biu.ac.il/JS/rennert/history_2.html Bar-Ilan University Ingeborg Rennert Center for Jerusalem Studies History of Jerusalem from Its Beginning to David Jerusalem: Life Throughout the Ages in a Holy City 18 January 2007 Shalem Yisrael 3 March 1997 ] Some archaeologists, including Kathleen Kenyon, believe Jerusalem { the original name URU URU salem KI in Akkadian—listed in the Amarna letters when it was still a fortified well of the Egyptians and ruled by Abi Heba—meant &quot; city of peace &quot; } as a city was founded by Northwest Semitic people with organized settlements from around 2600 BCE. According to Jewish tradition, the city was founded by Shem and Eber, ancestors of Abraham. In the biblical account, Jerusalem ( &quot; Salem &quot; ) when first mentioned is ruled by Melchizedek, an ally of Abraham (identified with Shem in legend). Later, in the time of Joshua, Jerusalem lay within territory allocated to the tribe of Benjamin ( [ Joshua 18:28 NIV ] ), but continued to be under the independent control of the Jebusite s until it was conquered by David and made into the capital of the united Kingdom of Israel (c.  11th century  BCE). [ A Promise Fulfilled: Theodor Herzl, Chaim Weizmann, David Ben-Gurion, and the Creation of the State of Israel Greenfeld Howard 29 March 2005 Greenwillow 0-06-051504-X 32 ] [ http://www.cityofdavid.org.il/timeline_eng.asp City of David Timeline Ir David Foundation 18 January 2007 ] [ bible-david v b ] Recent excavations of a Large Stone Structure and a nearby Stepped Stone Structure are widely believed [ December 2010 ] to be the remains of King David&apos;s palace. The excavations have been interpreted by some archaeologists as lending credence to the biblical narrative, while others disagree. [ King David&apos;s Palace Is Found, Archaeologist Says Erlanger Steven 5 August 2005 24 May 2007 http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/05/international/middleeast/05jerusalem.html?ex%3D1280894400%26amp%3Ben%3D3c435bc7bd0cd531%26amp%3Bei%3D5088 The New York Times ] According to Hebrew scripture, King David reigned for 40 years. The generally accepted estimate of the conclusion of this reign is 970 BCE. The Bible records that David was succeeded by his son Solomon, [ The Complete Book of When and Where: In The Bible And Throughout History Michael E. Sharon O. Rusten, Philip Comfort, and Walter A. Elwell Tyndale House Publishers, Inc. 0-8423-5508-1 28 February 2005 20–1, 67 ] who builtthe Holy Temple on Mount Moriah. Solomon&apos;s Temple (later known as the First Temple), went on to play a pivotal role in Jewish history as the repository of the Ark of the Covenant. [ http://www.andrews.edu/ARCHAEOLOGY/archive/merling/newpage3.htm Andrew&apos;s University Where is the Ark of the Covenant? Merling, David 22 January 2007 26 August 1993 ] For more than 400 years, until the Babylonia n conquest in 587 BCE, Jerusalem was the political capital of the united Kingdom of Israel and then the Kingdom of Judah. During this period, known as the First Temple Period, [ http://www.bu.edu/mzank/Jerusalem/p/period2-2-1.htm Boston University Zank Michael Capital of Judah I (930–722) 22 January 2007 ] the Temple was the religious center of the Israelites. { Jerusalem: Illustrated History Atlas Martin Gilbert, Macmillan Publishing, New York, 1978, p. 11 } On Solomon&apos;s death (c. 930 BCE), the ten northern tribes split off to form the Kingdom of Israel. Under the leadership of the House of David and Solomon, Jerusalem remained the capital of the Kingdom of Judah. [ http://www.bu.edu/mzank/Jerusalem/p/period2-2.htm Boston University Capital of Judah (930–586) Zank Michael 22 January 2007 ] When the Assyria ns conquered the Kingdom of Israel in 722 BCE, Jerusalem was strengthened by a great influx of refugees from the northern kingdom. The First Temple period ended around 586 BCE, as the Babylonians conquered Judah and Jerusalem, and laid waste to Solomon&apos;s Temple. [ Classical antiquity ] [ Yehud Medinata Jerusalem during the Achaemenid period ] [ Jerusalem during the Second Temple Period Aelia Capitolina ] In 538 BCE, after 50 years of Babylonian captivity, Persian King Cyrus the Great invited the Jews to return to Judah to rebuild the Temple. [ http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search%3DEzra%201%3A1-4%3B%206%3A1-5%26amp%3Bversion%3D51%3B Ezra 1:1–4; 6:1–5 Biblegateway.com 11 September 2010 ] Construction of the Second Temple was completed in 516 BCE, during the reign of Darius the Great, 70 years after the destruction of the First Temple. [ Between Rome and Jerusalem: 300 Years of Roman-Judaean Relations Sicker Martin 0-275-97140-6 Praeger Publishers 30 January 2001 2 ] [ http://www.bu.edu/mzank/Jerusalem/p/period2-3.htm Boston University Center of the Persian Satrapy of Judah (539–323) Zank Michael 22 January 2007 ] In about 445 BCE, King Artaxerxes I of Persia issued a decree allowing the city and the walls to be rebuilt. [ http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search%3DNehemiah%201%3A3%3B%202%3A1-8%3B%26amp%3Bversion%3D51%3B Nehemiah 1:3; 2:1–8 Biblegateway.com 11 September 2010 ] Jerusalem resumed its role as capital of Judah and center of Jewish worship. When Alexander the Great conquered the Persian Empire, Jerusalem and Judea came under Macedonian control, eventually falling to the Ptolemaic dynasty under Ptolemy I. In 198 BCE, Ptolemy V lost Jerusalem and Judea to the Seleucids under Antiochus III. The Seleucid attempt to recast Jerusalem as a Hellenized city-state came to a head in 168 BCE with the successful Maccabean revolt of Mattathias and his five sons against Antiochus Epiphanes, and their establishment of the Hasmonean Kingdom in 152 BCE with Jerusalem again as its capital. In 63 BCE, Pompey the Great intervened in a Hasmonean struggle for the throne and captured Jerusalem, extending the influence of the Roman Republic over Judea. [ Schiffman Lawrence H. From Text to Tradition: A History of Second Temple and Rabbinic Judaism Ktav Publishing House 1991 0-88125-371-5 60–79 ] Following a short invasion by Parthians, backing the rival Hasmonean rulers, Judea became a scene of struggle between pro-Roman and pro-Parthian forces, eventually leading to the emergence of Edomite Herod, who would be appointed King of the Jews by the Roman senate and establish the Herodian dynasty. Roman siege and destruction of Jerusalem (David Roberts, 1850) As Rome became stronger it installed Herod as a Jewish client king. Herod the Great, as he was known, devoted himself to developing and beautifying the city. He built walls, towers and palaces, and expanded the Temple Mount, buttressing the courtyard with blocks of stone weighing up to 100 tons. Under Herod, the area of the Temple Mount doubled in size. [ This Is Jerusalem Har-el Menashe Canaan Publishing House 68–95 1977 0-86628-002-2 ] [ http://www.bu.edu/mzank/Michael_Zank/Jerusalem/templemount.html The Temple Mount Zank Michael Boston University 22 January 2007 ] Shortly after Herod&apos;s death, in 6 CE Judea came under direct Roman rule as the Iudaea Province, [ The Historical Jesus: the life of a Mediterranean Jewish peasant Crossan John Dominic John Dominic Crossan 0-06-061629-6 HarperCollins San Francisco 26 February 1993 Reprinted 92 from 4 BCE until 6 CE, when Rome, after exiling [Herod Archelaus] to Gaul, assumed direct prefectural control of his territories ] although Herod&apos;s descendants through Agrippa II remained client kings of neighbouring territories until 96 CE. Roman rule over Jerusalem and the region began to be challenged with the First Jewish–Roman War, which resulted in the destruction of the Second Temple in 70 CE. Jerusalem once again served as the capital of Judea during the three-year rebellion known as the Bar Kokhba revolt, beginning in 132 CE. The Romans succeeded in suppressing the revolt in 135 CE. Emperor Hadrian combined Iudaea Province with neighboring provinces to create Syria Palaestina, erasing the name of Judea, { Elizabeth Speller, Following Hadrian: A Second-Century Journey Through the Roman Empire, Oxford University Press, 2004 p.218 } romanized the city, renaming it Aelia Capitolina, [ http://www.usd.edu/erp/Palestine/people%26amp%3Bp.htm http://web.archive.org/web/20080310053409/http%3A//www.usd.edu/erp/Palestine/people%26amp%3Bp.htm 10 March 2008 Palestine: People and Places 18 April 2007 Lehmann Clayton Miles The On-line Encyclopedia of the Roman Provinces The University of South Dakota ] and banned the Jews from entering it on pain of death, except for one day each year ( 9 Ab ). These anti-Jewish measures [ Peter Schäfer The Bar Kokhba war reconsidered: new perspectives on the second Jewish revolt against Rome http://books.google.com/books?id%3D1TA-Fg4wBnUC%26amp%3Bpg%3DPA36 4 December 2011 2003 Mohr Siebeck 978-3-16-148076-8 36– ] [ http://www.usd.edu/erp/Palestine/history.htm http://web.archive.org/web/20080310053428/http%3A//www.usd.edu/erp/Palestine/history.htm 10 March 2008 Palestine: History 18 April 2007 22 February 2007 Lehmann Clayton Miles The On-line Encyclopedia of the Roman Provinces The University of South Dakota ] [ Cohen Shaye J. D. Judaism to Mishnah: 135–220 C.E Christianity and Rabbinic Judaism: A Parallel History of their Origins and Early Development Hershel Shanks 1996 Washington DC 196 Biblical Archaeology Society ] which affected also Jewish Christians, { Emily Jane Hunt, Christianity in the second century: the case of Tatian, Psychology Press, 2003 p.7 } was taken to ensure &apos;the complete and permanent secularization of Jerusalem.&apos; { E. Mary Smallwood The Jews under Roman rule: from Pompey to Diocletian : a study in political relations BRILL, 1981 p.460. } The enforcement of the ban on Jews entering Aelia Capitolina continued until the 4th century CE. In the five centuries following the Bar Kokhba revolt, the city remained under Roman then Byzantine rule. During the 4th century, the Roman Emperor Constantine I constructed Christian sites in Jerusalem, such as the Church of the Holy Sepulchre. Jerusalem reached a peak in size and population at the end of the Second Temple Period, when the city covered two square kilometers (0.8 sq mi.) and had a population of 200,000. [ This Is Jerusalem Har-el Menashe Canaan Publishing House 68–95 0-86628-002-2 1977 ] From the days of Constantine until the 7th century, Jews were banned from Jerusalem.
